Her skin is golden too, thick muscles beneath its surface. Around her neck a torque of gold glistens. Gold stitching upon her dress outlines the powerful lines of her body. The torches burn bright in the darkness, and she blazes too. They outline a path up to the palace steps where she is standing. The light shines upon her jewellery, on her skin, and she seems to shimmer before us like one of my visions. As the chariot stops beside the path of torches she steps to the left and claps her hands. The palace doors are thrown open behind her. Servants come out, bearing a long red tapestry. They unroll it, throwing it down the steps. It unfurls dark as blood, a red tide flowing out between the lines of torches. I gasp. In my mind I see the steps of the palace in Troy flow with blood, real blood, liquid and sticky. It smelled of rot and the grave and the sea.

 Clytaemnestra strides forward, beside the tapestry, not upon it. Her long tawny hair falls wild and loose down her back, like the mane of a lion. I have never seen a lion in the wild, but my father had one brought to the palace once. It prowled in its cage, movements constrained by the bars. She reminds me of its captive grace, and the sense I had that were the bars removed it would explode into violence. She comes to stand before us, at the foot of the pathway she has created. Agamemnon steps down from the chariot and she smiles, showing her teeth.

 They speak, and at her urging he strides forward upon the tapestries, his feet treading upon the thick red path. In my memory, he and his men stalk forward as Troy burns, their sandals soaking up blood. He goes through the doors alone, and Clytaemnestra turns to me.

 'Come princess, there is no need to remain in the chariot. Come into the palace, my women will see you bathed and dressed.' Her smile does not touch her eyes. I say nothing, thinking of the lion again, and her teeth. She raises her eyebrows. 'My husband is very taken with you, little bird. Perhaps he is in love. You do not have to speak to me, if you do not wish, but come inside.'

 I find my voice. 'Why do you call me that?'

 She laughs. 'You are so dark and still, you make me think of the nightingales in my gardens at dusk. And I have heard tales of your visions, your songs.'

 I do not speak again, but allow her women to lead me from the chariot and into the palace. I do not trust her kind words. She spoke as sweetly to her husband, and I know the malice which must fester in her heart toward him.

 There are low fires lit within the whole palace, so that the marble floors shine with light, and flickering shadows crowd in the corners. I am led to a bath chamber, a bronze tub brimming with water, rose petals floating on its surface. Steam clouds the air. The servants take my clothes and do not return them. I sink into the water and let out a sigh. It is soothing upon my skin, which seems to soften beneath its surface. I smell sweet now, like flower sap. I look up and find Clytaemnestra standing there, watching me. I cannot read her expression. Her brow furrows.

 'How came you by that?' she asks, indicating a bruise the size of a palm upon my breast. I look down, and remember.

 I speak without thinking. 'That, that is the love token your husband left upon me.' I am surprised by the venom in my voice. So, it seems, is she. Her lips part, as if she would speak, but a servant comes in.

 'Milady, the King wishes her brought to him.'

 Clytaemnestra nods. 'Of course.'

 I am given a white dress to wear. It is cool upon my skin, still hot from the bath. We walk through the palace. Water clings to my hair, weighing it down. The girl takes me to a bedroom, and then leaves. He is standing there waiting, and smiles to see me. My pulse flutters beneath my breast. I thought I had forgotten how to feel, my emotions dying with my father at Troy, but being in this house has awoken them again. He walks toward me and I feel a sick dread. Maybe I am not the dead girl I thought. The naked want in his eyes is obscene. He props his sword against the bed and comes closer, close enough that I can see the individual hairs in his finely trimmed beard, like little spikes. Do not touch me, I think. I do not want your hands on me again. I do not, cannot, speak, but let him manoeuvre me, backing me toward the bed. His teeth shine in the torchlight as he smiles. My newly awoken fear has aroused him. I feel nausea swoop in my stomach and find myself longing for the numbness I had felt in my shock. He looks at me and sees my city burning. I am a trophy to him, a marker of his victory. I think again of Clytaemnestra. She will avenge my city and me, whether she knows it or not. It is as if this summons her. I look over his shoulder and see her behind, stalking forward on quiet feet, her sword raised. My eyes meet hers for a second. She raises an eyebrow. I look back at him, seeking to keep his attention fixed on me. She moves closer.

 'Agamemnon,' she says, her voice low. 'This is for our daughter.' He turns at her voice, his hand going to his hip as he registers her words, but of course his sword is not there. Her blade plunges into his stomach and out, dark blood spurting forth, spattering her dress. Her smile is so wide it is a grimace, a snarl. He falls sideways onto the floor, crying out wordlessly in pain and surprise. His head hits the ground but he is still moving. One hand goes to his waist, coming up red. The other gropes behind him, reaching for his sword. I am faster. I snatch it up and unsheathe it, the scabbard clattering on the floor.

 'This is for my people,' I say, and I stab down into his flesh, a hand span higher than the wound she has given him. It goes in deep. I am stronger than I thought. He coughs, red foam gathering on his lips. I leave the sword in him and step back, looking down. Impaled, helpless, he shudders and jerks, pinned by his own sword. He tries to speak, but only spits blood onto the floor. She kneels beside him, gripping his head with her hand.

 'For Iphigenia,' she says, her lips near his, and she presses her sword down and across, slitting his throat. His lifeblood gushes forth, splashing into her smiling mouth, streaking her skin, dark flecks landing on her like red petals. She stands and looks at me.

 'So,' she says. 'Why did you help me?' If I thought my heart beat fast before, it is nothing to now. It throbs in my temples, my throat, hummingbird fast. I meet her eyes. She is still smiling, fierce and wide. Awed, I incline my head toward her. Blood drips from her sword onto the floor, joining the spreading pool there. She stands like a statue, terrible and still. I look up at her again, unable to keep my eyes from her.

 'You are not the only one he has hurt,' I say.

 'I did not do this for you,' she says after a pause.

 I laugh. 'No, and yet it is done nonetheless. We gave him a quicker death than he deserved.'

 'Is that so, little nightingale?' she says. The blood, his blood, still glistens upon her lips in the torchlight. She steps around him, closer to me. 'You are even more vicious than I thought.'

 'Maybe so. Will you kill me as well?' I ask, raising my chin. I know the answer, but I want to hear her say it, to make her admit it. I can almost taste the blood in my mouth.

 'No,' she says quietly, very close to me now. 'You helped me,' she says. 'I will not forget.' I can see her chest rise and fall in her excitement, a vein throbbing in her throat. I cannot help myself; I reach out for her, and kiss her. The sword is still in her hand, but the other comes up, stroking my wet hair. I fall against her, clinging to her. She tastes of the death she has wrought, salt blood upon her lips. She drops the sword, but I do not hear it hit the floor, a roaring in my ears. We fall back upon the bed. Her weight presses me down, her touch upon my skin blotting out everything. I feel more than I have in days, a tide of sensation, my pulse beating like drums inside of me. I am giddy with triumph. I kiss the trail of blood from her neck, her throat, her cheek. It is like ambrosia upon my lips, the taste of victory and vengeance.

full_story:
Brauron belongs to the Arktoi and Artemis does what she must to keep it that way. The bars are hers and the strip joints are hers and the sheriff is in her pocket. Every other club that wants to run product up or down the coast has to pass through her town and they pay for the privilege. If they think that the only all-female motorcycle club for seven states is going to be a pushover, they are quickly proved wrong. The desert has a wide embrace to welcome the dead.

There is a woman in Artemis' bed and she does what she must to keep her there. Kallisto is bright and golden; she smells of gasoline and warm asphalt and everything Artemis loves. Artemis leaves epic poems of her devotion with her teeth on Kallisto's thighs, presses her desire inside on the tip of her tongue. Kallisto sobs and begs, hips rolling, but Artemis doesn't let go. Her love is greedy; Kallisto knew that before she ever kissed her, quick and chaste behind the garage in the fall when the weather was turning. Now it is summer and the sweat stands out on her lover's skin. Artemis laps it from the hollow of her throat, fingers slick and curling.

Her life is everything she wanted when she left her father's house.

She's afraid it won't last.

 

The trouble starts small. Her father's Olympians are scaring patrons out of Arktoi bars, harassing the staff, driving club profits down. It's petty, no less than she expected from her father but so much milder than she dreamed. It still needs to be dealt with. She still doesn't want to.

"I'll go for you," Kallisto says one morning over breakfast.

Artemis' head jerks up. "You're sure?"

"Of course. If he's half the asshole you've said he is, you don't need to be anywhere near him." Kallisto dishes scrambled eggs onto their plates. "I'm your second; I can speak for you. I'll get it sorted out and be back by dinner."

She isn't back by dinner.

 

Artemis finds her in the kitchen the next morning, clutching a cup of coffee, eyes bloodshot. Before Artemis can ask what happened, Kallisto walks out.

They play a game of avoidance for weeks. Kallisto shows up to club meetings and her shifts at the garage, but she won't sleep in Artemis' bed, won't even meet her eyes.

Artemis corners her eventually in the hall bathroom, hunched over the toilet. Kallisto is only dry heaving, nerves and not illness; the source is obvious--a pregnancy test lies forgotten in the sink. Artemis doesn't bother to count the blue lines; her sinking feeling drops all the way through the floor.

"Who was it?" (She knows already and hates that she knows.) "Who?" she howls and Kallisto flinches.

Kallisto drags the back of her hand over her mouth, scrubbing away bile. "It was your father."

 

Kallisto tells her what happened in fits and starts. Artemis sits beside her on the bathroom floor, close but not touching, and listens. It's a familiar story.

(Artemis remembers Leda, one of the Olympians' women. She got along with everybody, always had a smile and a kind word. Once, after a patching over, she'd been making eyes at a new guy all night. It had been enough to set off Zeus's temper.

She remembers watching Zeus throw Leda down on a pool table and fuck her right there in front of everyone; the wings of her swan tattoo flexing along her shoulder blades as she tried to crawl away.

Artemis had been twelve.)

Eventually, carefully, they move back into Artemis' room. She spoons up behind Kallisto on the bed, slides one hand around to rest on her stomach.

This could be her child. The only child she may ever have.

"It's gonna be alright," Artemis says. "We'll make it alright."

"Yes," Kallisto breathes back. "We will."

 

Artemis is wrist-deep in an engine rebuild when her phone rings. She wipes her hands off, digs her phone out from her pocket. "What."

"Art." It's her brother. He's the only one who ever got away with calling her that. (He stayed behind and most days she doesn't blame him. It's not like Daddy was trying to watch him in the shower.)

"Your girl's been here for the last two hours. She's in Dad's office; sounds like they're just talking, but--"

"Yeah." Sometimes talking is dangerous enough. "Thanks, Apollo. I appreciate it."

"Of course, sweetheart. Stay safe, okay?"

She hangs up so she won't have to lie to him.

 

The following night, Artemis and Kallisto go for a ride. 

(It's something they did more often when the club was young: take just one bike and a blanket and drive out into the desert well past dark. They'd watch the stars and make out like teenagers until it got too cold to stand.)

Kallisto wanders in a slow circle after they park, talking about her doctor's appointment and the girls she met in the waiting room. Artemis drops the kickstand, draws her gun from the saddlebag.

"Get on your knees, honey." 

Kallisto glances back, a smile already starting to form. She thinks Artemis is flirting right up until she spots the gun. The blood drains from her face. "Artemis, please--"

"Turn the fuck around and get down on your knees."

She does, slowly, shakily, hands raised. "Baby, you've got to understand--"

Artemis doesn't want to hear it. "I understand perfectly. You sold me out."

"No, no, that's not true." Kallisto risks a peek over her shoulder; her pupils are blown in fear. "I...I made a deal, yeah, but it's the best thing for all of us. It's going to keep us safe. We just...we just have to get patched over, and then he'll leave us alone."

"He'll leave us alone," Artemis repeats. "I should give up my club--my club--because you think he'll keep his word?"

"You'll lose the club anyway!" Kallisto screams. The silence after is ringing, lasts for a solid minute before Kallisto adds, "He's so angry, baby. We have to take his terms. Do you know what he wants to do to us? Do you know what he wants to do to you?"

"Of course I fucking know!"

(She's known for years, known since he looked up and smiled, one hand pressing bruises into the back of Leda's neck. He did everything but touch her and she thought she was safe.

Whatever she does now, it will be war: with her father first, and then whatever's left of the Olympians after. She doesn't care. She wants a war, wants bloodshed and ruin, wants the world to suffer for almost being everything she hoped for.

But this could be her child. The only child she may ever have.)

"I did it for you," Kallisto is sobbing. "I did it for us."

"I know, baby." Artemis pulls the trigger.

Eldest of the sisters, Medusa alone stood the guardian of the Eastern gates of Sicani by the lapping sea. With unblinking gaze, she watched against the rising of the sun and the tides of invaders that sought to take the wide olive groves of Sicani for themselves. Her sister, Euryale, guarded the western gate with brazen hands and fearsome cries. The people of the city stood with her there. They held their shields together as impenetrable scales under her guidance. Stheno, the youngest, the softest of aspect, hers was to face the mountainous north with its crags and eagles' reach. With her yellow wings, she often flew to perch there. The great eagles and the seahawks, they flocked to her and took the flesh of the sea from her brazen hands.

The sea that lapped upon the harbor, they did not guard against. Were they not the daughters of the chthonic sea? They were the daughters of Phycys and Ceto coiled down far into the deep. They were the daughters of wine deep darkness and salt and echoes.

Medusa was in love. 

She did not show it easily. That was not her nature. Her nature was unblinking. Her nature was the strong slide of great coils through the rolling hills bestrewn in ancient olive groves. 

In the springtime of the year, when the yellow pollen fell from the trees, she first looked out from the Eastern gate and met the gaze of grey-eyed Athena. She, the daughter of a younger god, whose father consumed her mother in a single swallow. His monstrous aspect hidden between red smacking lips and a golden beard.

Medusa, she was unafraid. She strode out from her gate. Her spear in her hand. She pushed back the frozen mask of her helm, the bronze of it an eternal scream of righteous rage. The pollen fell golden upon her face. It trembled upon her lashes. Her bronze hair tumbled free. It alone indicated the tumbled nature of her feelings in that moment. That golden hour when she first met the gaze of grey-eyed Athena, wise as a serpent and contained too in her aspect.

They gazed into each other on that morning. 

It would be imprudent to describe then what occurred between them. What happened when the eldest of the Gorgon sisters and Pallas Athena first met. It would be best to then say that Medusa opened her gates to Athena and let her into the city to dwell there. 

On the highest hill within the polis, Medusa built for Athena a temple with wide open doors. That all might come in and find wisdom.

In the temple of Athena, they were often together. Athena at her loom, as Medusa watched her clever hands at their weaving. It was their home. They met with Euryale and shared bread drizzled with olive oil. They met with Stheno and played games. 

They were in love. They pleated their fingers as one might weave the threads in a loom. They played at games together. 

It would be imprudent to say more and yet, who writes with prudence that tells the tales of gods?

The kisses of their lips were as rich and golden as an olive oil of first press. Not virgin sisters kisses these, no. Medusa was a daughter of the chthonic sea. She kissed as fiercely. Athena, whose first words were a battle cry, she gave nothing way, but willing battled for Medusa's regard. Athena was the goddess of craft and arts and skill. Her fingers were clever. She crafted such things as to give her love delight. Athena greatly loved to rest her clever head upon the wild bronze masses of Medusa's hair and speak the names of clouds as they lay upon the flat roof of the temple. Medusa greatly loved to pay tribute to Athena and hold her tightly wrapped in her coils. They delighted in each other. 

They were in love. 

The lapping sea brushed against the sea steps that led down into the water. It was summer and all was blessed in the world. The olives grew round and ripe in the ancient olive groves that stretched into the rolling hills of the East.

In autumn of the year, the people of Sicani plucked the olives and took in the harvest. They fortified the walls of their homes. They painted the doors blue against the winter winds.

The lapping sea surged in its tides against the port of Sicani. It rose and fell. The boats of the fishermen rose and fell with it.

The wintertime came. With it the storms of grey skies and rain. In sorrowing aspect, Athena left for a journey to spend the shortest days with her father on high Olympus. That there might be some wisdom there.

They parted with sorrowing hearts and hopeful fingers. 

Medusa was unafraid. Stheno mourned the loss of long days of flying in blue skies. Euryale used this time in training with the people. But Medusa reveled in the rain. She walked down the sea steps and she swam in the sea. Was it not her mother? Was it not her father?

Alas, Medusa had forgotten it was no longer chthonic days. There then her crime. To forget and for an instant close her eyes against the salt of the sea.

For in that winter storm, Poseidon looked upon her with her clouds of bronze hair floating in the fierce waves and found her beautiful. As she slithered back up onto the sea steps, he called to her and offered all the bounty of the sea if she would lie with him, but once. Her aspect was unchanged. She looked at him with unblinking blue-green eyes and picked up her spear in answer.

She forgot. What is a spear against the sea?

The waves roared. They crashed upon the harbor. There was no sea wall. The waves rushed past. They flooded the streets. Salt water poured past the doors painted blue. Whole families drowned. Grandmothers clutching at the plump legs of the babe just born. Euryale did what she could. She gathered her soldiers and led the people to the higher ground. Stheno battered as well she could against the wind and led them to the high passes in the mountains.

Medusa, she remained. She alone was the guardian of the Eastern gates.

But this was the sea. She fell back higher and higher within the emptied city. Poseidon pursued her. She cast her spear and the waves parted before it. She climbed the steps to the temple of Athena. She went into the temple with wide open doors that all might come in and find wisdom there.

It would be cruel to speak of what occurred there on the floor of the temple of Athena. What occurred on the marble that Medusa herself had carved for her love. The sea desired. The sea took. When the waters finally receded, buildings had been thrown from their moorings. Ships lay tilted upon the flat roofs where the people had gathered in halcyon days.

And the dead. There were so many dead. 

Medusa screamed. She was rage personified. 

She thrashed with her coils. She did as much damage then as the sea had done. Her screams were unending. She wrent the sky with them.

In the mountains above, Euryale wept. Stheno hid her face behind her wings. The Sicani cried out in fear. 

The sisters parted from them then. They went to their sister, but Medusa could not be comforted. 

Athena returned. 

Tears poured down her stalwart cheeks. But Athena could only be the goddess that she was. She spoke of temperance and strategy and appeals to the law of Olympus. The blue-green gaze of Medusa met grey-eyed Athena then. She asked then what of the law for Metis? What of Athena's mother, consumed by her father, the young king of the gods. This was the rule of law. She did not say these words. She shouted them as she crashed her mighty coils. Athena gave her then the only comfort that she could.

Medusa's aspect, she changed to the face of her bronze helm. An eternal scream that her voice might rest. Her bronze curls that she had so loved, that had so drawn the sea lapping softly at the sea steps, she transformed into venomous serpents that none might trifle with her again. Her eyes, the eyes of the daughter of a chthonic sea, she made as stone and to look them was to become stone. Even the sea. Even the ever changing sea would be stone were it to look therein.

She might have then have waited. But for all her wisdom, Athena was a child of a younger god. Medusa bid her leave and Athena left. Her love grew gravid with the children the sea had forced upon her that day. She would not let fall from her body. She kept them inside herself. She ripped up the ancient olive groves. She destroyed the temple. She destroyed the city. Until even Euryale and Stheno were forced to make way from the city that was polis no more. Only the dead lived there. 

Only statues of heroes that sought to slay the monster that dwelt there. They wanted the treasure of Siciani. The golden casks of olive oil transmuted by time and legend into boxes of gold. 

There was no treasure. The olive oil had long since gone rancid on the touch of the sea.

Athena in time grew wiser then. It is not prudent to speak of the gods being unwise. But even the most clever can grow in wisdom. What were the thoughts of the goddess of craft and skill and defense when she sent Perseus with a shield as bright as a mirror to her love? It cannot be known.

But thereafter upon the shield of grey-eyed Athena, wise as a serpent, she bore the face of Medusa in her eternal rage. A goddess of wisdom may not be inclined to forgetfulness. She may also consider that in the end, even gods may die and the sea may turn to stone.

full_story:
Zoro's atheism was never a secret to anyone in the crew. He had first made it known during the time they visited Skypeia, an island floating in the sky, when they faced a so-called god who ruled the land with terror and dictatorship. Such a god was laughable as he needed to use such methods. What he had weren't believers or followers. They were prisoners trapped within the cages of his power.

 

If gods and goddesses were to really exist, and everything that happens is according to fate, isn't the world we live in just a book written to entertain mankind's supposed creators? Zoro has never once prayed to a god because he knows that he's the only one that could carve his fate. If he ever did face a real god, he wouldn't hesitate to draw his sword.

 

If gods and goddesses were real and they are pure and kind as what people acclaim, the world should be a much better place. It should be rid of evil. It should be rid of grief and anger. It should be rid of sadness, of pain, violence, and abuse. But it's not.

 

"So you would fight a god?" Chopper asked with admiration visible in his eyes, twinkling in awe as he made himself comfortable on one of the couches in the crow's nest.

 

"I don't see why not." The older responded, counting his barbell reps in his head.

 

The kid seemed concerned. "But they're gods, you know! And what if they're not bad?"

 

"So what if they're a god?" Zoro grunted as he put down the giant barbell, grabbing a towel to wipe his sweat dry. "If they're not bad, then I'll leave them be. It works like that, no?"

 

Before Chopper could respond, both of their attention was diverted to the sound of the trap door opening, a blond head popping out of it. It was Sanji, the crew's cook.

 

"Oye, you two. It's time for dinner." The blond notified them, Chopper immediately getting off his seat to climb down the crow's nest.

 

"I'll be there in a minute." The swordsman replied, signalling that he'd tidy up first. The other two went on to the galley while he stayed behind to gather his swords and put the things he used back to where they were placed.

 

When he was done, he made his way to dine with the rest of the crew. As he was about to enter the kitchen, he noticed a little snake trying to sneak in, and his first instinct was to pick it up.

 

It was a peculiar snake. Its tail was severed, but it didn't look like a clean cut from a knife or a sword. Rather, it looked like it was plucked off. Neither was it bleeding. It was merely weakened, though, on the verge of dying.

 

"Change the fate. Save Medusa." He heard a voice whispering directly in his head. It travelled from ear to ear. It was eerie.

 

"Change the fate. Save Medusa." Zoro had to look around this time. The voice felt like it was passing by him. His surroundings started to become a blur.

 

"Change the fate. Save Medusa." It came from his right.

 

"Change the fate. Save Medusa." Now from the left.

 

"Change the fate. Save Medusa." The voice whispered from behind and everything went pitch black.

 

The swordsman, however, remained alert, right hand reaching for his sword while the other still held the snake, even as it forcefully tried to slip out of his hold.

 

As Zoro's eyes started to adjust to the dark, he could feel the snake growing stronger by the second. It coiled around his arm, and he only let go of it when it buried its sharp fangs under his skin accompanied by a deafening scream. "CHANGE THE FATE!!! SAVE MEDUSA!!!" There was a loud bang before the swordsman finally lost consciousness.

 

 

 

 

* * *

 

 

 

 

Gods and goddesses. That concept is something Zoro is familiar with, but would never understand. Do people worship them because they really want to? Do they revere them because they feel overwhelming love, peace, and joy in their presence? Is that really the case? Or do they just worship them because they have the power to make them suffer and take their lives? Or perhaps, they just put them on such a high pedestal because they have been enslaved by the idea that was passed onto them by the previous generations? Nevertheless, Zoro would never be caught kneeling in front of a god even if his life was at stake.

 

"How peculiar. He has got green hair." He heard a woman's voice not very far from him. His head was pounding after just waking up. The bright blue sky was the first to greet Zoro as soon as he opened his eyes, birds flying high, twittering in glee. Looking to the left, he saw a line of tall trees serving as an entrance to the woods. Underneath him, he felt the soft brush of grasses against the fabric of his clothes. To his right were footsteps approaching him. "Mister, are you alright?"

 

"Uh... yeah." Zoro groaned as he pulled himself up, still feeling a bit woozy. Now that he had a clear look at his surroundings, he immediately concluded that he was separated from the crew. He wasn't sure how, but it was certainly related to that snake he found outside the galley. "Do you know what place this is?"As the swordsman looked at the person who approached him, he was slightly taken aback at how fair-looking the maiden was. She had long, beautiful locks that glistened under the gentle rays of sunlight. Her skin was smoother than porcelain, putting even snow to shame at how white it was. Her eyes were the prettiest he had seen, fiercely staring straight into him with kindness and warmth. However, what caught his attention was her elegance as she carried herself in her beautiful white dress. Though the design was something he had never seen before.

 

"Am I in a foreign country?"

 

"I believe so, sir. Given the way you dress, I am quite certain that you are not one of the people of Greece." The woman answered, politeness apparent in her tone, adjusting her hold on the porcelain jar she was carrying.

 

"Greece? Where even is that?" Zoro whispered to himself, his stomach suddenly making a rumbling sound which made him flush. He remembered that he didn't get to eat dinner before he got in this place.

 

"Oh, my. Are you, perhaps, hungry? I would like to offer you food, but I still need to fetch some water for Goddess Athena's temple." The woman seemed conflicted. "Would you be willing to wait?"

 

Goddess Athena? Who?

 

"Ah- yeah, thanks. Sure." Zoro scratched the back of his neck, not wanting to refuse the beautiful maiden's offer of free food. "I'll help you carry that in return."

"I swore on the Styx that I would keep it a secret. If you want to know, you will have to ask Persephone."

With that, Apollo left the Underworld, his heart heavy with disappointment. Hades watched him go, and the secret of Hyacinthus's rebirth was safe for now. He walked to the banks of the Styx, mentally summoning the goddess of oaths and hatred. The eldest Oceanid appeared to him in all her dark glory.

"I cannot tell you what that oath was."

"I know." The God of the Underworld told his subordinate.

"When Thalia Grace was born you sent quite a few monsters after her but you have not done the same for the Percy Jackson. Why?"

Styx raised an eyebrow.

"I am unable to do so. The day after that child of the broken oath was born, Poseidon descended here and drank from my waters to atone for his misdeed." Styx admitted.

"It is not like you to be quite that lenient my dear." Hades pried.

"What did you do to the child?"

Styx gave her lord a cold, cruel smile, her eyes glimering with the hate that was her domain.

"Her father broke an oath. An oath not to have children." Her piece said Styx dove back into her dark waters.

Hades paused by the banks, pondering back on Apollo's words. The sun god had told him that the tree that was Icarus had gathered Perseus Jackson's demigod essence. After Hyacinthus had died, Apollo used the demigod essence lingering in the first hyacinth flower to create Asclepius. Of course, he had to plant the embryo in some woman's womb, but Asclepius was still Hyacinthus's son. Just like Theseus had been created from Poseidon, mingling his essence with that of King Aegeus and planted it in Aethra's womb. Aethra had been far smarter and more pragmatic than Princess Coronis, not that it has spared her from paying the price of Theseus' folly.

Hyacinthus is born.

Icarus is born.

Poseidon and Hades have a chat.

Tale of Hyacinthus:

Clio's attachment to King Amyclas faded when her belly swelled with his child. When her mind was finally clear, the muse cursed Aphrodite. Despite their dalliance being caused by love magic, Clio was fond of King Amyclas; he was very handsome, clever, well-learned, and dutiful. Everything a muse could appreciate. When Aphrodite's curse struck him, Clio would note his passing with sorrow. Clio returned to Olympus, having had quite enough of Sparta. She did bid goodbye to her lover and was gracious as he wept at her feet, patting his thick dark curls and murmuring some consoling nonsense she had observed Apollo utter whenever he took leave of his besotted lovers. Eventually, King Amyclas remembered that he was indeed a king and thus must maintain his dignity. They said more dignified goodbyes, with Amyclas promising to raise yet another temple to Apollo with shrines for her, her sister muses, and their mother. Clio informed him of her pregnancy and promised to keep him updated on the resulting child. That almost made the Spartan king weep again, but thankfully he restrained himself. Clio mounted her chariot and allowed the blessed swans of Apollo to carry her back to Olympus, her rightful abode.

At Olympus, she was greeted by her muse sisters and her lord. Apollo's eyes immediately went to her midsection. Of course, he was the god of healing, among many other domains.

"Congratulations," He told her with a bright smile, but his eyes were worried.

Clio smiled back, patting her slightly swollen belly.

"The child's father?" Inquired Apollo.

"The King of Sparta, Amyclas," Clio informed him.

Apollo frowned, eyes unfocused as if seeing visions of the future.

"And her curse?" He hinted at what had happened mere seasons earlier.
"I don't know. I became unusually infatuated with him, but it has faded completely today. Now, I am not any more fond of him than I am of my previous lovers."
Clio had always made it a policy to be kind and generous toward her lovers unless they wronged her. However, she preferred to leave sentiment out of it.

Apollo paused to ponder this new information.

"You might just be immune to love's agonies. My beloved twin and our chaste aunt are, after all. You have always been the most logical and rational of your sisters. Perhaps you are fortunate."

Clio had to ponder that. She fervently wished it was so.

"I have sworn no oaths of maidenhood."

Apollo had no answer for that.

"Let us not worry; it is unhealthy for your child anyway. When fate strikes King Amyclas, I will console you if needed."

Apollo eyed her belly again.

"I hope fate strays its hand until the child has been birthed and recognized by the father. A fatherless demigod will have little standing. It will be far more proper and fitting for your dignity if your child is recognized as a royal."

Clio had to admit that her lord's logic was sound. Amyclas had been quite taken with the idea of a demigod son.

" Let us go seek Artemis. You will need her soon enough." Apollo ushered her toward the shining eternal city but he was soon intercepted by Hermes, who shot a knowing smirk at Clio. Apollo shot her an apologietic glance and followed their brother.

Clio was deeply relieved that Artemis held the domain of childbirth as the divine patroness of midwives. Eileithyia was Hera's loyal daughter, and Hera had no love for any of her husband's bastards. It is better to have Artemis assisting in a birthing of any descendant of Zeus that was also not a descendant of Hera. The tales of what Eileithyia had done to Leto had caused the original goddess of childbirth to lose worshippers.Eileithyia was still honored, still important, but Artemis had eclipsed her. Clio knew that it had been the instigation of Apollo. Her lord was inventive in his wrath and wielded word and song akin to weapons. Deciding to heed his advice Clio made her way to Artemis' palace.

The maiden huntress was in the gardens, and several of her immortal companions were with her. Artemis was perched on a rock, watching her hunting dogs frolic in the grass. Her silver bow was lying on the ground by her feet. She idly inspected her quiver full of arrows. Today, Artemis favored her older form, one that could pass as almost older than Apollo's preferred guise. The goddess sensed Clio's approach, and her cold, silvery eyes aimed right at Clio's midsection. Artemis frowned, sighing with slight displeasure.
"I thought that you had better sense than to get yourself with child, even if you do not have enough sense to avoid the company of men altogether." Artemis challenged her brother's muse.

Clio arched an eyebrow.

"I never swore any vows of maidenhood, dear half-sister. To each their own. I find no quarrel with your choice to remain a maiden for eternity and I hope that you will grant me the same grace in respecting my own choices."

"I heard of the trouble you had with Aphrodite. How much was it your choice?"

Clio pondered this.

"Knowing how vicious she is, I would have expected her to steer me to a hideous, disgusting creature. Not the most handsome king in the Peloponnese."

Amyclas was no different from the usual man she chose to bed, even without Aphrodite's meddling. Clio liked handsome warriors; they always had the most fascinating stories to tell her. Even the ones that embellished were amusing. Amusing to punish for the hubris of rewriting history in her presence. Amyclas had done no such thing. He had enough distinguished accomplishments that he needed not to invent any. He had defeated any enemy to come his way and had expanded his kingdom, even building a new settlement, Amyclae. Apollo would say that naming a new city after himself was too much pride for a mortal, but Clio felt that Amyclas had earned it. Besides, Apollo could not complain much. Amyclae was home to an extensive sanctuary dedicated to her lord.

"Can I count on your help when my child is born?" Clio asked, eager to hear Artemis' response.

Months later, in the heart of Mount Helion, where the sacred waters of the Hippocrene spring flowed, Clio found herself in the throes of labour. The air was thick with anticipation, the usually melodious woods hushed in reverence. By Clio's side was Artemis, assisting her as promised, her presence a comforting beacon amidst the pain. Artemis was a pillar of strength with her serene face and steady hands. Childbirth was the worst trial of Clio's immortal life.

Artemis spoke, her voice echoing through the silent palace,

"Breathe, Clio. With each breath, you bring life closer."

Clio nodded, her face etched with determination. As the contractions grew stronger, Artemis never left her side. She whispered words of encouragement, her hands expertly guiding the process. The goddess' touch was surprisingly gentle, belying the strength that could bring down the mightiest of beasts.

And then, with a final push, a cry pierced the silence of the hall, Clio's son was born. Artemis, with a soft smile, placed the child in Clio's arms. The Muse looked down at her son, her heart swelling with an indescribable love.

The demigod, even as a newborn, had the radiance of a sun-kissed flower. His eyes, bright and curious, were a lovely shade of purple, much like Clio's own, inherited from her own mother, the Titaness Memnosyne.

"I will name him Hyacinthus." Clio told Artemis as the goddess guided the attending nymphs to wipe off the afterbirth from Clio's body.

"Rain blossom?" Artemis peered at the baby.

"It fits him." the Muse smiled as she stroked her baby's soft cheek.

As Clio held Hyacinthus close and fed him from her breast, the woods breathed a sigh of relief. The trees swayed gently, and the waters of the Hippocrene spring gurgled happily, and the creatures of the woods stirred. It was as if nature itself was celebrating the birth of Hyacinthus. Clio's precise and analytical mind was at work planning her son's upbringing. She would have so much to do.

Unfortunately for Clio, someone was watching her from Olympus. Hight in the clouds, Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth, daughter of Zeus and Hera, paced restlessly. Her usually calm face was marred by a frown, her heart filled with a sense of betrayal.

"Why would Clio choose Artemis over me? Eileithyia muttered to herself, her voice echoing through her private quarters.

Unable to contain her frustration, she sought out Hera, her mother and the queen of the gods. Her mother would certainly know how to resolve this issue; this insult was flung at Eileithyia by someone who was supposed to be an impartial recorder of history. Clio would know that Eileithyia was older than Artemis far more seasoned in childbirth. And yet, Clio still chose Artemis, the goddess who had usurped Eileithyia not only in her domain but also in her father's affections.
Eileithyia found Hera in her chambers; her attention focused on the mortal world below. She was likely trying to catch her kingly husband at yet another adulterous tryst. Such questions were not to be spoken to Hera. As vigilant as she was to her husband's infidelities, she was loathe to hear it discussed by others.

"Mother," she began, her voice trembling with suppressed anger.

"Why would Clio choose Artemis to assist her in childbirth? Have I not aided countless mortals and immortals alike?"

Hera turned her gaze from the mortal world to Eileithyia. She studied her daughter for a moment before speaking, her voice regal and haughty.

"Eileithyia," Hera began,

"Your anger is justified. But remember, Clio is just another of your father's bastards. It is only fitting that she would choose another bastard daughter of Zeus to assist her in birthing her own. Clio's choice does not diminish your importance to Olympus, your abilities or mastery of your domain."

"But it's a slight, Mother!" Eileithyia protested, her eyes flashing with indignation.
"It's a slight against me, against my domain! Which I held well before Father even looked at Leto!"

Hera grimaced, she was well aware that after the issue with Metis, Leto had been one of Zeus' first choices for queen. However none of Metis's cousins had agreed to wed Zeus. And yet, the titaness still besmirched Hera's marriage.

"I will take Clio and Artemis to task," Hera spoke to her daughter.

"Remember, you are still the goddess of childbirth, and you are still revered."

Eileithia frowned.
"Not as much as I was before Artemis was born."

Hera sent her daughter her way as she formulated the plan of attack. Zeus did not very favour Clio. The Muse was too devoted to her domain. Zeus, all too often, did not like how he was portrayed in Clio's records, nor did he like having to deal with the complaints of others who did not like how they were recorded. But Clio had Apollo's favour and had a very important role in Olympus. Zeus still held a fondness for her mother, Memnosyne. On the other hand, Artemis and Athena were one of Zeus's unabashed favourites.

Hera had to leave Artemis out of this if she hoped to get her daughter any justice. Clio had erred against Hera's domain by dallying with a married man and conceiving his child. King Amyclas believed himself to be clever, but his wife detected the behaviour change and discovered the tryst. Hera's altars in Sparta had been flush with offerings as Diomede prayed to preserve her marriage, her status as queen, and her sons' birthrights. Clio would need to be struck via her demigod son. Hera closed her eyes as she sensed. Already, the Muse was deeply attached to her newborn. She would let some time pass for the bond to become even deeper and strike. Clio hoped to raise her son herself. Hera would not allow that to happen. A demigod had no place in Olympus. If there were a precedent, her husband would want to bring all of his mortal bastards into her home!

Clio kept Hyacinthus in her palace to ensure that the baby was not in the vicinity of a god being careless with their true form and incinerating her son by accident. Her sisters and her mother were delighted with her baby and would often visit, amusing the baby and hearing his gleeful laughter and cheerful gurgling. Memnosyne spoke seriously to the baby, lecturing him on many things. Clio had tried to explain several times that Hyacinthus was too young to understand anything, but her mother would not be moved. Artemis had dropped by; while she was adverse to adult males, she was fond of all small children. Apollo had been unable to visit; their shared Uncle Poseidon had invited him under the sea, in the very heart of his kingdom. Apparently, a new sea god, one Glaucus, had developed prophetic abilities and needed instruction. Clio thought this bliss would continue.

Zeus had summoned her in his presence. He was unhappy that a mortal was living in Olympus. It was only supposed to house gods. Clio had pointed out that Olympus was home to many nature spirits as well but Zeus had just gotten angrier and ordered her to give up her infant to his mortal father. Fortunately, her aunt Demeter had overheard their argument and had burst in, defending Clio.

"Once more, you want to separate a mother from her child!"

Demeter had declared, causing such a scene that the rest of the Olympians had to be called in to decide. There was a lot of arguing back and forth. Clio's head spun as her heart sank. Demeter planted herself by her side, viciously defending a mother's right to her child. Poseidon also supported Demeter. Clio figured out that Zeus must have offended him recently. Apollo was the one who resolved the issue. While Hyacinthus would need to be given up to Amyclas, he obtained the right for Clio to visit her son as often as she would like. Zeus was unhappy at this lenience.

"You may visit your son, Clio, but the moment that these visits interfere with your duties, I will rescind the privilege, and you will not be allowed to see him"

Clio hid her devastation, thanking Demeter, Poseidon, and Apollo and hurrying to her palace. She would need to be very, very careful from now on to prevent herself from losing the right to see her son.

Amyclas was overjoyed with the baby, admiring how beautiful, bright, strong and alert Hyacinthus was. His mother, Queen Dowager Sparta, was just as delighted but less effusive. She cast a critical eye on the demigod. She had been wife to a demigod and knew firsthand how exceptional they could be. Sparta loved her other grandsons, but the kingdom was her priority. Only the best prince could become the next king to keep Laconia strong and safe. Queen Diomede seethed with silent rage but did not dare to utter a single word. The divine wrath of an immortal goddess was not something to take lightly, even if that goddess was a mere Muse.

At Amyclas' discretion, Hyacinthus was assigned the quarters that had once belonged to his mortal grandfather, King Lacedaemon, son of Zeus. Amyclas justified that a demigod ought to be given quarters fit for a demigod. Diomede wanted to argue that Lacedaemon was the son of the mighty king of the gods, not the son of a mere muse but she bit her tongue and swallowed her venom while her mother in law's eyes were on her. Old Queen Sparta was not fooled. She was the one to chose and supervise Prince Hyacinthus' attendants. Diomede would have to say or sway in Hyacinthus' household. Which was a wise decision. Very, very often a divine glow was seen from the Old King's wing of the palace, signifying that Hyacinthus' immortal mother was visiting him. Amyclas always stared at the light descending from the sky with wistful longing but never dared to approach. His affair with the glorious Clio had ended, he had gotten a perfect son from her. To ask more was to tempt the fates and invite divine retribution upon himself and his kingdom.

 

The Tale of Icarus

King Minos stood on the rocky cliffs overlooking the azure waters surrounding his mighty kingdom, his eyes scanning the horizon. The sun dipped low, casting a warm glow on the waves. The ship carrying the famed Daedalus was due any moment now.

The salty breeze ruffled Minos' regal purple robes as he waited. Daedalus, the brilliant inventor from Athens, had been sent to Crete by King Aegeus. Minos had received a formal request from his fellow king but he had long been aware of the contents of it. As any king worth the title, Minos had eyes and ears in every kingdom of note. He had long been aware of what was going on in Athens under Aegeus' own nose.

As a demigod son of Zeus, Minos held precious knowledge that mere mortals like Aegeus' were denied. Daedalus was not just a brilliant inventor from an excellent lineage. He was the son of bright-eyed Athena, one of her curiously created mind children. Minos stay in Chiron's camp did not coincide with Daedalus, he would have liked the opportunity to establish a rapport with the greatest mind of their age. The same mind that Aegeus was carelessly throwing away.
To be fair to the Athenian King, Daedalus had been caught murdering his own nephew, but that could have been solved without casting Daedalus away. They could have claimed Daedalus to have been possessed by an eidolon. A few bags of gold to a few priests and they would have confirmed such. Or crafted a tale that Talos had attacked first and Daedalus had just been defending himself. Is not like the boy had not given Daedalus ample reason to kill him.

As the ship's silhouette emerged, Minos clenched his fists. Daedalus had not just brought himself to Crete but also a revolutionary invention, the new and improved sails. His original sails had revoluntionized seafaring and commerce and those had just been crude, ordinary canvas sails that flapped clumsily in the wind. No, these were sleek, efficient and adjusted automatically to harness every gust. Minos had conversed via Iris Message with Daedalus often since the trial in Athens. He had seen the designs and marvelled at their ingenuity.

"Daedalus!" Minos called out as the ship docked. The gangplank lowered, and the inventor stepped onto Cretan soil. His eyes sparkled with intelligence, and his hands bore the calluses of countless experiments. The calluses of swordsmanship as well, but few knew him to be a demigod.

"King Minos," Daedalus greeted, bowing low.

"I bring you the future -- the sails that will propel your ships faster, smoother and with less effort. Imagine the trade routes that you can open, the wealth than you can amass!"

Minos nodded, his mind racing. The Athenians had exiled Daedalus, blinded by their sanctimousness. They could not appreciate the genius in their midst and accept that genius could have a price. But Minos saw opportunity were others saw a blood crime.

"The Athenians are fools," Minos muttered.

"They cast out a man who could have elevated their city-state. Now, I shall profit from their ignorance."
Daedalus smiled knowingly.

"Indeed, King Minos. Let us usher in a new era of maritime supremacy. Our ships will glide like eagles, and the coffers will overflow."

And as the sun sunk beneath the waves and the stars blinked into existence, Minos whispered to the sea breeze.

"Welcome to Crete, Daedalus. May your genius light our path."

Daedalus marvelled at the Port of Knossos, which counted as a city in its own right rather than just part of the rest of Crete's royal capital, Knossos. Daedalus had always been fond of the sea, unusually among his maternal siblings. He did not dare to lower himself in the waters since the sea god was not fond of Athena's spawns but enjoyed watching the sea and being on a ship. This voyage had been a delight; he had done so much work with hardly anyone bothering him.

Minos had promised him a household, lands and cattle in exchange for his new sails. Instead of establishing himself in Knossos proper, Daedalus had in mind to establish himself in the Port of Knossos. As Minos had pointed out, it was a short horseback ride from the port to the royal palace. It was almost a shame that the Port was not its own separate city.

Queen Pasiphae was everything one could expect of a minor goddess gifted in marriage to a mortal king as a reward. She was intimidatingly beautiful and had impeccable manners. She was also interested in matching him with one of her many noblewomen. While marriage to a woman of local lineage would be greatly helpful in establishing him in Crete, Daedalus was utterly reluctant to do so. He had seen his father's marriage. A cold, tense union not unlike war.

He was devoted to his work and would have little time and interest in a young bride. Being neglected would make said bride bitter and resentful, and before long, he would become his father and his bride his stepmother. He declined Queen Pasiphae as graciously as he could. The immortal seemed to understand. Her sister, the famed immortal sorceress Circe, approved of him for the first time when he explained how unsuited he was to marriage. The sorceress finally drew him in conversation, and Daedalus was able to learn more about a most fascinating and elusive subject: magic.

Pasiphae and Circe, one wed to a man she despised against her will and the other having suffered enough indignities to put her off marriage, might respect Daedalus' choice to remain unattached, but Athena would not. Her plan relied on her getting Daedalus to wed, have a child and then use the child to punish Daedalus. She knew who she needed to bring her plan to fruition, Eros, god of love.

Athena approached Zeus, who welcomed his beloved daughter with a smile.

"Athena, my dear child," He spoke to her.
"What brings you here?"

"It's my demigod son, Daedalus, the brillian craftsman. He has grown lonely, cast from his city, into a foreign land, consumed by his inventions. I believe he needs love, companionship. I wish for him to find a partner, to marry.

Zeus leaned back from her with a laugh.

"Love and marriage? Love fades away like the mist in sunlight and marriage all to often turns sour."

Athena thought of a different approach.

"Your son, King Minos delights in having Daedalus in his court, but the inventor has to blood tie to Crete. He needs to marry and have children of Cretan blood to fully tie him to Minos' kingdom."

Zeus looked thoughtful, his Cretan son had done him great honors and built several temples in his honor. It brought renown to Zeus to have kingly sons.

"Father, Eros owes you a debt. Remember Psyche? The mortal girl who captured his heart? You granted her immortality, made her a goddess, and Eros, in turn, owes you favours."

Zeus glanced at Aphrodite's palace in the distance and then at the palace of the sun, which housed Apollo. The two Olympians that had bitterly opposed Psyche's immortality. Aphrodite out of jealously for the girl's beauty. Apollo because he despised Eros and wished to watch him suffer. Something about a son of Clio, Athena could not be bothered to remember.

"Psyche? Ah, yes. A tangled tale, that was. Very well Athena. What do you propose?"

Athena smiled, glad to once again have gotten her way. Her father never denied her anything. As unpleasant as it had been to be swallowed as a fetus, the guilt of eating her other and very nearly her was very useful.

"I ask that you command Eros to shoot an arrow into Daedalus' heart. Let him fall deeply in love with a Cretan woman of good status, and may that love lead to marriage. Daedalus deserves happiness, and perhaps his passion will ignite new creations. Have you seen the glorious statues of you that adorn your temples in Knossos? They were the creation of Daedalus."

"You are persistent, my daughter. Very well. Eros shall heed your request. But remember, mortal affairs are unpredictable. Love can be both a blessing and a curse."

Athena relied on love becoming a curse to Daedalus, but she smiled and nodded, accepting her father's warning.

"Thank you, Father. Daedalus will be grateful, and perhaps his love will inspire wonders beyond even our imagination."

Zeus gestured for an attendant to approach and ordered him to fetch Eros and bring him to Zeus.

Eros has been with his beloved Psyche and their daughter Hedone when he received the summons to Zeus. His flawless face darkened with irritation. Since his wife's apotheosis his grandfather constantly summoned him. Everytime a pretty mortal caught his eye. As grateful as he was to have his family immortal and thus safe from his many enemies, the summons were starting to grate. Eros was used to not being accountable to anyone other than his mother, who rarely made him do something he didn't want to. Unfortunately, mother felt threatened by Psyche's beauty, forcing Eros to turn to Zeus.

As it was, the one with the demand of him was not Zeus, but his favored daughter, the goddess of wisdom. Athena apparently wished for her son Daedalus to fall in love, wed and reproduce. Eros was very suspicious. Hermes had visited him and Psyche to inform of how Athena and her brilliant son had a severe falling out. Now she wished to reward the son that humiliated her by committing a blood crime and got himself exiled from her patron city? Eros smelled a rat, he had a feeling that he was being set up for something. Zeus murmured about it needing to be a Cretan woman so Daedalus' genius could be bound to Minos' kingdom.

That informed him what this was about. The most worshipped gods in Crete had since the dawn of the mortals been Poseidon and Demeter. Minos was changing that by promoting the worship of Zeus. Daedalus had built several glorious temples, the likes of it had not been seen. Athena planned to deliver a blow to Poseidon and use Eros for it.

Eros smirked, know he knew how to counter her. He would agree to the request yes. But the woman he would chose for Daedalus it would not be one Athena would like. Poseidon had many nymph daughters living in Crete. Eros knew of one in particular, a rather young one by the name of Naucrate. The naiad was just as disinterested in matters of the heart and flesh as Daedalus was. She very much wished to join the retinue of Artemis. Yet another that sought to defy him and his mother. Eros accepted to help Athena. One his way back to his family he told to every god that he met that Athena planned to make her son Daedalus wed. This way when tragedy struck, Poseidon would know were to place the blame. Right at Athena's feet.
Placing Daedalus and Naucrate in each other's path was a child's play for Eros. Striking them with his arrows was even easier. They were both enchanted with each other. Daedalus took Naucrate to Pasiphae and introduced her as his wife-to-be. Helios's sorcerous daughter was immediately suspicious. Daedalus waxed so poetic that he was struck by love instantly. That told Pasiphae all that she needed to know. Eros showed himself to her and made a silencing gesture to her. The minor, unimportant goddess blanched before giving him a curt nod. She would keep her mouth shut. She would not dare to make an enemy of him.

Pasiphae busied herself organizing the nuptials and teaching the naiad now to run a household fit for a man of means and standing. Eros ensured that Athena was otherwise preoccupied. Quite a few of her priestesses broke their vows, and she was busy running around and punishing them. Nothing as dramatic as Medusa, unfortunately. That particular monster had been most amusing. Eros vaguely recalled a demigod sister of his. One Smilax had goaded quite a few of her enemies into going after Medusa and never returning. His mother had been proud of her and the strength of her Charmspeak. Smilax had been the lover of Crocus of Lacedaemonia, the closest friend of the Spartan Prince Hyacinthus.

Daedalus had been wed and had a newborn son in the crib by the time Athena was done punishing her erring priestesses. To Eros surprise she showed up in front of him, furious.

"You wed my son to a seaspawn!"

Eros smirked while notching his arrow, taking aim and striking a random satyr.

"My dearest aunt. You told me to make your son fall in love. I chose the most beautiful of the available women in Crete. She is a naiad. Daughter of a river."

Athena stamped her foot.

"She is a daughter of Poseidon! Not some minor river god!"
Eros observed as the satyr caught sight of a lovely nymph. He notched another arrow. This one made of lead. When the satyr staggered over to the pretty nymph he let loose the arrow. The nymph shrunk back, screeching in horror at the satyr and bolting as quick as the wind. The satyr quickly followed in pursuit. Eros chuckled.

"Never fails to be amusing."

Athena seized him by the shoulder and spun him around to face her. Eros snarled.

"You will undo your magic! I will not have a son of mine enamoured by such a creature!"

She flashed away, taking him with her. Eros was unsurprised to find himself in Daedalus house. The demigod was sweetly feeding his wife a few ripe red strawberries. Athena made a noise of disgust.

"Fix it or I will go to my father. You are supposed to obey him in exchange of Psyche's immortality!"

Eros clenched his teeth, gathering some blood red energy in his palm and hurling them both at the happy couple. He saw the change the moment they were hit. They both froze. Daedalus with a strawberry staining his fingers, Naucrate with her head titled up and her mouth opened like a little bird. The both sprang away from each other. One stared at the other with utter, uncomprehending horror. Naucrate was the first to break. She sprang away from Daedalus and let out a howl of pure anguish, her hands going to her breasts, once virginal, now leaking with milk. As if on cue the infant in the crib let out a wail. Naucrate flinched, inching away from the sound. Daedalus quickly hurried over and picked up the baby, gently and tenderly cradling him against his chest.

Percy found it strange but she owed Galaxaura. Three years ago, she rescued him and has since taken him under her protection and patronage. Under her stern tutelage, Icarus feels that he has made significant progress.

"Remember, Icarus," Artemis instructs, uttering no sound but speaking directly into his mind as it was customary for when they were hunting.

"Patience is key. Wait for the right moment to strike."

Patience did not come naturally to him, but Artemis had managed to instill a measure of it in Icarus.

Icarus nods at the goddess, readying his bow and notching an arrow. His eyes focused on the small pack of savage wolves terrorizing local herds. He loosens the first arrow with a swift movement, striking the most enormous wolf. Quickly, he loses three more arrows. The remaining wolves head towards him, and he readies his long hunting knives. With quick jumps and swift movements, he manages to take down the remaining wolves, ensuring the safety of the people's livelihood. The very same herders that had been fervently praying to Artemis.

He looks at the wolves' corpses. They are almost twice as large as ordinary wolves and drawn to people rather than preferring to run away like most wolves would. They are possibly enhanced by magic or with something unusual in their ancestry. He does not ask her. Artemis is disgusted by mentions of couplings and is not fond of magic users either. Sorcerers tend to invoke the moon in their workings despite Artemis having nothing to do with the domain of magic.

Artemis, observing his success, gives him a rare nod of approval.

"Well done, Icarus."

She praises, healing his minor injuries with a touch of her hand."But remember to be more careful. You are not invincible."

Icarus busies himself with expertly skinning the wolves under Artemis' critical eye. Wolf pelts are highly prized as trophies of one's prowess as a hunter and for their warmth in the winter.

As the day draws to a close, the sun slowly sinking on the horizon, Icarus confesses his worries to Artemis.

"Lady Artemis,"

He begins, switching to a more formal address. The goddess raises her eyebrows.

"I am worried about Ariadne, my father, Queen Pasiphae and Crete. King Minos beseeched Lord Poseidon for approval, and Lord Poseidon sent a magnificent white bull. "When kings and queens anger gods, their children, their daughters, are punished. I don't want Ariadne to be the next Andromeda."

"Perseus rescued Andromeda." Artemis reminds him.

Icarus sighs.

"He was one of the very rare demigods that got to be happy, and so did his wife. Ariadne is too young to be a bride, and she is more likely to end up like Megara than Andromeda."

Artemis, listening to his worries, advises him.

"Icarus, you must do what you feel is right. Always honour the gods who have helped you. They will guide you in your path."With these words, she vanishes in a flash of light, leaving Icarus alone in the forest. Left with the skins of the fallen wolves, he bundles them up and carries them to the nearest shrine of Artemis. He dedicates the pelts on Artemis' altar as a token of his respect. Despite the goddess's counsel, he can't shake off his worries about Minos and the potential consequences of his actions.

In the lush pastures of Knossos, Icarus approaches the majestic bull sent by Poseidon. The beast stands tall and proud, its eyes reflecting the divine power of the sea god. Icarus, filled with reverence, asks.

"When will this magnificent creature be taken to Poseidon's temple for the sacrifice?"

King Minos, Prince Androgeus, and their attendants burst into laughter as if Icarus had said some funny jest. Minos, with a dismissive wave of his bejewelled hand, says.

"We have another bull for that; Poseidon won't notice."

Icarus, taken aback, privately thinks that Minos has lost his mind. Poseidon is a god and not a god safe to anger. Cities had been hit with devastating floods and shattering earthquakes for much less.

Once everyone has left, he attempts to lead the bull to Poseidon's temple himself. Hopefully, if the bull gets there, Poseidon will be appeased and not unleash his divine wrath on Crete.

However, Prince Androgeus, suspecting Icarus might try something, has been watching from a distance with some friends. They burst from the bushes just as Icarus got the bull to follow by tempting the beast with some berries. The prince and his friends overpower Icarus, who does not dare to hit the king's favourite son and drag him to Minos.

Minos, furious with this defiance of his authority as king but wary of making an enemy of Daedalus, Icarus' loving father, orders the boy to join the women in the gynaeceum and learn how to weave.

"You will go there daily for a month," Minos commands.

"And at the end of it, you must present me with a cloth you have woven, and it better fit a king!"

The task assigned as punishment by Minos was considered women's work and thus humiliating to men. Icarus, as a diligent student of the goddess Artemis and best friend of Princess Ariadne, does not care. The people he respects the most are women, and he does not find their work humiliating. Everyone needs to wear clothes after all.

Unfortunately, someone else cares. Poseidon, Icarus' maternal grandfather. Father of Icarus' late mother, the naiad Naucrate. As Icarus leaves the pasture, the bull lets out a low, mournful bellow, as if sensing the impending wrath of Poseidon. The echo of the sound lingers in the air, a chilling reminder of the consequences of dishonouring the gods.

The next day, Icarus goes to the gynaeceum to receive instructions on weaving. Ariadne is the one who takes charge of him, firmly guiding him to a loom.

"What were you thinking, defying my father!" She hisses at him, worry and fear making her large brown eyes glassy.

"You are lucky that he needs your father."

Icarus nods at her words, his eyes landing on Queen Pasiphae, standing by her loom but not weaving. Her eyes seem glazed with a hint of pink, her cheeks flushed, and a strange smile playing around her lips. He narrows his eyes and can almost smell rose perfume, a scent that the queen is not fond of, preferring lotuses and irises.

"Do you smell roses?" He asks Ariadne.

His best friend pauses in her work and tentatively sniffs the air.

"There is a hint of it? I hope Mother does not get angry!"

"It seems to be coming from your mother!" Icarus tells her.

"She hates roses. Something weird is happening."

Ariadne wrinkles her nose.

"Don't try to distract me. You need to understand that you can't do something like this anymore! The king does not like defiance, and he never forgets or forgives a slight."

Icarus sighed and nodded, understanding the gravity of his actions. Still, he had to try to give Poseidon his due for the sake of everyone he loved and everyone living in Crete. Ariadne lectures him on proper weaving techniques, but Icarus's attention is drawn to Queen Pasiphae.

She keeps acting strange, her movements more deliberate, and her gaze is distant. And then there's the scent - roses. Icarus wrinkles his nose. He knows fully well that the queen and her sister Circe despise the perfume of roses, reminding them of losing their father, Helios.

"Why roses?" He wonder aloud, a terrible sense of foreboding sinking under his skin, giving him the same levels of anxiety he only felt in the cave that Artemis rescued him from.

Ariadne shrugs, her eyes filled with concern not just for Icarus but also for her mother. The gynaeceum, usually a place of laughter and chatter, is unusually quiet. The air is heavy with the scent of roses growing thicker and the unspoken tension of the palace.

Icarus, despite his predicament, can't help but feel a pang of sympathy for the queen. He resolves to do his best in the gynaeceum, not just for his sake but for everyone in the palace affected by Minos' pride and Poseidon's wrath.

Ariadne, noticing his distraction, asks him about his studies with his father. Recently, Daedalus had started teaching Icarus mathematics, sciences, poetry, and philosophy. Icarus did his best to be a diligent student and make his father proud, but had little interest in the subjects. Some sciences were fun, especially the ones involved in making things. He loved making pottery and sketching scenes with his father, but mathematics bored him utterly.

"I'd rather hunt, swim and do gymnastics. But I do love pottery and sketching. Mathematics, though, bores me."

Ariadne scolds him.

"You should appreciate such an opportunity. I would do anything to be allowed to study mathematics and science."

Her voice is tinged with longing and a hint of frustration.

"Unfortunately, no scholar is willing to teach a girl."

Icarus looks at her, surprised.

"That's not fair," He says, his voice firm.

"I'll try to convince my father to teach you."

Ariadne thanks him, but her smile is sad.

"I appreciate it, Icarus, but I don't expect anything."

As Icarus leaves the gynaeceum that day, he can't help but think about the unfairness of it all. Why should girls be denied an education or training? And forced to stay indoors all day doing a task as repetitive and mindnumbing as weaving? It's a question that lingers in his mind, a reminder of the injustices even within the palace walls. And it's a question that he's determined to find an answer to, for Ariadne's sake.

He rushes home, where his father waits for his lessons. Icarus approaches Daedalus with a request.

"Father, I want Ariadne to join our lessons," He says, his voice as steady as he can keep it.

Daedalus looks at him, astonished.

"Why would I waste my time teaching a girl? She will only marry and produce children. Her entire life she will spend in the women's quarters, running the household and raising her children."

Icarus grits his teeth in frustration.

"Ariadne deservest to be educated. She is one of the smartest people that I know! It's unfair that she's denied the opportunity just because she's a girl."

Daedalus scoffs, "Education is for men, Icarus."

Thanks to the mishap with the bull, Icarus had the perfect retort.

"And yet, Minos is making me, a boy, learn how to weave. Isn't that supposed to be women's work?"

Daedalus' fists clench in anger, and his face twists into a fearsome scowl, gray eyes blazing with cold rage.

"Fine," his father grumbles,

"Ariadne can join the next lesson. But she had better study quickly, or she will be expelled."

Icarus nods, satisfied. He knows it won't be easy, but he is determined to help Ariadne get the education she craves. He knows that Artemis will approve.
