Percy sat down by the door, hugging her knees. Her mom and Galaxaura were talking in the other room, and she did not know that the door was slightly open, and she could hear them.

"A catholic school? How did this even happen?" Galaxaura wanted to know.

Sally Jackson sighed.

"I was baptized as a child after my parents died. I attended Catholic school for a few years, the same one until the clear sight got too much. My uncle relented and put me in a regular school. It seems that the administration assumes that Percy was baptized."

"She hasn't? Correct?" There seemed to be fear in Galaxaura's voice.

"Of course not!" Her mom spoke.

"Oh, thank Thalassa and Pontus. I can't imagine how furious Poseidon would have been. His sacred pine tree gets devastated during Christmas, and he loathes the concept."

Sally snorted.

"I know; I use a fake tree for a reason. I would prefer to go without, but Gabriel would get suspicious, and Percy has enough trouble without being the kid whose family does not even celebrate Christmas."

Percy was starting to suspect that her mother and her agent were followers of the Hellenistic religion. She had seen posts about it on social media. Models and influencers praying to Aphrodite for beauty and grace. During flu season, people prayed to Apollo and Asclepius. It was a niche movement but present. Galaxaura had mentioned it several times and was always excited when she saw such a post. Percy now knew the reason why. Well, she would go to the catholic schools since she had no choice, but she would avoid taking communion or praying in the attached church.

Percy was already less than enthusiastic about Catholic school, but the reality was even worse than she expected. The nuns realized that her mother had her before marriage and would not stop lecturing Percy about the evil of such sin. She shot back that if God was truly offended by her existence, then surely Percy would not have existed. That shut them up for a few moments before they started lecturing her on being disrespectful.

The other students took cues from the nasty nuns and either ignored Percy utterly or tried to make fun of her. Percy couldn't care less if they insulted her alone, but it was another matter when the foul little brats thought that they could insult her mom.

One of them, Patricia, called Percy's mom a slut. Percy dragged her to a secluded area, beat the girl bloody, and threatened to skin her alive and dunk her in saltwater if she ever repeated the same. Percy snatched Patricia's phone and took down her address so she could get revenge if the other girl opened her mouth. Percy needed to last at least one year in this cursed school before she got expelled.

Patricia told the administration that she had just fallen down the stairs. It was clear that no one believed her, but she kept insisting in an increasingly desperate voice. The whole time Percy was there, Patricia didn't dare even look at her. There was a part of Percy that she buried deep in her soul for the sake of her mom that took joy in Patricia's fear of her.

The following months were lonely, but at least the nuns had stopped criticizing her mom. The problem was the priest. He kept trying to give her communion after his boring sermons, but Percy claimed to be allergic to grapes and could not take it. The priest was instantly suspicious because it was not in Percy's file. She told him it was a mild reaction but did not want to suffer the discomfort. The kind, loving and benevolent god Father Lucas described daily in his very long sermons would not want a little girl to suffer. Percy was called impertinent and assigned detention.It was not the end of it. Father Lucas started talking to the nuns. They were constantly whispering with each other while looking and pointing at Percy. She wished that they would stop doing that. Not only was it rude, but it was making the other students even more obnoxious. Percy needed to last one year in this hellhole. December had barely started.

The day before they left for the Christmas holidays, Sister Margaret came to collect her. Percy's heart sank. Were they expelling her? She noticed that the nun looked rather pale and her hands were shaking. She threw puzzling looks at Percy and always seemed on the verge of saying something.

To her surprise, Sister Margaret did not take her to the offices but to the church instead. There Father Lucas and two more nuns were waiting. Father Lucas was holding his little bowl of grape juice soaked wafers.

"Percy, you must take the communion. It's part of our faith," Sister Margaret implored her.

Percy shrank away. In addition to her mom's and Galaxaura's worries. Being inside a church felt instinctively wrong for her. Her skin itched with anxiety and she always felt nauseous. She was sure that if she tried to eat those wafers she would vomit.

"It have told you many times! I can't take that. I am allergic to grapes. And at this point I don't want too!"

Father Lucas scowled and interjected.

"Percy, if you refuse the communion, it's a sign of the devil's influence. We must cleanse you."

The other two nuns seized her and dragged her to a chair where they secured her with ropes.

"Have you gone crazy! There is no such thing as the devil! This is illegal!"Sister Margaret wrung her hands, a look of discomfort on her face but she stayed silent and still.

"The devil exists and his greatest victory is making others believe that he does not." Pompously spoke Father Lucas.

"You are going to end up in jail just like the rest of the crazy priests!" Percy hissed, thrashing in the chair and trying to get free.

None of them answered, the priest started chanting while holding a crucifix and nuns doused him with holy water. It was December, no snow had fallen yet but it was bitterly cold. Most of her classmates huddled near the heaters and aways wore gloves and scarves. Percy was not bothered. The cold had never bothered her much. Galaxaura had noticed and murmured something about the icy temperatures at the bottom of the sea.

As terrifying and confusing as this situation was, Percy was not worried about the water. It had a strange texture, both slimy and gritty like all tap water but it did not hurt her. She would have vastly preferred that it was salt water with its delightful minerals. Some freshwater came close but none could be as pleasant on the skin and nose as seawater.

"It's freezing, Father. Shouldn't we stop? She will get hypothermia!" Sister Margaret asked, concerned. She looked at Percy with fear, biting her lips.

"No, the devil is resilient. We must try fire," Father Lucas decided.

He grabbed a stick, resembling a cheerleaders batton, except that when he turned a stitch, the end if erupted in fire. Father Lucas smiled and approached Percy with the flaming torch. She shrank back in the chair and felt a tug in her gut.

Suddenly, the water exploded, and the ground shook violently. The priest and the two nuns were thrown away from Percy. The church crumbled around them.

Percy's struggles against the ropes bore fruit, she managed to free herself and ran out, leaving the priest and the nuns trapped inside. She shouted for Sister Margaret to run but had no consideration to spare for the other two nuns and that vile priest.

She run to the offices to tell the administration what the priest had done. The headmaster listened to her with a strange look on his face as Percy explained. He told her to go back to her dormitory and that he would sort this out.

Percy went to bed with hopeful thoughts but the next morning she was disappointed. The school expelled her without explanation. She was left with more questions than answers about what had happened. Percy wondered if she should ask her mother.

When Sally arrived, she looked so beside herself with fear that Percy decided against asking questions. They just packed Percy's things and headed out. By the gates there was a car waiting. Percy expected Galaxaura, but she did not expect her boyfriend there as well. She could never quite catch his name, Ant something, most likely Anthony but everytime she tried to clarify something stoped her. She looked at him, he had unruly black hair like her and almost the same green eyes. Percy's eyes rolled back and she slumped in the car seat.

Sally gasped and clutched her daughter.

"Don't worry, I just put her to sleep." Anteros spoke.

"You told me that she was yours but she was descended from my father." Anteros accused Galaxaura.

The Oceanid shrugged.

"I did not lie. Her father entrusted her to me. I am officially her guardian so the child is mine in the legal sense. And she definitely is descended from your father."

Anteros scowled.

"I was imagining at least a great granddaughter! Not his actual demigod daughter, my sister!"

Galaxaura patted his arm.

"The less people know the better it will be. You are on Olympus almost all the time."

"This is going to be such a mess. The destruction of that church was noticed. It ended on Olympus Weekly."

Sally gasped.

"Are they going to find her?" She grabbed her daughter's hand.

Anteros shook his head.

"No, because I was nearby everyone thinks that I did it. I have not denied it."

"So Percy is safe?"

"For now."

He looked at Sally seriously.

"You need to avoid her getting in highly emotional or dangerous situations. If she discovers her powers she will realize what she is an the monsters will be even more drawn to her. The rest of them might notice too. My uncle is angry about what happened to his daughter. He will not take it well that my father's daughter is alive and has been living in safety."

Sally glanced at her daughter, blue eyes shiny with fear. Galaxaura noticed ad sighed.

"Lets just take it one day at the time."

"My father might retaliate against this place." Anteros warned.

"Can you talk him out? It will only draw more attention here."

"I will try, but I make no promises."

Percy woke up. Galaxaura was on her phone, arguing with someone. Her boyfriend was driving the car while singing along. Percy looked at the screen, it was a spotify list of love songs. She rolled her eyes, adults were all the same. Love this and that. She turned to her mom. Percy wanted to say that she was sorry that she did not last the year in the school. Her mom stopped her from saying anything by hugging her.

"Percy, I am so sorry! I should have never taken you to that school."

"It's ok mom. I know how it is." Percy murmured on her mom's shoulder.

Hyacinthus returned to Sparta with Crocus and Smilax in tow. Amyclas was happy to receive his son back and had some news for him. While Hyacinthus had been away, many things had happened. Betrothals had been arranged for Argalus and Cynortas to local young women of high status. However, these weddings would not take place until Amyclas himself was wed.

People had been trying to compel King Amyclas to marry again the moment the late Queen Diomede's corpse had grown cold. But they had all been rebuffed. Amyclas had needed a long break after his first marriage. He would have stayed unmarried until his death if it had been up to him. He had four healthy sons; there was no need for a bride.

However, Amyclas received an offer he could not refuse--one from a god. Ares, the god of war, had a demigod daughter in Laconia. Her name was Aristodamia, and she was quite beautiful. Amyclas had accepted her as a bride, and she had arrived in the palace to prepare for her role as queen.

Not wanting to deal with a second Diomede, Hyacinthus was polite and kind to her when introduced. He even introduced her to his friends, Crocus and Smilax.

Aristodamia was happy enough to greet him and even Crocus. But when she caught sight of Smilax, her smile fell.

"Aren't you quite beautiful?" She told Smilax, teeth bared.

"A daughter of Aphrodite?" Being a demigod, she did not mistake Smilax for a nymph or pretend to do so, as a regular mortal would.

"I attended camp myself a few years back. I met a few of your sisters."

Smilax gave the future queen a sweet smile that immediately alerted Hyacinthus. He knew his friend. That was the smile she gave enemies when assessing them and wanting to downplay her threat level.

"I hope you had a better time at camp than we did, my lady," Smilax told Aristodamia sweetly.

The king's betrothed smiled insincerely before turning to Hyacinthus.

"Your father, the king, decided to postpone our wedding for a few weeks because he wants to hold a celebration for your thirteenth birthday first."

Hyacinthus frowned. It was not quite necessary to do that. It was the fifteenth birthday when he would finally be considered a man by Spartan law that mattered.

"I will talk to him about that. The king's wedding needs to be a priority. And the eldest and second eldest princes weddings too. This is just my thirteenth, not the fifteenth."

Aristodamia looked at him up and down and licked her lips as she focused on his face.

"Ah, yes. In two years, you will be a man." She told him in a throaty voice with a languid smile.

Hyacinthus barely repressed the urge to step away from her. He looked at his friends. Crocus had an expression of disgust on his face--the same one he had when someone commented about Hyacinthus's looks. Smilax had the same pleasant expression, but her eyes were blazing with wrathful fire.

Hyacinthus decided to take his leave of his stepmother-to-be and took his friends to the gardens that overlooked his private quarters, far away from any eavesdroppers.

"What is the matter, Smilax? What is wrong with her?"

Crocus growled, and Smilax gave a very unhappy sigh. She pursed her lips, deep in thought, before she spoke.

"She is the most lustful woman that I have met, save for my mother. I could sense it on her. She was resisting the urge to feel you up. Crocus, too, but to a lesser degree. I think you are safe from her now, but she might try something by the time you are fifteen."

Crocus made a face.

"She might try what Queen Anteia of Tiryns tried with my brother Bellerophon."

Hyacinthus sighed in unhappy resignation. Disliking the mention of that ill-fated son of Poseidon, it had not been that long since his passing.

"Welcome to the royal palace and the king's court. It's a pit of vipers. Last chance to leave and not get involved in this mess."

Smilax shook her head and gave him a rueful smile. Crocus a look of surly disbelief.

"Fat chance." Were Crocus' only words.

"I like hunting vipers," Smilax told him with a naughty smile.

Hyacinthus secured invitations for them and their families to the upcoming celebrations and escorted them home. They had discussed this at camp. Smilax's father might betroth her to the highest bidder, so they had to pretend that Hyacinthus was an option until Crocus established himself and became a more suitable suitor for Smilax.

With that, Hyacinthus had to throw himself in the wedding preparations. It would take place during Hera's sacred month, the first month of the year, to ensure maximum blessings for the marriage. He helped his father incorporate the bride's dowry with the rest of the royal family's wealth. Ares had been quite generous, maybe too generous in Hyacinthus' opinion.

He watched Aristodamia like a hawk and told his grandmother about what Smilax had said. Queen Sparta was skeptical, but she agreed to have her new daughter-in-law carefully watched.

The wedding was magnificent; no expense was spared since it was the marriage of a king. Aristodamia looked radiant as long as Amyclas was not near her. Hyacinthus caught her eyeing him, Crocus, his brothers and a few guards, but the new queen stayed composed for the most part.

True to her word, Grandmother Sparta watched Aristodamia carefully for several months. The new queen was the picture of decorum the whole time, except for a few long looks. Queen Sparta relaxed her vigilance since it took energy, time, and resources to be better used elsewhere.

Hyacinthus would have picked up the slack, but he and Crocus got busy. They were demigods trained by Chiron, meaning they had more responsibilities. They trained daily with the rest of the warriors and often were sent to kill monsters, bandits, and other nuisances in a lawful kingdom. They also had lots of competitions to participate in. Hyacinthus was well established, but Crocus had been kept locked up in the house by his resentful grandfather. He needed to prove himself to the other Spartans.

That same grandfather had fallen off a cliff and drowned in the Eurotas River. Hyacinthus convinced Amyclas to grant the properties to Crocus, which his mother would manage until her son came of age. Hyacinthus first met Crocus's mother at the funeral. She was a very beautiful woman who was deeply relieved to see her father dead. There was tension between her and Crocus, but they loved one another.

Queen Aristodamia fell pregnant, and everyone rejoiced. Months later, she gave birth to a daughter whom she insisted on naming Daphne. King Amyclas allowed it, much to everyone's discomfort. Daphne was not a lucky name to give to a little girl. Aristodamia expressed her disappointment that little Daphne was not a boy and happily passed her daughter to nursemaids and did the bare minimum as a mother.

Hyacinthus visited the baby girl a few times and brought Smilax with him. His friend eyed the baby, carefully inspecting her.

"The princess does not seem to resemble the king at all," Smilax spoke, her face pale.

Hyacinthus peered closer at little Daphne.

"She is still a baby. I take mostly after my mother, too."

Smilax turned to inspect him.

"True, but you do have small hints of your father. You have the same body type as the king and the same smile."

Hyacinthus swallowed thickly. If Smilax's concerns were correct, it would bring immense shame to Sparta.

"Nothing we can do now." He told her.

"Except watch your stepmother." Smilax was unamused, and Hyacinthus sighed.

"I asked Grandmother, but after several months of perfect behaviour, she stopped because treating the Queen of Sparta like that is improper. I can't watch her myself for the same reason and am too busy."

Smilax exalted, looking fatigued and worried.

"Let us pray that it does not end up in disaster."

Their prayers went unanswered because shortly after Daphne turned one year old, Aristodamia was caught in the act. The queen of Sparta was caught committing adultery towards her husband, the king, and thus high treason against the kingdom.

It would have been an unprecedented disaster even if it had not been for the location where it took place and the person who caught her.

Aristodamia was caught defiling the temple of Hera that her predecessor, Queen Diomede, had built. Thus, in the heart of Sparta, a scandal of divine proportions unfolded. Hera, the goddess of marriage and queen of the gods, had caught Aristodamia, the young Spartan queen and the second wife of King Amyclas, committing adultery in her sacred temple.

Hera's fury was a fierce as a tempest.

"Spartans!" she thundered, her voice echoing through the city, compelling everyone to head quickly toward her temple.

"Bear witness to this disgrace!" She pointed the young queen and handsome guard entangled with each other. Prompting gasps or outrage from all witnesses.

Hyacinthus' father, King Amyclas, was livid with his young wife. He glared at her with hatred, his hand dropping to his sword. Yet, Aristodamia stood up, defiant.

She announced to everyone that she was a mere twenty years old, wedded to a man nearly three decades her senior. As if that was not enough of an insult, Amyclas' heart did not belong to Aristodamia. But to the Muse Clio, the other of Amyclas' favoured son, Prince Hyacinthus.

Hera slapped the defiant queen down, her eyes blazing with divine rage and addressed her with utter contempt.

"Amyclas has not committed an outrage against me, Aristodamia. But you have,"
With those words, Hera summoned a divine fire that consumed Aristodamia and her handsome lover. The two screamed and thrashed for what seemed an eternity while no one present dared even to twitch.

Once the deed was done and all left was ashes, Hera turned to Amyclas.

"You will strike Aristodamia from all records. She was an affront to all good queens, wives, and women. She is not even to exist anymore."

Amyclas went on one knee before the queen of the gods and nodded in acceptance.

"My temple," The goddess continued.

"Is now polluted by her actions and must be dismantled. Purify the site and build a grander one in its place."

Amyclas, his face ashen, nodded again.

"Your terms are accepted, Lady Hera."

Hera departed with a final, piercing look, leaving the king with his thoughts.

Turning to his son, Hyacinthus, Amyclas gave his command.

"Hyacinthus, the task of dealing with the temple falls to you. Make it worthy of Hera's grace."

Hyacinthus, however, had another concern.

"What of Aristodamia's little daughter? Princess Daphne?"

Amyclas' face and response were cold.
"She is no daughter of mine nor a princess of Sparta. Just the spawn of an adulterous whore and her lover. Let her be exposed to the wild animals, as is the fate of all unwanted children."

Hyacinthus had to remind him of the reason his father married Aristodamia in the first place. Because she was the daughter of a god, and that god was fond enough of her to get her a queen's crown. While Ares could do nothing about Aristodamia's fate, since it was decreed by his own mother, he could take offense in Daphne was not dealt with carefully.

"Remember, father, Aristodamia's father is the god of war, Ares. He may take offence if his granddaughter is killed. We already have one Olympian who is unhappy with us. The Furies may also be offended if a child born in your household and under your name is killed."

Amyclas gave him an impatient look as he stomped on the ashes. People were thankfully leaving. Hyacinthus continued.

"I suggest we give the girl to a peasant family far from Sparta."

Amyclas considered his son's words. After a moment, he nodded.

"Very well, Hyacinthus. See to it."

As a dutiful prince, Hyacinthus sprang into action. He immediately went to Sparta's first stone mason and commanded them to dismantle the temple. They obeyed immediately and abandoned all other projects. They understood that appeasing the angry goddess was a priority to avoid further disaster in their kingdom.

Next, Hyacinthus visited the treasury. Building temples was expensive, and he needed to know his budget before making plans. There, he discovered that Aristodamia's generous dowry was mostly untouched. He would use most of it to rebuild the temple. Satisfied that he had enough funds, he turned his attention to his little stepsister.

While he felt pity for the little girl who had done nothing wrong, Hyacinthus understood that she could not stay in Sparta to remind everyone of the disgrace her mother had committed. It would not be safe for her. He needed to get her out of the kingdom immediately before someone got the idea of killing the child.

He asked around and found a group of merchants from Argos. He entrusted the girl to them and paid them proper compensation for their trouble.

"Find a childless family for her on your way back," he instructed them.

"And remember, she is Ares' granddaughter. Be honest about it, and don't leave her to the mercy of wild animals, or you might get gored by a boar."

The leader swallowed in fear and reassured Hyacinthus that nothing of that sort would happen. The prince gave him a grave look before handing the girl over. To his surprise, the girl had not cried. She was eerily silent and watched him with huge eyes.

Reluctantly, Hyacinthus tore his eyes from her and walked away. He had tasks, wrongs to right and his family's honour to restore. Hyacinthus idly wondered if this was what all fourteen-year-old princes had to deal with or if it was just his rotten luck.

To distract from scandal, Amyclas decided it was time to hold the long-delayed weddings of Argalus and Cynortas. Nothing held attention like a royal wedding. Soon, to Hyacinthus' relief, people stopped whispering about Aristodamia and started speculating about the upcoming marriages and the bride's looks. It amazed him how easily distracted people were, not just in the demigod sense of being aware of everything around them. A queen of Sparta was caught betraying her husband and king in Hera's temple, but all it took to shift the rumours to a different topic was a royal wedding. Hyacinthus mentioned to his friends. Crocus was quite astonished, too, but Smilax wasn't.

The first to arrive was Argalus' bride, Parthenia. Amyclas wanted to make a good impression on the new in-laws, so he ordered the royal family to greet them. They were to be at their best. Hyacinthus was busy constructing Hera's temple and asked to be excused, but Amyclas would not hear it. He reminded Hyacinthus that he was the crown prince and needed to be present. So he had to be there, carefully bathed, exfoliated, his bronzed skin oiled and glowing. Bedecked in his finest chiton and bejewelled. His hair was carefully styled.

He made quite the impression but on the wrong person. The bride's eyes lit upon him, and she let out a whoop of joy, rushing to Hyacinthus and exclaiming how delighted she was to marry him. He scrambled away from her in alarm, cursing his damned luck and hoping that Amyclas did not change the groom.

"I am not your bridegroom! I am his younger brother!" Hyacinthus desperately pointed to Argalus, who glared at him as if he had stolen his bride. Hyacinthus glared back at him, it was not his intention to enchant the bride! He looked desperately at his eldest brother and his father to do something, but both had frozen in place.

Parthenia looked at Argalus and then at Hyacinthus with an obstinate expression.

"Let's change the groom then. It does not matter which Spartan Prince I marry."

Amyclas finally found his voice, his face red with anger and humiliation. He eyed his new daughter-in-law with the same contempt he had leveled on his second queen.

"That is enough! You will wed Argalus as negotiated. Hyacinthus has not even turned fifteen, and you are older than him!"

Parthenia wailed, tears falling down her cheeks, but her blushing and humiliated father backhanded her across her face, making her flinch and fall quiet. Her tears continued to fall. Hyacinthus felt hollow with guilt. He caught Smilax's gaze, and she gave him a rueful shake. Parthenia did not miss the glance between Hyacinthus and Aphrodite's daughter because she started to glare defiantly, misunderstanding the situation.

Sparta had yet another delicious scandal to celebrate, along with the royal wedding, which went as planned. Too much cattle and other wealth had passed hands for it to be called off as Argalus wanted. The celebrations were stilted, and everyone kept looking at the bride and Hyacinthus. The prince knew that he would need to be careful from now on and steer very clear of his sister-in-law. They did not need another scandal.

Unfortunately, Harpalus did not understand the assignment. The moment the wedding was over, and the bride and groom ushered to their marital quarters, the third prince announced to the remaining royals that he would be leaving Sparta to travel the world. Amyclas did not agree and demanded to know why Harpalus wanted to leave.

"There is no place for me here. Father, I might have had a place if you had not dallied with a muse and produced him."

Harpalus glared at Hyacinthus with loathing. Amyclas was not deterred.

"You are a prince, Harpalus!" Amyclas shouted.

"You have no idea what it is like for someone to live without status and means. Every meal has been prepared, and others have washed and mended your clothes. How are you going to survive?"

Harpalus grabbed a goblet and threw it at a wall. The spilled honey wine left a yellow stain on the goblet.

"At least I will be free. No one will be comparing me to a demigod every moment of the day!"

"Why do you have so much trouble with your footwork, the trainer always tells me. Your younger brother could do this flawlessly when he was a small child. Why aren't you as beautiful as your brother? The girls I try to court tell me."

"I don't care where I go as long as there is no Hyacinthus. I know that you don't care about me or my siblings because you hated our mother!"

Amyclas did not answer his third son, and Hyacinthus felt a vice grip of guilt and regret around his throat. But he doubted they would do any good even if he could get any words out.

"Your muse is never coming back to you, Father. The gods don't love mortals. They just take their pleasure, use us and then leave us heartbroken! Just as they did with you!"

Harpalus then looked directly at Hyacinthus and gave him a vicious smile.

"As pretty as you are, as pretty as Adonis was, you will end just like him!"

Everyone flinched. That felt very much like a curse.

"Harpalus! Do not curse your brother!" Amyclas screamed, his face going pale.

"If you want to leave, then leave. But you are not a prince of Sparta anymore. If you leave the city, you are never to come back!"

That was a king's command. Harpalus nodded and left the megaroon. Hyacinthus also left, his legs taking him to the half-constructed temple of Hera. He looked at the shell of what would be a beautiful temple in a few months.

"Should I even be in charge of making a temple to the goddess of marriage and family? I destroyed a marriage by being born, another one today before it began, and I destroyed a family. Driving a son and a brother away."

The prince sighed, playful wind whipping around him, almost as if trying to console him, caressing his hair and ruffling his robes. Hyacinthus frowned. The wind felt almost intrusive. Apprehensive, he hurried inside the temple. There, the wind no longer bothered him. He busied himself inspecting several artisans building a mosaic depicting Hera and her husband, resplendent on their thrones, with their symbols of power.

Hyacinthus smiled ruefully at the image. Maybe, just maybe, marriages and families were doomed to fail. The goddess of marriage could not stop her husband from constantly betraying her. Neither could she stop her family from harming one another.

 

Tale of Icarus:

Icarus fletched an arrow as Ariadne paced outside of her mother's rooms. They could hear the queen's screams of agony. They were both worried. Pasiphae had not struggled this much with little Phaedra. King Minos had stopped by, but being told it would be long before the queen gave birth, he left to attend court affairs. Icarus felt it was rather cold of him to stay away while his wife and queen struggled to give birth, but Icarus was no royal.

"Something is wrong," Ariadne spoke.

"She should have been done by now."

Icarus put his arrow in the quiver.

"The queen is an immortal goddess and will be fine."

Ariadne sat next to him.

"But my sibling isn't. And might not be."

Icarus recalled what Artemis had told him about childbirth. It was very dangerous. The women's battlefield, she called it. It could last for days, with the mother slowly bleeding in agony with no guarantee that she and the babe would make it. Since the birth of Artemis' nephew Asclepius, it had become a habit to cut the child out after a certain amount of time so that at least one could be saved. But that practice left motherless children, who often died in infancy due to the nurses not prioritizing them and giving them enough milk. Animal milk was never enough. Regarding demigods, a drop of nectar could be added to goat's milk, sustaining them. But nectar would burn out a fully mortal child. Artemis had given Icarus a vial of nectar in case he ran into a motherless or abandoned demigod child.

Pasiphae's screams finally stopped, and Ariadne and Icarus jumped on their feet. They could hear nothing, no cries from the baby, no congratulations from the midwives and nurses. The two friends looked at one another, worry etched on their faces. Icarus started to rise slowly and helped Ariadne to her feet. They walked to the entrance of the queen's bedroom, fearful of what lay inside.

Minos had posted a guard to alert him when he needed to come and see the new child. The guard had been daydreaming, but he snapped to attention when he saw the princess and the inventor's son move. He ran to alert his king and missed the screams from the delivery room.

With bated breath, Icarus and Ariadne walked inside the dimly lit chamber. The air was thick with anticipation and fear. Suddenly, a cry echoed through the room, not the cry of a newborn child, but a guttural, monstrous roar that sent chills down their spines. Their eyes widened in horror as they beheld the creature Queen Pasiphae had birthed - a monster. It had the lower body of a human infant if human infants were covered in coarse fur. The head was that of a calf. Icarus swallowed, stepping in front of his friend.

The chamber doors swung open with a loud crack, and King Minos stormed in, ready to see the new child. His proud smile fell into a fierce scowl when his eyes fell upon the monstrous infant. His face contorted in fury as he glared at his queen with disgust and rage.

"Who is responsible for this abomination!?" he demanded, his voice echoing ominously in the chamber.

Pasiphae, exhausted yet defiant, met his gaze head-on.

"It was Poseidon's doing," She confessed.

"Angered by your arrogance, he enchanted me to mate with his white bull."

Minos recoiled, and Icarus could almost see the barest hint of regret, but the king recovered, and his fury was unabated.

"You have ruined my reputation!" he accused, pointing a trembling finger at his wife.

Pasiphae defended herself, her voice barely a whisper.

"It was not my choice, Minos. I was but a pawn in the hands of the gods."

"If I had sold the gifts of Aphrodite, given my body in secret to some man, you would have every right to condemn me as a whore. But this was no act of the will! I am suffering from some madness brought on by a god. It's not plausible! What could I have seen in a bull to assault my heart with this shameful passion? Did he look too handsome in his robe? Did a sea of fire smoulder in his eyes? Was it the red tint of his hair, his dark beard?"

Icarus knew she was right but would still be responsible for what had happened. The gods were never held accountable for their actions. He had heard the tale of Callisto. The only one who had done wrong was Zeus, but the ill-fated huntress had been punished instead. She was still a monstrous bear somewhere, and Zeus was still king of the gods.

Polyboea had been the one to tell him that tale since she was connected. Her sister Laodamia married Callisto's son Arcas and was his queen until her death. Polyboea looked sad as she told him about her sister but did not weep. Not like she did when her brother Hyacinthus came up. Whenever they were together and chanced upon a hyacinth flower, Polyboea would utter a sound of despair and clutch Icarus close, begging him not to die too. It was confusing, but all the immortals were strange.

Minos did not listen to the pleas of his queen, just like no one had listened to Callisto's pleas. Unable to bear the sight of the monstrous infant and his wife, the king stormed out of the chamber in disgust, leaving Pasiphae with her monstrous infant.

Icarus and Ariadne watched as Pasiphae, with a mother's love, attempted to breastfeed the creature. Ariadne, moved by the scene, stepped forward, but Icarus held her back. His instincts screamed danger, and he knew they must keep their distance from the Minotaur. This could not be a docile creature. Poseidon was too angry at Minos for that.

Icarus's instincts were proven right only one year after the birth of the Minotaur. Pasiphae had named him Asterion, but only she called that. To everyone else, he was the Minotaur, much to the king's rage. The creature had grown to the size of a man, and its monstrous form was a constant reminder of the divine retribution that had befallen the royal family.

One fateful day, while Icarus and Ariadne were in the palace gardens, the Minotaur broke free from its confinement. It had been a wonderful day. There was hardly a cloud in the sky, and the sunshine was perfect. They had been discussing Prince Androgeus' upcoming travel to Athens to participate in the games and make a name for himself and Crete. As the heir, he had to. What had befallen them had caused Minos and his family to become a laughingstock.

Ariadne's older sisters, the princesses Acacallis and Xenodice, were of age to marry. Still, no one wanted to do so despite their beauty as daughters of their mother and wealth as daughters of their father. No one wanted to have the risk of being cuckolded by an animal. Princess Xenodice did not seem to care and wanted to become a priestess and fade into obscurity, but vain Acacallis did. She had several screaming matches with her mother and had not spoken to the queen for nearly a year.

The beast rampaged across the palace grounds, its roars echoing. Servants and guards fell before it, their screams of terror abruptly silenced as the Minotaur feasted on their flesh. Icarus and Ariadne watched in horror, frozen in place, as the beast turned its gaze towards them. Ariadne let out a small scream of terror, drawing its attention further.

Icarus' instincts and hunter training kicked in in the face of imminent danger. He grabbed Ariadne's red himation and waved it in front of the beast, using it as a distraction. The Minotaur, drawn to the vibrant colour, so similar to freshly spilled blood, charged towards the boy, its eyes focused on the himation.

With a swift movement, Icarus moved the red cloth out of the beast's path, causing it to stumble and fall into one of the deep ponds that dotted the queen's garden and was home to her beloved lotuses. The water splashed around the beast, its roars of frustration muffled by the water.

Without wasting a moment, Icarus scooped Ariadne into his arms and ran as fast as he could towards his father's house, leaving the floundering beast behind. His heart thundered in his chest, the terror fueling his escape. As they reached the safety of Daedalus' home, they dared to breathe, their relief palpable. They stayed there, barricading themselves until Daedalus himself came home. The first thing Daedalus did after ensuring that his son was unharmed was pour himself wine and drink it without cutting it with water first. Icarus gasped.

"Father! You must add water to that or risk Dionysus's madness falling upon you!"

Daedalus obliged with his next cup.

"The king feels inspired by the beast's rampage. He ordered me to build a labyrinth to keep it contained."

Icarus frowned.

"Is he not going to kill it?"

Daedalus shook his head.

"No, he will not. I don't think anyone can. Several guards and warriors tried but they failed. The queen managed to pacify it with her magic and he is being kept trapped in a room near her. It will not last, I will need to be quick about building the labyrinth. The queen has agreed to help me so we can add magic to it and make it safer."

"Why doesn't the king want to kill it? He is a son of Zeus and you one of Athena. If you worked together surely you could kill a beast barely one year old? I can ask a few of the huntresses to assist you?" Icarus asked.

Daedalus glanced at Ariadne before speaking in a softer tone.

"The king has decided to use the monster as a weapon of terror. He will feed all his enemies to the Minotaur. He already threw several of the nobles that spread the rumours about the bull and the queen to the beast."

Icarus and Ariadne looked at each other, this did not bode well. Daedalus left after hugging his son and taking a quick meal. He told Icarus to avoid the palace and go in the woods to keep company with Artemis and the huntresses. Icarus wanted to object but Daedalus pleaded him to please keep himself safe for the sake of his dead mother.

"Ariadne? Do you want to come with me? Lady Artemis always likes to hear me speak about you."
Modern times

Percy Jackson trudged up the steps of Yancy Academy, her backpack heavy with textbooks and a sense of impending doom. It was yet another school where she didn't quite fit in. Her dyslexia and ADHD had always made her an outsider, and she had a knack for attracting trouble. But she was determined to keep his head down and survive this time. Her mom did not need to have another fight with the school board and struggle to find her another school.

On her first day, Percy was in the cafeteria, scanning the room for a friendly face. That's when she saw Grover Underwood. Grover sat alone at a corner table, his crutches leaning against the wall. His legs were twisted, and he moved with a slow, deliberate grace. Percy hesitated for a moment, then decided to join him.

"Hey," Percy said, sliding into the seat across from Grover. "Mind if I sit here?"

Grover looked up, surprise flickering across his face. "Sure. No one ever wants to sit with the cripple."

Percy winced at the bluntness but appreciated Grover's honesty. "I'm Percy," she said. "New kid."

"Grover," Grover replied, extending a hand. "Nice to meet you."

They talked about inconsequential things--favourite movies, hobbies, and the weird smell in the cafeteria. Percy found himself laughing, forgetting for a moment that she was in a strange place. Grover's cheerfulness was contagious.

But then Nancy Bobofit walked in. She was a redhead with a perpetual sneer, the girl who made everyone else feel small. Percy had seen her type before--the rich bully who ruled the school with an iron fist. She would have been a queen bee if only she had been pretty. Nancy was, quite frankly, hideous.

Nancy's eyes landed on Grover, and she wrinkled her nose. "What's wrong with your legs, freak?"

Percy's blood boiled. She'd been bullied enough to recognize cruelty when she heard it. How often had she been taunted about not having a father? Every time Father's Day came by, at least one classmate would weaponize the cursed day against her. She had stopped keeping count of how often she had been called stupid and dumb due to her dyslexia. Even the teachers were not above it. But before she could say anything, Nancy turned her attention to her.

"Hey," she purred, batting her eyelashes. "You're Percy Marina Jackson, right? The model?"

Percy clenched her fists. She'd done modelling gigs to help pay the bills since she was five years old, but she hated being recognized for them, especially by vicious bullies like Nancy.

"Yeah, that's me."

Nancy leaned in, her voice dripping with faux sweetness. "We should hang out sometime. I know all the cool people."

Percy glanced at Grover, who was staring down at his tray, his cheeks flushed. Nancy's hypocrisy was nauseating. "Thanks, but no," Percy said. "I've got better things to do."

Nancy's eyes narrowed. "You'll regret this," she hissed. "I'll make your life hell."

Percy shrugged. It wasn't her first rodeo. Hostile schools were her specialty. But she had a feeling Grover needed a friend more than he needed another enemy.

As days turned into weeks, Percy and Grover became inseparable. They explored the campus together, shared secrets, and laughed until their sides hurt. Then Grover introduced Percy to Mythomagic, a card battle game that brought Greek mythology to life.

The cards depicted gods, monsters, and heroes. Percy loved it--the thrill of strategy, the rush of power. But there was something deeper. The characters resonated with him--their struggles, their victories. She chalked it up to her mother, who had read him Greek myths as bedtime stories. She'd taken him to museums, pointing out statues of Perseus, the hero who faced impossible odds and emerged victorious.

One day, as they played Mythomagic, Percy held the card of Perseus--the same hero she was named after. She stared at the image--the winged sandals, the sword, the severed head of Medusa. Her mother's words echoed in his mind: "Perseus survived, Percy. Against all odds, he stumbled to a happy ending."

Yet, strangely, it wasn't Perseus's card that gripped Percy's heart. It was the Spartan Prince Hyacinthus--the youth who died tragically, either by a frisbee accident or jealousy-fueled murder. And Icarus--the skydiving fatality, the boy who flew too close to the sun, forever etched in memory.

Her mother had shielded her from their stories, fearing their tragic ends. But Percy wondered why their images haunted her. Why did she feel a strange kinship with these forgotten heroes?

Perhaps it was their defiance--their refusal to be mere footnotes in someone else's tale. Maybe, just maybe, they held secrets that transcended myth and spoke to the hidden corners of Percy's soul. Grover always tried to pull those cards away from her, but she did not allow him. She kept them in her bag, and often, she would stare at them.

She had to admit, the artwork was gorgeous, much more than the other cards. Both Hyacinthus and Icarus were drawn beautiful enough to put celebrities to shame. They strangely looked alike. Same hair, same face structure. What set them apart were the eyes. Purple eyes are for Hyacinthus, like the flowers named after him, and amber eyes are for Icarus. Reminiscent of the sun that had caused his death. The artwork was different from the other cards, save for two: the cards of the Olympian god Apollo and his son Asclepius. Percy took those two cards to keep in her bag, too. Grover always gave her a glance of fear and pity whenever he saw her looking at the four cards.

About a month after they became friends, a new teacher arrived, Mr. Brunner. He was a middle-aged man in a wheelchair who smelled of coffee and had eyes that looked too old for him; he smiled easily and knew the meaning of the word dyslexia. Percy liked him instantly, appreciating how easy his class was and how engaging his teaching.

Percy sat in the back row of Mr. Brunner's mythology class at Yancy Academy. It was her lifelong habit to stay in the back. The less attention on her the better. The teacher would not constantly call on her and then make fun of her when she failed to do what the teacher wanted.

The room smelled of old books and ancient secrets. Mr. Brunner, the wheelchair-bound teacher, had a way of making the myths come alive, as if they were more than stories.

Today, Mr. Brunner focused on two tales: Hyacinthus and Icarus. Percy listened, half-distracted by the sunlight filtering through the dusty windows. The bronze discus and the ancient amphora depicting Hyacinthus in a swan-drawn chariot feeling from a winged being caught his eye. The swan-drawn chariot, the fleeing figure--it all felt too real. Percy could feel herself sweat with anxiety, ready to spring into a run if needed.

"Zephyrus," Mr. Brunner said, his voice low and haunting. "The West Wind. He loved Hyacinthus, but fate was cruel. Apollo struck Hyacinthus with a discus during a friendly game. The boy died, and a flower--the hyacinth--bloomed from his blood."

Percy's stomach churned. She felt physically ill looking at the discus. Zephyrus--the name filled her with unexplainable hatred. Why did she despise it so? Why did she wish to grab that amphora and break it to pieces until the image of the winged god disappeared?

"Zephyrus," Mr. Brunner continued, "diverted Apollo's discus so it would strike Hyacinthus dead."

Percy clenched her fists. She fought down the urge to scream how unfair it was.

Mr. Brunner moved to the next tale. Icarus--the boy who dared to fly too close to the sun. On his desk sat a small bronze statue of a boy with delicate wings. Percy stared at it, feeling a strange connection.

"But how do you know it's Icarus?" Percy blurted out. "There are so many winged gods--Erotes, wind spirits. How can you be certain?"

Mr. Brunner smiled, revealing wisdom etched into his features. "Look closely, Percy." He handed Percy the statue. "At the base."

Percy turned the bronze figure. There, inscribed in ancient Greek, was a name: Ikaros, how the Greeks used to say Icarus.

"It's not just about wings," Mr. Brunner explained. "It's about hubris, daring to reach too high. Icarus flew too close to the sun, and his waxen wings melted. He fell into the sea."

Percy shivered. The statue seemed to hold memories--of a boy who defied the gods and wings that carried dreams and doom. But that did not seem right to her.

Prince Hyacinthus of Sparta stood at the threshold of manhood, his fifteenth birthday marking the moment Spartan males came of age. But this was no ordinary celebration; it was an opulent affair orchestrated by his father, King Amyclas. Hyacinthus was not just any prince--he was the chosen heir, supposed to ascend the throne.

The festivities unfolded in the grand hall of the palace, adorned with tapestries depicting heroic battles and marble statues of gods. As guests arrived, the air hummed with anticipation, their fine linen robes brushing against the mosaic floors. Argalus and Cynortas, Hyacinthus's older brothers, watched from the shadows, their expressions a mix of envy and resentment.

Argalus, the eldest, nursed a deeper grudge. His wife, Parthenia, had eyes only for Hyacinthus. The young prince's charm and grace had ensnared her heart, leaving Argalus bitter. To make matters worse, Parthenia had not borne him an heir, and whispers of her blatant longing for Hyacinthus echoed through the palace corridors.

Cynortas, the middle brother, fared no better. After the scandal involving Parthenia, he remained unmarried. Amyclas struggled to find him a suitable bride, fearing another family scandal. The noble families hesitated, wary of aligning their daughters with a man tainted by association. No one wanted to risk their daughter falling in love with her brother-in-law and disgracing the family.

But Hyacinthus cared little for such matters. His mind was consumed by the unfinished temple of Hera, rising on the outskirts of Sparta. The goddess demanded perfection, and he supervised the workers day and night, keeping watches as they chiselled marble and invoked blessings. He worried about how strangely the wind behaved around him, making him seek refuge in holy temples. Yet, for this night, he played the dutiful son, feigning delight as the festivities unfolded. He drank wine, sang along, and danced through the feasting hall.

His two friends, Crocus and Smilax, stood by his side. Having inherited his grandfather's property and fought in multiple conflicts for Sparta, Crocus was in a high position. His wealth and influence now rivalled even the noblest of Spartans. Smilax's father had finally allowed a betrothal between them. They would be wed when Smilax turned eighteen, as it was custom for women of Sparta.

And then, she arrived in godly splendour--the muse Clio, Hyacinthus's mother. Her ethereal beauty stirred memories of a time when love flowed freely between her and Amyclas. But that love had shattered, leaving scars on the family. Diomede, their deceased first queen of Amyclas, had suffered the most. Argalus and Cynortas blamed Clio for their mother's heartache and feared her wrath.

Amyclas greeted Clio with a mixture of longing and regret. He knew she had moved on, but old flames die hard. The tension in the room thickened. Argalus and Cynortas exchanged glances, their silence a testament to Clio's immortal power. She was no ordinary woman; she was a goddess, and her wrath could unravel kingdoms. She had little tolerance for any slight towards her beloved son.

As the night wore on, Hyacinthus danced with Smilax and Crocus, their steps echoing the rhythm of the stars. Clio watched, her eyes filled with both pride and sorrow. She thought she knew her son's destiny--the throne awaited him. But would it bring joy or heartache?

Argalus clenched his fists in the shadows while Cynortas stared into his wine goblet. The lavish celebration masked deeper wounds--the ache of an unhappy and loveless marriage, the burden of expectation, and the fear of divine retribution.

And so, Prince Hyacinthus celebrated his fifteenth birthday with his parents, little sister, dearest friends, and grandmother. The temple of Hera stood unfinished, its marble columns reaching for the heavens. Perhaps he would find answers in its sacred halls--the path to kingship, the balm for wounded hearts, and the courage to face an immortal mother's gaze when he felt unworthy of her gifts and favour.

But for now, the music played, the torches flickered, and the gods observed. In Sparta, where honour and fate intertwined, the lavish celebration masked secrets that would shape the kingdom's destiny. And Clio, her gaze unwavering, sang forgotten verses into the night, weaving the threads of mortal and divine.

Her singing completely outshone the famous mortal bard that Amyclas had invited, a grandson of Apollo named Thamyris. The bard sang gloriously, inspired by the prince's beauty, love blooming in his heart, drawing censure and consternation from the muse and unease and discomfort from her son.

Hyacinthus withdrew at the threshold of the grand feasting hall, the air thick with the scent of roasted meats and spiced wine. His fifteenth birthday celebration was in full swing, the flicker of torches dancing across the gilded walls. His father, King Amyclas, presided over the revelry, his laughter echoing through the marble columns.

But Hyacinthus needed respite. The bard Thamyris had been weaving verses all evening, his honeyed voice extolling the prince's beauty. The courtiers clapped and cheered, oblivious to the discomfort etching lines on Hyacinthus's brow. He was no stranger to flattery, but Thamyris's words felt like a silken noose tightening around his throat. Much like Aristodamia's lascivious eyes on his body, the way she licked her lips when he turned sweaty and flushed from the training grounds. Or like the pleading glances from Parthenia and how she would try to reach him. With both women, Hyacinthus had to flee. He could do nothing but run from them.

He slipped past the feasting nobles; their goblets raised high, their hands reaching him to pat his shoulders. The night was warm, and the moon was a silver crescent above the palace gardens. Hyacinthus stepped into the fragrant darkness, the petals of roses brushing against his blue himation. Here, away from the prying eyes, he could breathe.

And then he heard it--the soft rustle of leaves, the susurrus of wind. Winged Zephyrus, the west wind, stood before him. His eyes were the colour of the dark twilight sky, and his hair, black as pitch, danced in the moonlight.

"Prince Hyacinthus," Zephyrus murmured his voice a breeze that stirred the petals. "Why do you flee from the bard's praises?"

Hyacinthus's heart raced. "Lord Zephyrus," he whispered. "Why do you haunt me? In the last few months, you've followed me, the winds only ceasing when inside the temples of the Olympians."

The god's smile was enigmatic as his dark eyes roved across Hyacinthus's body. He drew his himation closer, trying to cover every inch of skin. Not for the first time, he wished that male garments were as modest as women's. He would be delighted to be covered from neck to ankle.

"You are more than mere mortal, Hyacinthus. Your beauty rivals that of the gods."

Phylonoe, Britomartis, Hecaerge, Loxo, Oupis, and Eucleia joined, their voices blending like a harmonious chorus.

But Aura's gaze swept over Artemis, lingering on her curves, especially her chest. Icarus recoiled, bile rising in his throat. That was sacrilege. Artemis was the personification of purity and maidenhood; no one should look at her like that.

"Pure, you say? That lush and buxom body of yours hardly befits a virgin." Aura taunted the goddess of virginity, who had sworn eternal maidenhood the moment she was born.

Icarus' jaw dropped in astonishment, unable to believe what he heard. Had Aura gone mad? Had she spied upon a revel of Dionysus and his maenads and taken leave of her senses?

Artemis had advised him always to water down his wine and not to linger too long in Dionysus' new temple because her half-brother had ways of corrupting youth. As the son of a naiad, Icarus knew when water was safe to drink, so he rarely drank wine, only during the king's hideous feasts, when the poor youths and maidens of Athens were taken into the Labyrinth. "Retract your words, Aura, or face my wrath." Artemis clenched her fists.

"This is what a true virgin is supposed to look like. Nothing to entice and provoke desire."

Aura was foolish and knew nothing. Icarus was lean and boyish, too, but he had seen how both men and women looked at him. He was fortunate to be under the protection of Artemis, or they would try more than just look at him.

"I speak the truth. Your desires are no secret. We all know of Orion. Had your brother not acted, no one would believe in your maidenhood."

The glade crackled with tension. The huntresses shifted, torn between loyalty and fear. Orion was a sore subject for everyone. Polyboea had told Icarus about the giant. Artemis trusted him, but he disappointed and betrayed her. Icarus had vowed to never be like Orion. Unavailable women were unavailable; it was the end of the discussion. He did not know why so many men had trouble understanding that.

Polyboea, ever practical, took Icarus aside. Her skin was pale, and her eyes were wide with fear. Not fear for herself but for him.

Polyboea: "Leave, my boy. Stay away for a month. Artemis will deal with Aura, and you shouldn't be here. This tension between them has been brewing for a long while and will get ugly."

Icarus nodded, his heart heavy. He slipped away, leaving behind the Goddess and Titaness to their strife.

As Artemis confronted Aura with sharp words of rebuke, the glade echoed with their strong voices that made mortal ears bleed. Deities' tendency to let their divinity slip when angered was yet another reason to send Icarus away. He had Artemis' training and several blessings from her, but he was not an immortal hunter; he lacked their resilience.

In that moment, Icarus realized that even among immortals, family bonds and discord danced side by side. Aura had never been fond of him, her eyes cold, and never a word to say in his presence, but she had been accepting of him as a child on Artemis' insistence. As he grew, she started sneering at him. Icarus had pretended not to see to keep peace in the group. Aura had said something about Artemis' brother. Only one god was called Artemis' brother, her twin, the sun god Apollo. The divine protector of young men. The same god that Icarus would burn part of his hair for, leaving childhood behind. Icarus had inquired why. Polyboea had been silent for a very long time. Some of the king's guests had made him deeply uncomfortable with their greedy eyes and reaching hands, which he had to evade cleverly. Still, Icarus felt that he had to risk it. Aura was out of control, much like Orion had been.

Icarus visited the family that watched over his father's herds and received one of the finest cows. He led the animal to the temple district in the Port of Knossos, constructed by Daedalus. Persephone had a smaller temple close to her mother's grander one. Tyche, Hebe, Eros, Psyche, Dionysus and even Hades had shrines. Today, though, Icarus went straight to Apollo's temple.

Thankfully, the priests knew him on sight. Icarus had accompanied Daedalus during the construction many times. As a result, he was ushered ahead of the line by the second-highest priest. Icarus apologetically looked at the people ahead of him but followed the priest. It was never a good idea to argue with priests.

"Daedalides," The priest greeted him pompously.

Icarus fought not to roll his eyes. No matter what he did, how many boars, wolves and bear carcasses he dragged home, he was just the son of Daedalus, the inventor, to pretty much everyone. His father had chuckled at him when Icarus had complained about it once.

"I have every faith that one day I will be known mainly as the father of Icarus," Daedalus had smiled and smoothed Icarus' curls away from his forehead.

"Come now. We will prepare the sacrifice. A very fine offering. Go kneel before the statue and pray to Lord Phoebus."

Icarus obeyed, reciting the proper formula before focusing mentally. He recalled the incident between Artemis and Aura as he gazed at Apollo's resplendent, sunlit statue. He stayed there praying for hours when he felt warm sunlight fall on him. He tilted his head up and felt sun rays gently touch his face. Icarus had a strange feeling that the sunlight was utterly shocked and delighted. The image of a beautiful cliff covered in purple flowers overseeing the sunlit sea flashed before his eyes. Icarus rose, knowing where to go. He nodded to the priest and politely said his goodbyes. The priest gave him a small smile.

 

Apollo stood on the cliff's edge, his gaze drawn to the figure below. The love of his life--reborn, yet unmistakably the same soul that had once been Prince Hyacinthus. The hyacinth flowers swayed around Icarus, their delicate petals like a memory of their past love. A love Icarus did not remember because he would have been compelled to drink from the Lethe before being reborn. No matter, they would love each other again, and this time, Apollo would keep his love. If Zephyrus ever showed his face, he would rip that accursed wind god to shreds. No matter what Zeus said. No matter if it caused a war when Aphrodite and Ares took offence.

"Icarus!" Apollo's voice echoed across the cliffs, startling the boy. Icarus teetered, his foot slipping on the rocky edge. Panic flashed in his eyes as he began to fall. Apollo's golden, immortal heart stuttered in his chest. He could not let harm befall his beloved, not again!

Apollo moved with divine speed. He caught Icarus, arms wrapping around him, pulling him back from the cliff's edge. Icarus gasped, breathless, and Apollo's heart thundered. How could fate be so cruel and kind at once? His hair, his face, his body, and even his scent were the same. The only thing that differed was the eyes. Purple had been replaced by amber. Eyes much like Apollo's own. The god's mark upon the soul of his lover.

"Steady," Apollo murmured, setting Icarus on stable ground and sitting beside him. "Forgive me for startling you."

Icarus blinked up at him, disoriented. His ankle bled a small wound from the rocks. Apollo's touch healed it instantly, the pain replaced by warmth. Icarus stared, dazed, at the sun god before him.

"Who are you?" Icarus asked, voice trembling. Apollo raised an eyebrow. Icarus surely already knew but wanted confirmation.

"I am Apollo," he replied, his smile as bright as the sun. "And you are Icarus, the boy my beloved twin looked after for eleven years. Without telling me."

Icarus frowned. "I am sure Lady Artemis just forgot to mention me."

"No matter," Apollo said softly. "I know of you now."

Icarus touched his ankle and then met Apollo's eyes. "Why did you come to meet with me?"

"Because," Apollo confessed, "I was curious. Most young men pray for their own sake, not that of others."

Apollo glowed with happiness to have his love alive, breathing and next to him once more. The Fates cackled, but Apollo was too enchanted by his beloved to pay attention to the dreaded three.

The man's gaze held regret, as if he knew more than he let on. "Sometimes strength comes from enduring the impossible," he murmured. "And sometimes, the sea answers prayers."

Percy scoffed, but as she walked, the sun warmed her skin, and the waves whispered secrets. Maybe, just maybe, there was more to her story than she realized. The man's eyes followed her, filled with a strange mix of pity and longing.

And Percy wondered if she was more than just a girl with a injured foot and a chip on her shoulder.

She knew Icarus was an avid hunter, familiar with the woods around Knossos. He was kindhearted and would not let a child die. Secretly, she went to Daedalus' house and asked to speak to Icarus. At first, she was met with disbelief. She was just a maidservant. How could she show up in the household of one of the most important men in Crete and demand to speak to his only son in the middle of the night? Everyone's beloved young master? The chief maidservant of Daedalus as about to send her away when the young man in question arrived and asked his servant to let her in. Grateful she followed inside.

 

Daedalus' mansion was a sight to behold. The receiving room, where Icarus received her, was adorned with red walls, fine tapestries, and finely carved wooden benches lined with plush cushions and animal pelts. The room's grandeur momentarily dazzled the maidservant before she recalled her mission. Hearing her tale, Icarus was horrified, grabbed his weapons, and ran to find the baby.

 

The moon was high in the sky when a loud, desperate knock echoed through the quiet halls of Icarus' home. Startled, Icarus rose from his bed and cautiously approached the entrance of his father's house. He heard Eumede, their housekeeper, argue with someone loudly. Curious he walked toward the noise and with Eumede he found one of Princess Acacallis' maidservants, her face pale and eyes wide with fear.

 

"Master Icarus," she began, her voice barely above a whisper. "I bring grave news from the palace."

 

Sensing her distress, Icarus invited her in, ignoring Eumede's frown of displeasure as the housekeeper kept after them, gesturing for her to follow him into the receiving room.

 

"What troubles you at this late hour?" he asked, concern etching his features.

 

The maidservant took a deep breath, steadying herself before she spoke.

 

"Princess Acacallis... she has given birth to a son, fathered by Apollo."

 

Icarus' eyes widened in surprise and a bit of hurt. He told himself not to be ridiculous. Apollo had already told him that he had an affair with a local woman before meeting him but it was over. The god had promised to be loyal to Icarus.

 

"Apollo's child? But why are you here?"

 

The maidservant wrung her hands nervously.

 

"The princess... she was angered. Apollo forgot her after a few secret nights but has been openly romancing you for months. In her anger, she ordered the child to be exposed in the woods."

 

Icarus felt a chill run down his spine. He was familiar with how cruel Acacallis could be. But could not believe that she would do this to her own child. He had consoled Ariadne as she sobbed after her sister bullied her viciously. He had seen the state of those poor girls after Acacallis unfairly accused them of stealing her necklace. At least he had been able to appeal to Queen Pasiphae, so the Acacallis victims were moved to the service of Ariadne and Xenodice. Both were kind and gentle princesses.

 

"Exposed? But that means..."

 

"Yes," the maidservant interrupted, her voice trembling.

 

"The child could be devoured by wild animals, bringing the divine wrath of his godly father upon us all! I cannot look for him myself, but you... you are familiar with the woods. You can fight off the animals."

 

Icarus was horrified. He could hardly believe what he was hearing. A child, an innocent life, was in danger because of a lover's spat. He couldn't let that happen.

 

Without a second thought, Icarus grabbed his weapons.

 

"Stay here," he ordered the maidservant. Acacallis would notice her absence and not be happy about it. The princess had no issue with ordering helpless women to be beaten to death. Besides, Pasiphae had been hinting at him what he wanted for his upcoming sixteenth birthday. He would ask for this brave maidservant.

 

"I will find the child." He told her, and the woman slumped in relief.

 

And with that, he dashed into the night, determined to save the innocent life that had been so cruelly abandoned. He would never let a child die, and certainly not a child of his lover.

 

Icarus grabbed his weapons and dashed towards the woods without a second thought. His heart pounding, he calculated the quickest route from Minos' palace to the woods of Knossos. As he neared the spot, he heard the distant growls of wolves. With a surge of adrenaline, he fought off the pack, his eyes finally landing on the tiny, helpless infant. The baby was laying on a mound of red earth close to a largethicket of smilax shrubs, the red berries glistening in the bright moonlight. Swallowing bile as he recalled that tragic tale, Icarus acted fast. A demigod girl or nymph who was murdered by her mother. He could not let it repeat.

 

Cradling the child in his arms, Icarus returned home while praying thanks to Artemis for his tracking and hunting skills. He ordered his servants to bring goat's milk, adding a drop of nectar to soothe the crying infant. But looking down at the innocent face, he knew he couldn't keep the child. Acacallis could harm him again, and Minos would surely kill him if he found out.

 

"I must protect him," Icarus decided, "I will entrust him to the family that guards my father's herds. They are kind and one couple is childless. They will raise him as their own. They are pious and will shelter and love him dearly when they know he is a demigod."

 

He decided to name the boy Miletus, a name with double meanings: red earth, for where he had found the baby, and the root word of solder. The sad truth was that every demigod must be a soldier. It was the only way they would survive this cruel world, trapped between humanity and divinity.

 

The kind cattle herders were happy to receive the baby demigod. Icarus left them a few vials of nectar. He instructed them to add one single drop to each large jar of goat milk. They were not to try and sample it themselves; it would burn them from the inside out. Even Icarus did not dare taste nectar and ambrosia; his father was a demigod, and his mother a naiad. Baby Miletus needed nourishment since a wetnurse could not be found, and goat milk alone would not sustain him.

 

With a heavy heart, Icarus informed Apollo of what had transpired when the god visited him the next day. Apollo was furious. Icarus asked him to ensure that whatever punishment he visited on Acacallis did not strike Ariadne. Ariadne, her other sister Xenodice, and their mother did not deserve to be punished for Acacallis' actions. Apollo agreed. Queen Pasiphae had already endure divine punishment once for the crime of another. Icarus did not want to see it happen again.

 

To punish the cruel princess, Apollo exposed her affair with Hermes and her new pregnancy. Hermes fled, not wanting to deal with the consequences as Minos beeseeched their father for justice. The king forgot that while he was a son of Zeus, so was Hermes. Hermes was a god, where Minos was not. Zeus would not care that Minos had been dishonoured by his godly brother, no matter how self-important King Minos felt he was or how many temples Minos built.
Unable to do anything to the god that humiliated him, Minos turned his sight upon his daughter and the child in her womb. At first, he wanted to beat his daughter and her unborn demigod child to death, but Icarus intervened. He reminded Minos that the child had a very powerful god as a father. Hermes could very easily take offence if his child were harmed. Crete's wealth was tied up in commerce, Hermes' domain. If the god was to be insulted, he could financially ruin Crete with a snap of his fingers. Minos was well aware that he would be nothing without his vast wealth and mercantile connections.

 

Furious and beet red with failure and humiliation, Minos held his hand. Once the baby was born, he tore the infant away from his mother and handed it to Icarus.

 

"What am I supposed to do with him?" Icarus asked the king as he cradled the tiny baby.

 

Minos glared at the inventor's son.

 

"It is your fault that the little bastard got to draw breath. You dispose of him!" He hatefully spat, glaring at his baby grandson.

 

Icarus's jaw dropped, and he gazed at the infant. He walked about the palace halls, not knowing what to do. He didn't think he could give another demigod to the herders. One demigod in one place was dangerous enough. Two of them would attract monsters like a lighthouse attracted ships in a storm. Especially sons of Olympians.

 

While walking about with a sleeping baby, he run across petitioners from settlements in the west of Crete. They had come to see the king but had gotten to witness scandal. One man in particular peered at the baby and whispered something to his wife. The wife nodded to her husband with a smile and approached Icarus.

 

"Daedalides," she spoke and Icarus snapped to attention.

 

"We could not help but overhear your argument with the king. My husband and I have no children. We will be happy to raise a son of the god Hermes as our own. It would be a honor for our household."

 

Icarus looked at the woman, trying to gauge her sincerity, she peered at the baby, a smile blossoming in her face and cooing helplessly as the infant opened his eyes.

 

"One of my maidservants had a stillbirth. Her breasts still have milk." The woman cajoled.

 

Icarus looked at the baby and the woman.

 

"Very well. We will go to Hermes' temple so you and your husband can officially adopt him."

 

He handed her the baby, and the woman took him gladly, looking at him with a look of maternal longing. Her husband approached, nodding politely to Icarus and smiling down at his new adoptive son. Icarus took a deep breath of relief. Hermes' son was now safe. Possible godly wrath upon Crete was averted.

 

"Could we call him Cydon?" The wife asked her husband.

 

"Of course, my dear. We can call him what you like." The husband responded, making faces to entertain the baby.

 

Minos was not done. He decided that Acacallis had caused him enough disgrace. He banished his daughter from Crete. A ship was to take her to Libya and abandon her there. It was the last that Icarus heard of Acacallis. But it would not be the last Acacallis would hear of Icarus.
