In the heart of Sparta, under the shadow of the shrine of Hades, Hyacinthus, the Prince of Sparta, and his best friend, Crocus, the Son of Poseidon, stood solemnly in front of the dark altar. Their hearts were heavy with grief as they mourned the loss of Smilax, Crocus' betrothed and the daughter of Aphrodite. The air was thick with the scent of burning incense, their silent prayers ascending with the smoke, pleading with Hades to welcome Smilax into Elysium for her eternal rest.

 

As they burned incense, Hyacinthus began the prayer, "Hades, lord of the underworld, we beseech you to be kind to Smilax. Welcome her into Elysium."

 

Crocus, his voice choked with emotion, added, "May she find peace in your realm, far from the strife that marked her end."

 

A year had passed since Smilax's tragic death. Neither Hyacinthus nor Crocus had been present at the time, but they had pieced together the events from the accounts of witnesses. Smilax had met with her mother, Aphrodite, and a heated argument had ensued. In her fury, Aphrodite had struck her daughter dead, transforming her body into a shrub. No explanation had been given for this cruel act of a lack of maternity, but people's imaginations had run. Thankfully, no one was besmeerching Smilax' reputation. She was well known to be a very proper Spartan lady. She was betrothed to a notable warrior and had been a childhood friend of the Crown Prince. Smilax had been well known to be pious. She visited temples regularly and made lavish offerings to the gods. Despite being perhaps the most beautiful woman in Sparta she never flaunted her beauty and was loyal to her future husband. Perhaps that was what enraged Aphrodite. Still, people did not dare to speak out against the goddess either.

 

The shrub, a living testament to Smilax's memory, was moved to the gardens of Crocus' manor. Hyacinthus had taken a few cuttings from it, planting them in the royal palace gardens and in the wild, ensuring that Smilax's memory would live on.

"Apollo has been my rock," Hyacinthus confessed to Crocus one day. "He has helped me through my grief. I don't know what I would have done without him."His secret garden held a decent thicket of the shrub and he often liked to ponder life near it. Apollo always pulled him away when the prince took too long. It bothered the god that Hyacinthus could be this sad. As an immortal Apollo didn't quite understand grief. His family and most of his friends were gods, thus undying. Apollo had many children but he knew that they would eventually die, so he did not grieve like Hyacinthus seemed to be doing. He did his best to console his beloved. It was his steady, bright presence that helped the most. It reminded Hyacinthus that he still had love and joy in his life.

"I did not have friends when I was small. The boys always tried to show me up and got mad when they could not. The girls would just giggle and try to touch me. Among the Spartides my age, Smilax was the only one that could hold a normal, intelligent conversation with me and would keep her hands to herself."

"I didn't see her as much as I would have liked. Her father is a crass opportunist. He made it blatantly clear that he was aiming to make his daughter Queen. My father did not like her until Smilax was betrothed to Crocus, since he had his heart set on Danae of Argos. Grandmother did like Smilax. Considered her a jewel of sensibility and cunning, but father has the last word in everything."

"Smilax was so wary of me at first, she thought I would be like those demigod brothers of yours at camp but relaxed when she realised that I meant her no harm. She could always make me smile even during the most stultifying formal occasion."

 

"I will miss her." Hyacinthus wept on Apollo's shoulder.

"She was like a bigger Polyboea."

 

In the aftermath of the tragedy, Hyacinthus found solace in the arms of his lover, the god Apollo. Crocus, however, was consoled by the god Hermes. As the son of Poseidon grappled with his grief, he found himself developing romantic feelings for Hermes. It had only been a year since Smilax's death, and Crocus was anguished, feeling as though his burgeoning love for Hermes was an insult to his betrothed's memory.

 

Hyacinthus, seeing his friend's torment, reminded him of Smilax's protective nature. She had always shielded them from despair and sadness. Hyacinthus believed that Smilax would want nothing more than for Crocus to find happiness again, even if it meant falling in love so soon after her death.

"Smilax always shielded us from despair and sadness," he said. "She would want you to be happy, Crocus. She would not want you to live in sorrow."

Crocus looked at his friend, his eyes filled with gratitude at how understanding Hyacinthus was.

"You're right, Hyacinthus," he said. "Smilax would want us to remember her with joy, not sorrow. I will try to honour her memory by finding happiness again."

 

Like the shrubs that now grew in the gardens, the memory of Smilax would continue to live on, not as a symbol of sorrow but as a testament to enduring love and resilience.

 

One day, Crocus invited Hyacinthus to the athletic arena, where he often met Hermes. "I think it's time you met Hermes," Crocus said. "He has been a great comfort to me."

 

To their surprise, Apollo appeared, inviting himself along. "I would like to come too," he said, a hint of alarm in his voice.

 

Hyacinthus was taken aback. "Apollo, you seem...concerned. Isn't Hermes your favourite brother?"

 

Apollo nodded. "Yes, he is. But this is about you and Crocus. I just want to make sure everything is alright. My brother is the god of mischief and trickery. He can be difficult and unpredictable."

 

In Sparta's athletic arena, Hermes, the messenger god, played with a disc while waiting for Crocus. His eyes sparkled at the sight of Crocus, but confusion clouded his features when he saw Apollo.

 

Crocus stepped forward, gesturing towards Hyacinthus, the Prince of Sparta.

 

"Hermes, allow me to introduce you to Hyacinthus, the Crown Prince of Sparta. My closest friend."

 

Hyacinthus bowed respectfully, acknowledging the Olympian god. "It's an honour to meet you, Hermes."

 

Hermes chuckled, "So, you're the Hyacinthus I've heard so much about. The one who has won Apollo's heart and the attention of two other gods."

 

Hyacinthus rolled his eyes, "I see my reputation precedes me."

 

But Hermes' attention had already shifted back to Crocus, a lovesick expression on his face. Apollo, however, was eyeing his brother with an expression of disdain.

 

Hyacinthus turned to Apollo, "Why the sour look, Apollo? Isn't Hermes your favourite brother?"

 

Apollo sighed, "Yes, he is. But seeing him with Crocus... it's just... strange."

 

Hyacinthus placed a comforting hand on Apollo's shoulder, "We all grieve and heal in our own ways, Apollo. Crocus has lost Smilax, and Hermes has been there for him. It's only natural that they've grown close."

 

Apollo nodded, smiling at his beloved.

 

"You're right, Hyacinthus. I should be more understanding."

 

Hyacinthus smiled back, easily catching the disc thrown by Apollo and throwing it back swiftly, appreciating the easy and deadly grace with which his lover moved. Not far from them, Crocus and Hermes were doing the same but Hermes seemed to be telling a few jokes because Crocus was chuckling.

 

Eventually, fun games had to end. Hyacinthus was Crown Prince, and Crocus was his second in command. They had duties to attend to, too. Reluctantly, they took their leave of the gods. Hyacinthus stood on his tiptoes to give Apollo a goodbye kiss. Crocus briefly embraced Hermes. The two demigods left the arena at a run, leaving the two gods behind.

 

The two gods, Apollo and Hermes, remained in the arena, facing each other. The playful air that usually surrounded Hermes had vanished, replaced by a tense silence. Much like Hyacinthus, the messenger god had noticed Apollo's tension and unease.

 

"Why are you acting so strange, Apollo?" Hermes finally broke the silence, his voice echoing in the empty arena.

 

"There's no need to be jealous. While your Hyacinthus is indeed the most beautiful mortal I've seen, I'm not such a fool as to go after him and make an enemy of you like that idiot Zephyrus."

 

Apollo's gaze was steady on his brother.

 

"It's not that, Hermes. I know you wouldn't dare, especially since you can't outrun me. But while you are the god of lies, I am the god of truth. And I see through your deception."

 

Hermes' smile faded. "What are you talking about, Apollo?"

 

Apollo's voice was firm as he accused, "It wasn't Aphrodite who killed Smilax. It was you, out of jealousy. You framed Aphrodite. She might torment and punish her erring children severely, but she has never killed one. She prefers to break and remould them."

 

Hermes lost his smile completely, his face turning serious. There was a hint of anger in his eyes.

 

"Smilax found out about my interest in Crocus and confronted me out of jealousy. She dared to insult me. I lost my temper. It was unfortunate. I wouldn't have minded sharing Crocus with Smilax. A young man of standing needs to marry and have heirs. But she had to be unreasonable."

 

Apollo's expression hardened at the mention of marriage and heirs. Hermes just had to poked at a sore spot. He had gotten rid of Princess Danae, but thousands others were eager to take her place and dared to covet his beloved. Plaguing him with jealousy and anxiety. And, given how Hermes looked at Crocus, Apollo doubted he would tolerate a bride when one presented herself. Well, his foolish younger brother would learn. The mourning period was over, and while not as eligible as Hyacinthus, Crocus was considered a great catch by young maidens and their parents.

 

"You might have placed Hyacinthus and Crocus in danger if Aphrodite ever finds out." Apollo voiced his concerns.

 

He knew personally how destructive and vindictive Aphrodite and her brood could be. He found that out when the Daphne incident happened. Apollo had agonized for centuries over a nymph he only spoke sparse words with, who just run from him. If a love with such a flimsy foundation could haunt and poison him for centuries, what would a mutual love based on friendship, affection, and compatibility do to someone? Apollo did not want to find out.

 

Hermes shrugged, "I covered my tracks well, and Aphrodite is fickle. She likely has forgotten the incident already."

 

As the two gods stood in the arena, the tension between them palpable, they were left to contemplate the consequences of their actions and the intricate web of relationships that bound them together.

Zeus frowned, his thunderous voice echoing in the grand hall, "Apollo, you are known to be fickle in love. If I grant this request and you move on, we will have quite a problem."

 

"But Father," Apollo interjected, "As a god of prophecy, I know I will love Hyacinthus forever."

 

Zeus remained unmoved, "Prophecy is vague and misleading, Apollo. I cannot grant your request."

 

Apollo turned to Hera, "Stepmother, I will marry Hyacinthus. Marriage is an eternal bond, not always a union of love but of duty. Godhood has been granted to the spouse of a god before."

 

The two wind gods who had pursued his beloved Hyacinthus and been firmly rejected were among those gods whose spouses had been elevated. Zephyrus, the arrogant fool, had caught a glimpse of some nymph from the Isles of Blest, and when unable to just have his way with her, he had proposed marriage, which was likely what she had been after. That upstart flower goddess always left Apollo with a bad taste in his mouth. The very sight of her irritated him for some reason.

 

Boreas also had fallen in love with a nymph, who had been made a goddess so she could share eternity with him. Apollo had dallied with Boreas and knew him and his wife fairly well. Orithyia was a lovely goddess, gracious and understanding. If nymphs could be made goddesses, then surely a demigod prince could be made a god. Hyacinthus was far worthier than the two, or their husbands would not have coveted him.

 

Hera, however, was not convinced, "Apollo, marriage is to set up a proper, lawful household to raise legitimate children. You and Hyacinthus are both men. You can't marry."

 

Apollo, undeterred, reminded Hera, "We are gods, Stepmother. We make the rules."

 

Hera, however, did not change her mind. "Apollo, you and Hyacinthus can't have children together. That is the point of marriage--children that are heirs for the husband."

 

Apollo, desperate, declared, "I am the god of healing and medicine. I can figure out a method for two men to have children together."

 

Hera's eyes widened in alarm, "Apollo, you mustn't! If men can marry and have children, it will eliminate the need for women. As the goddess of women, I cannot allow that."

 

Apollo groaned. Why was everyone so ignorant?

 

"Hera, the method will not be available to everyone. Only gods will have access to it. Women will still be needed because procreation is not easy. One can't just snap infants into existence without consequences or defects. We are not Gaea, a primordial of creation. Besides, not every man will want to marry another man."

 

Unfortunately, this was when Ganymede walked in, holding his chalice full of ambrosia for Zeus. Seeing him, the king of the gods perked up, a smile gracing his face. Hera glared first at her husband and then at the mortal-turned-god. Ganymede faltered and visibly wanted to flee, but Zeus gestured him closer.

 

"Your request is denied, Apollo!" Snapped Hera.

 

Apollo gritted his teeth and had to leave as Hera began yelling at Zeus and insulting Ganymede. He would try again. As many times as it took. And if they still kept denying him, Apollo would make Hyacinthus immortal without their leave. He just needed to get a golden apple or take Ganymede's chalice. Hera and Zeus would just have to deal.

The Palace of Knossos was ablaze with light, its grandeur magnified by the flickering torches. The yearly Harvest Feast was underway, a grim event that marked the arrival of the Athenian tribute. Icarus, son of Daedalus, and Princess Ariadne, daughter of King Minos, were in attendance, their hearts heavy with the knowledge of the impending doom. They looked at each other as Icarus led Ariadne to their allotted seats. He helped the princess into the chair and then took his seat. The platters in front of them were laden with choice cuts of roast meat, flatbreads still warm from the oven, white crumbly cheese, glossy black olives, plump ripe figs and glistening dark purple grapes, but neither of them would be able to eat a single bite.

 

Ariadne, her face pale and her lips trembling with suppressed tears, quickly drained a goblet of wine. The effects were immediate, dulling her senses and providing a temporary escape from the horrifying reality. She slumped in her chair, her eyes glazed over, oblivious to the fearful whispers that filled the grand hall.

 

Icarus, however, was not so fortunate. The wine had little effect on him, a trait he attributed to his lineage as the son of the naiad Naucrate, a daughter of the sea god Poseidon. His mother had passed away when he was but a year old, leaving him with no memories of her and no way to verify his immunity to the intoxicating effects of wine. Normally, he rejoiced in this; wine was dangerous and corrupting, but he would have loved a respite from the horror of this day.

 

His clear eyes took in the sight of the Athenian maidens, their faces pale and their bodies trembling as they were led into the hall. Of the youths that tried to be brave, stand strong with their heads held high. They were gawked at, their fear a spectacle for the heartless crowd. Icarus felt a surge of anger and helplessness, his fists clenching at his sides. Not for the first time, in the privacy of his mind, he cursed the cruel tyrant king.

 

King Minos rose to his feet, his voice echoing through the hall as he spoke of his dead son, Prince Androgeus. His words were filled with grief and anger, a father mourning the loss of his child. Icarus watched him, his heart heavy with distaste. Minos spoke of a father's pain, but he eagerly inflicted the same pain on other fathers. Each of those maidens and youths had fathers, mothers and others who loved them and would mourn their passing. Androgeus's death had been unintentional on the part of the Athenian king. It was traditional for the winners of athletic competitions to be offered a chance to go after a local menace or monster in order to obtain more renown. Minos was conveniently forgetting that. The prince also got a proper burial, ensuring his passage to Hades. The youths and maidens would not even have that if it was not for the system that Ariadne and Icarus had set up. They had bribed several of the servants who looked after the youths before they were thrown in the Labyrinth to give each one a small pouch containing one silver coin, a vial of quick-acting poison, and a small blade. For them to take matters into their own hands and to at least have coin for Charon the Boatman.

 

The feast was a reminder of the cycle of violence and retribution, a cycle that seemed impossible to break. Icarus could not wait for it to end. Once the feast was over, he could go home and spend the night in Apollo's arms. The sun god was excellent at distracting him from his worries. Ariadne had no such respite. Icarus prayed silently for Ariadne to find someone to love and share her joys and burdens with. He quickly caught himself. He had heard enough about the cruelty of the love gods from Artemis and the huntresses to wish Aphrodite or her son on his dear friend.

 

As the night wore on, Icarus and Ariadne shared a look of understanding. They were trapped in a world of gods and monsters, bound by the whims of fate. But they had each other, their friendship a beacon of hope in the darkness. And perhaps, just perhaps, they could find a way to change their destiny.

 

As the feast ended, Icarus hurried home to his father's fine mansion. In the solitude of his bedroom, he was met by his lover, the god Apollo. Seeing the distress on Icarus's face, Apollo moved to console him. His words were soft, a balm to Icarus's troubled soul."The Fates are cruel," he said, "but one day, a hero will come, a son of Poseidon, who will slay the Minotaur. But for now, we must wait."

 

Their shared moment of solace was a small comfort in the face of the grim reality. But it was a comfort nonetheless, a promise of a brighter future amidst the darkness. And for now, that was enough.

 

The following day, as it was Icarus' habit after a Harvest Feast, first thing in the morning when Apollo left to raise the sun, Icarus made his way to the shrine of Hades. He was there to pray for the souls of the youths and maidens who had been sacrificed. He asked Hades to be kind and merciful to the unfortunate victims, his voice echoing in the silent shrine. The fine incense that Icarus had brought suffused the space. The other offerings were burning. It was strangely peaceful.

 

He was attended by a young priest named Nicodemus, who thanked Icarus for asking his father, Daedalus, to build the shrine. Icarus observed the priest. The young man, only a few years older than Icarus, had pin-straight, inky black hair, obsidian black eyes and very pale skin. Shadows seemed to behave strangely around him. He held himself with a demigod's casual, deadly, borderline inhuman grace. Sheer power was palpable in every gesture and movement. For some reason, Icarus was reminded of King Minos, his brothers and Heracles, even though the kind priest was nothing like the sons of Zeus. Icarus pondered on what it was that reminded him of them. He noted the shadows playing around the priest, and it hit him. This priest was a son of Hades.

 

Hades rarely had demigod children, being quite devoted to his queen, the fair Persephone. But Persephone left each spring, and the dark king got lonely. He was much more restrained and loyal than his brothers, but every so often, a mortal woman managed to hook his heart. Icarus was not surprised that Nicodemus only announced himself as a priest of Hades rather than his son. Children of Hades were widely feared, and all too often hated.

 

"Few people have the courage to properly honour the god of the underworld. Never seen shrines go up outside of the established sanctuaries of Hades or Sparta. The Spartans have never feared death." Nicodemus said, his voice filled with respect.

 

Icarus pointed out that since the shrine went up, it had seen lots of use.

 

"People are realizing that they can easily pray for their deceased loved ones," he said, his voice soft.

 

Icarus visits yearly on the anniversary of his mother's death or when a neighbour passes away. He was fortunate not to lose anyone whom he truly loved. He honored Naucrate's memory but he himself did not remember her at all. He had been only one year old when she had died, just weaned. When he thought of the word mother, Artemis's face came to mind. He always tried to banish that thought but never succeeded.

Nicodemus nodded, a thoughtful expression on his face.

"People often miss the obvious," he said. "Death, while terrifying, is the only thing in life that is certain."

Icarus had to agree that all mortals would one day die. Some sooner than others. Given that he himself had agreed to become the lover of the sun god, Icarus would likely die young. Apollo was the only person Icarus would ever love, but he knew how people who loved Apollo ended up dead well before their time. Icarus knew from the moment he realized that he was in love with the sun god that it would be the death of him, but could not walk away. Love was all-consuming and could not be denied.~~~~~~~~~~

In the ancient lands of Greece, Thamyris, a gifted and famous musician from Thrace and grandson of Apollo, was madly in love with Prince Hyacinthus of Sparta. The fabled musician had travelled far and wide, but he had never seen the like of the Spartan Prince. The gods had given him every possible gift: beauty, talent, martial prowess, intelligence and kindness. Hyacinthus, mostly renowned for his beauty, was pursued by mortals and gods alike. Yet, his heart belonged to none other than the sun god Apollo. Hyacinthus had rejected all suitors except the golden Olympian.

 

Thamyris, heart heavy with unrequited love, decided to share a cautionary tale with Hyacinthus. He recounted the story of his grandmother, Philonis, who boasted about her affair with Apollo and Hermes. Her pride and insinuations of simultaneously seeing both gods led to her downfall, as an angered Apollo shot her through the mouth with an arrow.

 

Thamyris had approached Hyacinthus, his voice trembling with emotion. "Prince Hyacinthus," he began, "I must tell you a tale. It is a tale of my grandmother, Philonis, who boasted about her affairs with both Apollo and Hermes. Her pride led to her downfall, as an angered Apollo shot her through the mouth with an arrow."

 

Hyacinthus listened to Thamyris' tale but confessed that his love for Apollo was unwavering. As the son of Clio, the Muse of History, he was well-versed in the deeds of Apollo - the good, the beautiful, and the ugly. He acknowledged Philonis' folly, stating that mortals should know better than to cheat on a god.

 

"Thamyris," the prince replied after patiently listening to Thamyris's tale, "I am the son of Clio, goddess of History, thus well-versed in the deeds of Apollo - the good, the beautiful, and the ugly. Yet, my love for him is unwavering. Philonis should have known better than to cheat on a god. Mortals who dare to do so meet only one end - death. There is no higher dishonour than infidelity. Mortals will kill their lovers for infidelity. What do you expect a god to do?"

 

The prince recalled one more detail of the tale of Philonis. She had boasted that she was more beautiful than the goddess Artemis. Yet another thing that was just not done. No mortal woman could boast that her beauty was greater than a goddess's, even when that goddess was an eternal maiden who shunned the company of men with vehemence. Kindly, Hyacinthus chose not to mention that to Thamyris. The musician was humiliated enough with his family drama.

 

"Hyacinthus," Thamyris lamented, "you will never even look at me. My heart aches for you, yet you have eyes only for Apollo."

 

Thamyris was left heartbroken by Hyacinthus' words. His love for Hyacinthus would never be reciprocated, and he could only express his sorrow through his music. He did this for years as he watched the prince love the god. Apollo usually grew bored of his mortal lovers quickly. At most, he stayed for a few seasons. It had been nearly four years since Prince Hyacinthus' meeting with Apollo. The sun god's devotion remained unchanged. Apollo visited Hyacinthus almost daily. During the day, they hunted, exercised or played music together. In the night, together, they retreated to Prince Hyacinthus' private quarters. In his despair, Thamyris learned that Clio bore a striking resemblance to her son, Hyacinthus.

 

"If I cannot have Hyacinthus," he resolved, "perhaps I can find solace in his mother's arms."

 

Seeing no other option, Thamyris decided to try to attract Clio. He challenged the Muses to a music competition, hoping to win Clio's favour. His heart ached for Hyacinthus, but perhaps he could find some solace in his pursuit of Clio. Maybe earning the love of a goddess would make him forget the rejection of a demigod prince.

 

Determined, Thamyris set out to go to Helicon, where muses often dwelled. It was also the birthplace of Prince Hyacinthus. The musician travelled on foot to Cyparissia. A beautiful town on the sides of one of the offshoots of the range of mountains runs along this part of the Messenian coast. The charming town had one flaw. It was home to a large temple of Apollo, which dominated the place. It also bore the name of another lover of Apollo, whom the god had transformed into a cypress tree. Thamyris had no choice; he had to go to the temple to pay his respects before he could access the shipyards and board a ship to the Isthmus of Corinth. One step closer to Mount Helicon.

 

Praying must have worked because the seas were smooth and the ship quick. At the Isthmus of Corinth, he had to stop by the temple of Poseidon to thank the sea god for the sea journey. He then walked to Corinth, where he took yet another ship to drop him off at Thespiae in Boeotia. From there, he walked to Mount Helicon.

 

The slopes of Mount Helicon were adorned with untamed and lush forests, a verdant tapestry woven from countless shades of green. Ancient trees reach skyward, their gnarled roots delving deep into the fertile soil, while their leafy canopies provide a sanctuary for many creatures. The air here is filled with the rustling of leaves and the songs of birds, a symphony of life that echoes through the forest.

 

Winding through the forest is the Hippocrene, a stream as pure and sparkling as the morning dew. Born from the hoof of the winged horse Pegasus, the sacred stream is said to bestow the gift of poetry and inspiration upon those who drink from its crystal-clear waters. The gentle murmur of the flowing water adds a soothing melody to the forest's symphony, creating a serene atmosphere. Thamyris had to observe the stream. He had caught a glimpse of Pegasus before going to Sparta. It was difficult to believe that so noble a creature had been born to a monster as merciless and deadly as Medusa.

 

Thamyris followed the stream and found himself before the Palace of the Muses. A grand edifice, built by the divine hands of the Hephaestus himself, is as inspiring as the Muses who dwell within. Majestic columns of gleaming marble supported a roof adorned with intricate friezes depicting scenes of epic tales and heroic deeds. The musician had to pause and stare. He had visited many royal courts and seen many palaces, but this one put every mortal palace to shame.

 

Thamyris pressed forward and stopped by the entrance. There, he announced his challenge to the muses.

 

"I, Thamyris, challenge the Muses to a music competition. If I win, I ask for the charms and favours of Clio."

 

The first Muse to meet him was Calliope, the Muse of Epic Poetry and leader of the daughters of Mnemosyne. While furious at his presumption, she nevertheless allowed him to proceed.

 

"Very well, Thamyris," she said, steely resolve in her divine voice, "we accept your challenge."

 

Following Calliope, Thamyris was led to the Hippocrene, where the Muses played their instruments. Clio sat at a stone dais, a golden lyre in her hands. Thamyris was speechless by her beauty, dark curls and purple eyes identical to her son's.

 

"Clio," he stammered, "you.. You.. are. Beautiful."

 

Clio sneered at him, an utterly unimpressed expression on her lovely, flawless face.

 

"How do you presume to challenge us when you can't even speak?"

 

Thamyris composed himself and praised Clio's beauty with much more eloquence.

 

"You look so much like your beautiful son." He added at the end of his speech.

 

Clio froze, her motherly instincts acting with a vengeance, making her jump to her feet, glaring at the mortal.

 

"How do you know my son?" she harshly demanded.

 

"We have met," Thamyris replied.

 

"I sang at Prince Hyacinthus' fifteenth birthday."

 

Clio finally remembered him. Had her mother, Memnosyne, been there, Clio would have been scolded ferociously for this memory slip. Memnosyne recalled everything and expected everyone to do the same, especially her daughters.

 

"Ah, yes," she said. "You made my sweet Hyacinthus very uncomfortable with your crass, vulgar songs. He fled to the gardens, where he was almost beset by the god Zephyrus. Had I not arrived in time to threaten him into leaving, I shudder to think what would have become of my one and only child.""Had you held your tongue, that winged pest might have never seen my son, and Hyacinthus would have been safer."

 

Erato giggled, cooing as she recalled the many songs Apollo had sung and the many poems he had written about her nephew.

 

"Well, dear sister. No one will trouble my nephew now that our golden lord is his lover."

 

Clio pursed her lips.

 

"Apollo comes with his challenges. I would have preferred if my son had avoided any amorous entanglements with any gods."

 

Calliope clapped her hands, giving the mortal a smile that exposed her sharp and white teeth. The eyes of the leader of the muses gleamed with an anticipatory sadistic glee. Calliope knew her sisters. This was not the first time a mortal had dared to challenge them. Clio usually sat out of the punishment, preferring to observe dispassionately and record the event in excruciatingly accurate detail. But this time, it was different. The mortal had poked at Clio's one weakness. Calliope would get to see her logical, rational sister go savage. It would be epic.

 

"Beloved sisters, let us focus on this challenge. We can discuss our lord and Clio's boy later."

 

Calliope declared the competition had started. Thamyris sang his best songs and played his best melodies. Each one of the muses played after him. The muses were much, much better. Thamyris realized that he had lost. But he was unwilling to accept complete defeat and relinquish what he coveted. He asked the fair and enchanting Clio if his talent and daring had stirred her heart.

 

Clio sneered at him in distaste. "You dare to challenge gods and presume to believe yourself better than us? Your hubris is your downfall."

 

With that, Clio and her sisters descended on Thamyris and ripped him. Clio was leading the charge for the first time. All the muses agreed that she deserved it. The mortal had offended her honour and had been a nuisance to her child. They discarded the pieces of the body at the foot of their mountain, a warning to whoever would dare to challenge them. The tragic tale of Thamyris' unrequited love and his fatal challenge to the Muses would echo through the ages, a testament to the destructive power of love and the consequences of hubris. Love is the house where logic, sense and reason go to die.

 

In the grand halls of the Spartan Royal Court, Prince Hyacinthus stood beside his lover, the God Apollo. The golden light of the setting sun streamed through the open windows, casting long shadows on the marble floor.

 

"Hyacinthus," Apollo began, his voice echoing in the silent hall, "I bring news of Thamyris."

 

Hyacinthus frowned, "Thamyris? The bard who left months ago without even proper notice? My father was furious at having to replace him quickly."

 

"Yes, the very same," Apollo confirmed, his face solemn.

 

"Thamyris went to Mount Helicon and issued a challenge to the muses. He pitted his musical skills against your mother and your aunts."

 

"But that's absurd!" Hyacinthus exclaimed, "He was good, I will admit it, but not divine. He was no match for you or my mother, Clio. For the Muses sake, even I am better than him!"

 

Apollo nodded, "Indeed, it was a foolhardy challenge. But there's more. In case of victory, Thamyris demanded...," he hesitated, "sexual favours from your mother."

 

Hyacinthus' face turned red with anger, "What?! Did he dare to disrespect my mother in such a way? I will kill him!"

 

Apollo held a hand, amusement on his face, "There's no need, my love. Thamyris is already dead."

 

Hyacinthus' eyes widened, "Dead? I will kill him twice, then! Where is his corpse?"

 

Apollo sighed, "The muses ripped him to pieces and threw the pieces at the foot of the mountains. Beasts have long devoured his remains."

 

Hyacinthus was silent for a moment, his fists clenched at his sides. Just the thought that Thamyris had dared to presume such things of his mother made Hyacinthus' blood boil.

 

"Even so," he said finally, "it doesn't change the fact that he dared to make such demands of my mother. It's unforgivable."

 

Apollo nodded, placing a comforting hand on Hyacinthus' shoulder, placating his prince. He understood his beloved's fury and disgust. When Apollo was a very young god, a disgusting giant dared to try and violate his mother. While Leto was on her way to Apollo's new temple, nonetheless, Apollo had shot the disgusting creature dead to rescue his mother. It still made his ichor boil to recall that the giant had managed to snatch Leto's veil off her head. If Apollo had been a bit slower...

 

"I understand your anger all too well, my love. But remember, the muses have already delivered their justice. Thamyris paid the price for his hubris."

 

And so, under the setting sun, the lovers stood, united in their shared outrage, yet finding solace in each other's presence. Hyacinthus rested his head on Apollo's chest, breathing in the scent of sunshine. The god's arms wrapped around him, enveloping the prince in warmth.

 

Seeing his lover still upset, Apollo suggested, "Let's take a walk in the gardens. It might help distract you from such things."

 

Several large and divinely blessed swans awaited as they entered the lush gardens. Hyacinthus' eyes lit up at the sight of the gorgeous birds. The prince laughed, delighted and enchanted. The birds snapped to attention at the sight of Apollo.

 

"These swans are a gift to you, Hyacinthus," Apollo said, smiling at his lover's joy.

 

"Like all swans, they are incredibly vicious, and I have trained them to protect you."

 

Apollo then gestured to a chariot, "These swans don't just act as guards. They can also pull a flying chariot. I know how talented you are in charioteering. You recently won the Chariot races of Sparta, which had competitors from all of Hellas. Now, I want to teach you how to drive a flying chariot."

 

Apollo gestured towards a splendid chariot, its intricate design and craftsmanship divine.

 

"This chariot," Apollo continued, "is a gift from Hephaestus' forges, made especially for you."

 

Together, the two lovers harnessed the swans to the chariot, their excitement palpable. Once the swans were secured, they climbed into the chariot, Apollo taking the reins first. With a swift command, the swans took off, pulling the chariot into the sky.

 

They flew around Sparta, the wind rushing past them as the city shrank below. Apollo easily handled the reins, showing Hyacinthus how to guide the swans. After a few rounds, Apollo handed the reins to Hyacinthus.

 

The prince had a few hiccups at first, the chariot swerving slightly as he got used to the sensation of flying. But he was a quick learner, and soon, he guided the chariot confidently, making Apollo beam with pride.

 

As they soared through the sky, Apollo couldn't help but feel a sense of contentment. His lover was safe, protected by the swans, and now, he could fly alongside him. He had taken Hyacinthus on the sun chariot quite a lot of times. His prince had always delighted in flying. Apollo had once let Hyacinthus hold the reins of the sun chariot. For caution's sake, Apollo had been behind Hyacinthus, enveloping the prince with his larger body, the god's hands hovering over the demigod's, just in case. There had been no need. Hyacinthus had driven the sun for close to an hour before becoming exhausted. Apollo had taken over, Hyacinthus leading against him. But it had been proof that his beloved deserved to become a god.

 

In the Hephaestus-forged chariot driven by swans, Apollo and Hyacinthus take turns holding the reins, their laughter echoing through the heavens. The sight of Hyacinthus, flushed with joy and excitement, stirs a deep longing within Apollo. He yearns to share his immortality with his prince, to have him by his side for all eternity.

 

Yet Apollo has kept this desire a secret. Zeus and Hera had denied his request for Hyacinthus' immortality. They believed that Apollo's love for the mortal prince would wane, making the gift of immortality unnecessary. But Apollo, the god of prophecy, knew better. He knew his love for Hyacinthus was eternal.

 

They had been together for four years, much longer than Apollo had spent with any other lover. His loyalty to Hyacinthus remained unbroken, his love unwavering. Apollo's resolve hardened as he watched Hyacinthus guide the swan-drawn chariot across the sky. He could not lose this bliss.

 

He became determined to secure either the golden apple of immortality or the chalice of the gods. Both held the power to transform Hyacinthus into a god, ensuring that Apollo would never have to part from him. The thought of Hyacinthus joining him in immortality filled Apollo's heart with hope and anticipation. Apollo wanted nothing more than to keep his lover with him always.

 

And so, the sun god set out on his quest, driven by love and the promise of eternal companionship. Unbeknownst to Hyacinthus, Apollo was ready to move heaven and earth to make him a god. For in Apollo's eyes, Hyacinthus was already divine.

One warm day in late spring, Apollo invited his beloved, Prince Hyacinthus, for a grand vacation across Hellas. The prospect of such an adventure filled Hyacinthus with excitement, his heart fluttering at the thought of exploring the vast lands of Hellas, hand in hand with his divine lover.

 

Before embarking on their journey, they sought the blessing of King Amyclas, Hyacinthus' father and the ruler of Sparta. King Amyclas expressed his concerns about his heir being away for an extended period. Understanding the king's worries, Apollo assured him that the three months would pass swiftly. With a heavy heart, yet trusting Apollo's words, Amyclas consented. Apollo also felt that Amyclas placed far too much on Hyacinthus' shoulders and needed to be taught a lesson. The king had Hyacinthus build temples before the prince was even officially considered a grown man. For years Hyacinthus had been handling duties that kings usually did. While it was good training for the future, it also was too much.

 

With the king's reluctant blessing, Apollo and Hyacinthus embarked on their journey. Apollo, driving his sun-chariot, took Hyacinthus to many cities. They visited Argos, the city of heroes; Elis, the site of the Olympic Games; Mycenae, the city of gold; Corinth, the city of two seas; Athens, the city of wisdom; and Thebes, the city of tragedies. With its unique charm and history, each city left Hyacinthus in awe. Seeing the joy and wonder in his lover's eyes, Apollo felt his heart swell with happiness.

 

Their final stop was Delphi, the city of Apollo's most famous oracle. Apollo showed Hyacinthus around the city, introducing him to his priesthood and ordering them to show Hyacinthus every honour. The priests, respecting their god's command, treated Hyacinthus with utmost reverence, making him feel welcomed and cherished.

 

Their journey across Hellas was not just a vacation but a celebration of their love, a testament to their bond. It was an adventure that brought them closer, an experience that they would cherish for eternity. And though they knew their journey would eventually end, the memories they created would forever remain etched in their hearts. Before long, they would have to go back to their duties.

 

Duty came calling far sooner than expected. He was wearing winged sandals, chlamys flapping in the summer breeze, and a cap over his black curls. Just a week into their visit in Delphi, Hermes, the messenger of the gods, appeared. He brought news that Zeus was calling an emergency meeting and that they needed to return to Olympus.

 

"Brother," he said, addressing Apollo, "Zeus calls for an emergency meeting. We must leave for Olympus immediately."

 

Apollo, who had cleared his schedule well in advance to spend time with his lover, was displeased. He voiced his frustration.

 

"But I had planned this visit," he protested, his voice laced with disappointment.

 

Sharing his brother's sentiment, Hermes revealed that he, too was not happy. He had also managed to carve out some precious time to spend with his own lover, Crocus, before their father, Zeus had summoned him.

 

Hermes sighed, running a hand through his hair. "I understand, Apollo. I'm not thrilled either. I had managed to carve out some precious time with Crocus."

 

Hyacinthus, understanding the gravity of the situation, stepped forward. "Apollo, you must go," he said gently. "The king of the gods can't be kept waiting."

 

Apollo looked at his lover, his eyes softening. He leaned in, giving Hyacinthus a lingering kiss. "I will return as soon as I can," he promised.

 

With that, Apollo and Hermes disappeared, leaving Hyacinthus alone in Delphi. But Hyacinthus was not one to wallow in loneliness. He decided to entertain himself while he waited eagerly for his godly lover to return. He explored the city, interacted with its people, and immersed himself in its culture. Still, Hyacinthus was a demigod. He needed more activity than visiting grand buildings and listening to musicians play. The prince decided to take this swan-driven flying chariot for a ride.

 

Hyacinthus was high in the air, hearing the trumpeting of his swans. The birds had been an odd sight in Sparta. They liked to stay in Hyacinthus' gardens most of the time, but sometimes, they would follow the prince around like ducklings. Crocus always struggled not to laugh when he saw the prince walking by, swans in his wake. As Apollo had promised, the birds were loyal and vicious.

 

Flying with them was a delight. Hyacinthus could leave the ground and be in the air, removed from all concerns. A breeze flowed around him as he lapped around the sky, whooping with joy, echoed by his pet swans.

 

Suddenly, the wind became strong, suspiciously strong. Hyacinthus registered that it was blowing from the west, and his blood turned to ice.

 

"Turn around!" He commanded the swans.

 

"Back to Delphi!"

 

The swans instantly obeyed and started pulling him to the nearest temple of Apollo as quickly as they could, strain visible in their white bodies. A temple of Apollo would be safe. Only a stronger god than Apollo could enter the temple with impunity. Zephyrus, while a god in his right, was nowhere as powerful as Apollo, a son of Zeus and an enthroned Olympian.

 

Unfortunately, Hyacinthus was in the air, in Zephyrus' domain, and the sun had gone down. Perhaps realising that the god of the west wind had attacked, Hyacinthus was forced to land the chariot roughly. He then ran towards the nearest temple of Apollo.

 

The swans, loyal to their master, viciously attacked Zephyrus, buying Hyacinthus some time. But Zephyrus, in his rage, killed the swans. The shrieks of his beloved pets reached Hyacinthus' ears, but he had to keep running.

 

Unfortunately for the demigod prince, Zephyrus was as fast as the wind. He managed to get a hold of Hyacinthus, ripping off his himation and tearing up his chiton.

 

"Stop fighting me," Zephyrus demanded, attempting to get Hyacinthus on his back and trying to get on top of him.

 

"Leave me alone!"

 

Hyacinthus screamed in horror and disgust, struggling against the god, tapping into the ichor in his veins more than before. With a burst of rare, inhuman strength, he managed to push off Zephyrus and injure the god, drawing golden ichor, but in doing so, Hyacinthus felt something shatter within him. It almost felt like a glass sphere in his guts, a curiosity that Apollo had shown him once. Hyacinthus felt it crack, but it stayed whole. He did not understand what it was but could not ponder it. He had to get away to reach the temple.

 

While Zephyrus was briefly stunned, Hyacinthus reached the temple and collapsed in front of a statue of Apollo. Apollo immediately appeared, holding his bow. He shot multiple arrows at the fast-approaching Zephyrus, forcing the wind god to flee when faced with the wrath of an Olympian. Hyacinthus knew that the arrows hit their mark. His lover never missed. The prince hoped that they hurt.

 

Apollo then checked on Hyacinthus, drawing the prince close to him, pressing a tender kiss on his forehead and wiping his sweaty locks away from his pale face.

 

"Are you alright?" he asked, concern evident.

 

"I'm somewhat injured," Hyacinthus replied, checking his body, "but I managed to prevent him from... from..." He couldn't finish the sentence; the incident had left him deeply shaken. Hyacinthus felt Apollo's healing light suffuse his body, and he relaxed, finally feeling safe. Tears stung his eyes as his whole frame shook with tremors as if it were the deep of winter.

 

Apollo nodded, understanding, swallowing down his rage at Zephyrus for daring to lay hands on his beloved. He could not be angry right now. Hyacinthus was deeply shaken and needed comfort. Apollo needed to be a protector and healer, not a destroyer and avenger.

 

"Rest now, my love," he said, taking Hyacinthus to his Delphic Palace to rest and recover.

Icarus:

 

In the grand throne hall of King Minos, Icarus, son of Daedalus, watched with a heavy heart as several men were condemned to be fed to the Minotaur. Beside him, his best friend, Princess Ariadne, shared his silent anguish. The evidence was scant, the accusations of treason based on the testimony of a single man who stood to profit from their downfall.

 

"Icarus," Ariadne whispered, her voice barely audible over the clamour of the court.

 

"You mustn't speak up. Father... he does not take kindly to defiance."

 

The princess knew her lifelong friend well. Icarus hated seeing injustice done to others, especially the powerless. She saw it when he defended her from the taunts and cruel words of her older sister, Acacallis. She had seen it when he prevented the guards from harassing the maidservants. While it was one of the reasons he was so dear to her, Minos' grand throne room was not the place to be a good and outspoken man. If there was a place where her father would broker no resistance and defiance, it would be where he had been declared king, where he felt the most powerful.

 

Icarus clenched his fists, his amber gaze never leaving the condemned men.

 

"This isn't justice, Ariadne. It's a horrific farce and mockery of justice."

 

Ariadne's hand found his, her grip tight and pleading. The princess took a deep, shuddering breath. Ever since Acacallis's disgrace, her father had been harsher with her and her remaining sisters. Xenodice was desperate to join a temple and get away from the palace. Phaedra was too young to understand why their father was so mean to her. Ariadne could just endure in silence.

 

Their father had grown fond of throwing the story of Princess Scylla to their faces: Scylla, the daughter of King Nisus of Megara. Nisus possessed a single lock of purple hair, granting him and the city invincibility. When Minos, the King of Crete, invaded Nisus's kingdom, Scylla saw him from the city's battlements and fell in love with him. To win Minos's heart, she decided that she would grant him victory in battle by removing the lock from her father's head and presenting it to Minos.Ariadne often asked herself what that princess had seen in her father to fall so deeply in love with him. Minos was already too old when he invaded Megara, and he was well-known for being cruel. What did a beautiful young princess see in him? Ariadne had to wonder if it was the caprice of a love god. Perhaps Zeus had ordered one to make the princess love Minos in order to give his kingly son an easier time conquering Megara.Minos, however was disgusted that a daughter would be so treacherous towards her father. He bound her to the prow of his ship, letting her hang on cruel chains, the winds constantly throwing her around. She wept with pain and regret. She prayed to the gods and finally, one took pity on her and transformed her into a seabird, an egret. Unfortunately, it was not the end of her suffering. Her father Nisus, angry at her betrayal, was transformed into a sea eagle and relentlessly pursued her.

 

After telling them this gruesome tale, Minos liked to remind Ariadne and her sisters that he had no use for treacherous daughters.

 

"King Minos has no use for treacherous daughters."

 

"I know, Icarus. But remember what happened with Cydon. You stood up to my father then, and he has not forgotten. I have seen how he glares at you when Daedalus is not around."

 

Icarus turned to look at her, his eyes reflecting the pain of memory. He had indeed stood up to Minos, defending Cydon, the son of Princess Acacallis and the god Hermes, from the king's wrath. It had been a bold move, reminding Minos of the dire consequences of offending a god. Especially the god of trade and merchants. They were an island. Without trade they would starve within the year. It had also reminded Minos of his own past offence against Poseidon, which had resulted in his wife's infidelity with a bull.

 

"I can't just stand by, Ariadne," Icarus said, his voice filled with frustration.

 

"These men don't deserve this."

 

Ariadne's eyes filled with tears as she looked at her friend. "Icarus, I beg you. Don't challenge my father again. I... I love you more than my brothers. I couldn't bear it if something happened to you."

 

Icarus looked at her, his heart aching at the fear in her eyes. "Even if I am the lover of Apollo, Ariadne, your father has shown he is willing to challenge the gods."

 

Ariadne nodded, her hand squeezing his tighter. "That's why you need to be careful, Icarus. Please, for me."

 

As the condemned men were led away, Icarus gave a silent nod, his heart heavy with the weight of injustice. But for Ariadne, he would lay low. For now.

 

His resolve did not last long. Minos threw in the Labyrinth a little boy who stepped in front of him when the king was parading through the streets.

 

Icarus stood at the entrance of the Labyrinth, his heart pounding in his chest. He had just returned from a hunt, his weapons still slick with the blood of his prey. But he wore no armor, his chest bare to the cool evening air.

 

His mind was filled with images of the Athenian youths and maidens, their faces pale and fearful as they were led to the beast's lair. He had seen them all, year after year, at Minos' gruesome Harvest Feast. Their screams still echoed in his ears, their terror a haunting memory.

 

But it wasn't just the Athenians who were fed to the Minotaur. Minos, in his cruelty, also threw his political opponents into the Labyrinth. Anyone who dared to gossip about the royal family, anyone who earned the king's ire, was condemned to the beast. Only days ago, a little boy of eight years had earned the king's ire. The child had stepped in front of Minos while the king walked through the streets to observe his kingdom. Minos took childish mischief as a challenge to his authority.

 

Icarus felt a wave of nausea sweep over him. The injustice of it all was too much to bear. He knew of the prophecy, the one that foretold the Minotaur's death at the hands of a son of Poseidon. But Minos had ensured that no son of Poseidon would ever set foot in Crete.

 

And yet, Icarus himself was a grandson of Poseidon through his mother, the naiad Neucrate. He looked down at his hands, the same hands that had slain countless beasts on his hunts. Could he be the one to end the Minotaur's reign of terror?

 

With a deep breath, Icarus stepped closer to the entrance of the Labyrinth, his resolve hardening. He would not stand by and let the innocent suffer any longer. He would face the beast, for the sake of those who could not defend themselves. And perhaps, just perhaps, he could bring an end to the tyranny of King Minos.

 

With a deep breath, Icarus reached out to push the door open, but was suddenly intercepted. An inhumanly strong hand gripped his arm, pulling him away from the entrance. He turned to see Hermes, the messenger of the gods, looking at him with a stern expression.

 

"Why are you stopping me, Hermes?" Icarus demanded, his voice filled with frustration.

 

Hermes sighed, releasing his grip on Icarus' arm. "It's on Apollo's behalf, Icarus," he explained.

 

"Only a child of Poseidon can kill the Minotaur. You are just a grandchild. If you try to face the Minotaur, you will die and leave Apollo heartbroken. Trust me on this, the world does not need his heartbreak."

 

Icarus felt a lump in his throat. "Am I supposed to endure this atrocity every year? Every day?" he asked, his voice barely a whisper.

 

Hermes looked at him sympathetically. "Icarus, there is nothing you can do. Throwing your life away will not help anyone. It will just hurt everyone that loves you. It will hurt Apollo, Daedalus, and Ariadne."

 

Icarus was silent for a moment, taking in Hermes' words. He realized that Hermes was right. He couldn't risk his life on a prophecy that might not even apply to him. With a heavy heart, he nodded, thanking Hermes for his wisdom.

 

With that, Icarus turned away from the Labyrinth, his resolve to fight the Minotaur replaced with a new determination: to protect those he loved, even if it meant enduring the injustice of King Minos.

 

Later, Hermes reported to Apollo. The messenger god idly held a crocus flower in his hands, twirling it. Hermes smiled sadly at the lovely flower. Seeing the Cretan boy was a shock. Icarus looked so much like the late Prince Hyacinthus. Seeing such a dead-ringer for his beloved Crocus' best friend brought the past back to Hermes. The loss of Crocus would always hurt, especially the knowledge that it was all his fault. He wondered if it was a case of rebirth, for just a coincidental resemblance. Given how obsessed his brother was with Icarus, Hermes suspected the first, but also he did not want to believe it. If Hyacinthus could rise from the dead to return to Apollo, why couldn't Crocus do the same? Why did his beloved still stay in Elysium? The one place where Hermes couldn't go.

 

"I stopped Icarus this time, but the boy is extremely upset about the devoured youths. If Minos feeds another small child to the Minotaur, Icarus might try again. That was what nearly made him break, a slaughtered child. Icarus is fond of small children."

 

Apollo realized what his favorite brother was getting at.

 

"If Icarus has a child of his own, he will be too busy to worry about the Minotaur and other people's children," he mused, recalling how much care a baby needed from when Asclepius was little.

 

This gave Apollo a new perspective and a potential solution to keep Icarus safe. Asclepius remained his favourite son, born of his greatest and truest love. Perhaps it was time for his beloved son to have a full sibling.

Percy was taking a shower and wiping the salt from her skin when she heard her mother talking on the phone."I need to talk to her first! She is my daughter and needs to hear it from me!" Sally was talking to someone.

 

Percy quickly got out of the shower, wiped off the water, and dressed at record speed. Her mom was still talking on the phone.

 

"Give me one hour to explain to her. I know my daughter. She will have trouble believing this."

 

"I will have trouble believing what?" Percy asked her mom.

 

Sally spun around to look at Percy and sighed.

 

"I have to go now. Give me one hour."

 

Percy frowned.

 

"Mom? You are freaking me out. What is going on?"

 

"Alright, Percy," Sally began, her voice steady despite the gravity of the story she was about to unfold. "I suppose it's time you knew the whole truth."

 

Sally took a deep breath, her gaze drifting towards the horizon where the sun was beginning to set, casting a warm glow over the beach.

 

"After Uncle Rich passed away, I was left with nothing but debts and this cabin. I had no choice but to drop out of school and move here."

 

Percy listened quietly, her eyes wide with curiosity and concern. She had heard bits and pieces of this story before, but never in such detail.

 

"I found a job at a local diner," Sally continued. "It wasn't much, but it was enough to keep us afloat. Every day after my shift, I would come back to this cabin, our only sanctuary in the midst of all the chaos."

"But as I got closer, I realized that the man was not a man at all. He was a god."

 

Percy's eyes widened in surprise, her mouth opening to interrupt, but Sally raised a hand to stop her.

 

"I know it sounds crazy, Percy. But it's the truth. Your father...is a god."

 

Percy's eyes widened.

 

"You mean that he looked like a god? People tell me that I look like a goddess all the time but I don't actually believe it.""Well, he did. But he is an actual, genuine god."

 

Percy gave her mom a look.

 

"Mom, did you eat or drink anything weird today?"

 

Sally gave her daughter a look of muted disappointment.

 

"Percy, I know that it is difficult to believe but you must."

 

"I realized what your father was after I had practically tried to wrestle him away from the animal. I got lucky that he was charmed and impressed by my bravery instead of offended and angered by my audacity."

"It can go either way with them."

 

Now this sounded familiar to Percy.

 

"Mom, are you talking about Greek mythology? The really bipolar gods of legend?"

Percy's eyes widened in disbelief, her mind racing to process the information.

 

"Poseidon? As in, trident-wielding, sea-controlling, earthquake-causing, horse-creating Poseidon?"

 

Sally nodded again, reaching out to squeeze Percy's hand reassuringly. "Yes, Percy. And he was charmed by my audacity, impressed by my bravery. He didn't smite me on the spot, which, as you pointed out, can go both ways with gods."

 

"But why would Poseidon be here, at Montauk beach?" Percy asked, her voice filled with confusion and curiosity.

 

Sally sighed, her gaze drifting back to the horizon. "That, Percy, is a story for another time. For now, just know this - you are special. You are the daughter of a god, and that means your life is about to get a lot more... interesting."

 

"Interesting how?"

 

Sally opened her mouth to speak more but was interrupted by a loud bang at the door. She quickly moved let the person trying to bring down their door in.

 

Grover Underwood stumbled into the Jackson cabin in Montauk, his eyes wide with terror. "Sally," he gasped, "there's a monster coming. We need to get Percy to camp. Now!"

 

Without a moment's hesitation, Sally Jackson ushered Percy and Grover into the car. As they sped towards the camp, the urgency was palpable. Percy, peering out of the window, felt her blood run cold as she recognized the monstrous figure pursuing them - the Minotaur.

As Icarus stepped into the grand mansion he shared with his father, Daedalus, the familiar scent of parchment and ink filled his nostrils. He made his way through the labyrinthine corridors, his heart pounding with anticipation. His father's workroom, a sanctuary of invention and creativity, was his destination.

 

Upon entering, his eyes fell upon the goddess Circe, her radiant beauty illuminating the room.

 

"Lady Circe!" he exclaimed, his voice echoing in the vast room. His delight was evident in his wide smile. His best friend, Princess Ariadne, held her aunt in high regard, and Icarus, in turn, had always been fond of Circe.

 

However, his father, engrossed in his blueprints, seemed oblivious to the goddess's presence.

 

"Father," Icarus said, his tone firm yet respectful, "Circe, a goddess, is sitting on a simple bench."

 

Without waiting for his father's response, Icarus turned to the maidservants.

 

"Bring food and wine," he ordered, his voice echoing authority. He then went to find a suitable chair for Circe. He found one, sturdy and comfortable, and covered it with one of his prized animal pelts before offering it to the sorceress.

 

"Circe," he said, extending the chair towards her, "please, make yourself comfortable."

 

Circe's eyes sparkled with delight.

 

"Icarus," she said, her voice soft yet commanding, "you have not lost the sweetness of boyhood now that you are sixteen. I am touched by your thoughtfulness."

 

She gladly took the chair Icarus offered her and partook in the refreshments, her laughter echoing through the room, a testament to the warmth and hospitality of Icarus, the young master of the mansion.

 

As they ate and drank, Icarus steering away from the wine as it was his habit, Circe regaled the youth with tales from her island. She had new apprentices, more nymphs had sought refuge with her. A pirate ship had attacked but Circe had swiftly dealt with them to keep her people safe. Icarus is glad to hear that the women under Circe's protection are safe.

 

"I must take my leave, Lady Circe," Icarus said after a while, "Apollo awaits me."
Icarus got up, gave a bow to the minor goddess and left at a run, eager to meet up with his beloved.
At the mention of Apollo, Daedalus looked up from his work, his eyes filled with concern.

 

"Icarus," he said, his voice heavy with worry, "I fear for you. Apollo's lovers often meet tragic ends."

 

Circe, too, looked worried.

 

"Daedalus," she advised, "it is not wise to anger Apollo. He is not a safe god to cross."

 

A weary Daedalus nodded, sitting next to Circe and draining a goblet of wine. The room fell silent, the tension palpable. Yet, amidst the worry and fear, there was also a sense of hope - hope that Icarus, with his youthful charm and kindness, could perhaps change the course of his destiny.

 

"I had hoped that it would be a short dalliance," Daedalus confessed to Circe.
"Gods have brief affairs with mortals all the time and then leave. I prayed for it to be so. True, my Icarus would have been heartbroken. But he is young and youth recover quickly. Better heartbroken than dead and turned into an accursed plant!"

 

Circe took Daedalus' hand in hers, giving silent comfort.

 

"It has been a year. Apollo shows absolutely no sign of getting bored. In fact he seems to get more and more besotted with my boy every day!"

 

"And Icarus is just as besotted and will not hear anything against Apollo."

 

Circe signed.

 

"Love makes one unreasonable."

 

Daedalus made a face.

 

"It took an arrow from Eros for me to feel that fabled love. Dreadful. I turned into a fool! And it wore off right after Icarus was born. I cared for Naucrate after, she was my lawful wife and mother to my child, but I don't understand this love business."

 

Circe gave him a rueful smile.

 

"You are fortunate then."

 

Daedalus gave the sorceress a look of curiosity. Circe seemed embarrassed for a moment, took a sip from her goblet and started talking.

 

"After Glaucus became a god, I became ennamoured with him. I tried to pursue him, but the wretch was intimidated by me. I was too ancient, too powerful, too crafty. He preferred to pursue some young, innocent young nymph."

 

"Scylla found him repulsive and wanted nothing to do with him. Glaucus, came to my palace and begged me for a love potion to use on the girl."

 

Daedalus listened, keeping his face carefully neutral. He was familiar with Scylla.

 

"I will admit I was jealous for a moment, but it passed. I looked at him and could not figure out what I ever saw in him. A weakling and a coward who could not endure a strong woman, and who sought to make an innocent nymph his by sorcery and deceit."

 

"Had I refused, he would have gone to a love god and they would have been all too eager to grant his wish. I decided to turn the girl into a monster instead. This way she is safe. Better to be transformed into a monster than to have your will usurped and your heart violated with false love."

Alkinoos's eyes narrowed. "Are you afraid? That Icarus will meet the same fate as the prince?"

In the sun-drenched halls of Knossos, Alkinoos, son of Athena, mingled with the old Cretan nobility. His lineage was a tapestry woven with threads of divinity and mortal blood. One evening, as the wine flowed freely and the torches flickered, Alkinoos found himself in conversation with an elderly landowning nobleman named Eurytion. The old man's gnarled hands traced patterns on his chiton as he spoke, revealing tales of a bygone era--the remnants of the old regime that clung stubbornly to their memories.

 

"Daedalus," Eurytion spat the name like a curse, "that wretched inventor! His sails have brought ruin upon Crete. "And what of you, son of Athena? What secrets do you carry?"

 

Alkinoos smiled, deflecting the question. He had a lot of practice with that lately, needing to avoid the god of truth. A difficult task given that Apollo visited Icarus almost daily. And in that moment, Alkinoos wondered if perhaps the greatest inventions were not of wood and canvas, but of stories whispered across generations, binding gods and men alike. He preened a bit, imagining his tale being told many generations after his passing.

The Fates exchanged pleased glances.

 

"Very well little hero," Lachesis said. "The deal is struck."

 

The Fates laughed, their laughter echoing across the ages. But Icarus knew--he had saved Apollo, and perhaps, in that sacrifice, saved the world. The most important thing was that Apollo would be spared. He would suffer but he would survive and eventually be all right. There was no other choice for Icarus to take.

 

In the opulent red halls of Knossos, where torchlight flickered against marble columns, Icarus stood, a shadow in mourning. His black chiton clung to his grief-stricken form, and silver jewelry adorned with black stones replaced the usual gold and brightly colored gems that marked his high status as Daedalus's only son and heir.

 

Princess Ariadne, his closest friend, moved beside him also clad in black but her jewelry gold, her eyes sympathetic. She, too, bore the weight of loss--their shared pain woven into the fabric of their friendship. Her brother, Deucalion, approached, offering condolences. Icarus accepted them tersely, his gaze distant.

 

But it was Minos, the cruel king of Crete, who disrupted the somber air. His voice, honeyed yet sharp, cut through the murmurs of the feast.

 

"Listen, noble guests," he announced, raising his goblet. "News from Athens has reached our shores."

 

All eyes turned to Minos. The wine-dark sea whispered against the palace walls, eager for secrets.

 

"King Aegeus," Minos continued, hatred lacing his voice, "has sired a son, by the name of Prince Theseus--a seventeen-year-old boy, not a babe in swaddling clothes. His mother is Princess Aethra of Troezen."

 

His lips twisted with bitterness. "Aegeus kept this hidden, even when Prince Androgeus met his end in Athens. Denying me my proper due."

 

Icarus's suspicion flared. Why conceal a son? Aegeus, despite numerous marriages and dalliances, had remained childless. Yet now, this mysterious heir emerged from the shadows.

 

"Troezen," Icarus murmured to Ariadne, leaning close. "A seaside kingdom, devoted to Poseidon. The god of the waves and storms. Aethra is a famed beauty. Beautiful enough for a god perhaps?"

 

Ariadne's eyes widened. She understood the implications. A son of Poseidon--destined for greatness, perhaps even peril.

 

"This Prince Theseus," she whispered back, "he bears the sea's mark."

 

Icarus nodded. "And a son of Poseidon is fated to slay the Minotaur."

 

As Minos raised his goblet in a toast, Icarus's mind raced. The labyrinth, the beast, the annual sacrifice--the threads of fate wove tighter. Prince Theseus, a secret son, stood at the crossroads of destiny. Would he unravel the Minotaur's monstrous secret, or would he, too, be swallowed by the maze's dark heart?

 

In the flickering torchlight, Icarus vowed to keep watch and plan. For the gods played their games, and mortal lives hung in the balance. And perhaps, just perhaps, the son of Poseidon held the key to their salvation. Ariadne meet his eyes and she nodded. They would make a plan to help Prince Theseus if their suspicions were correct. If Theseus was a son of Poseidon it would finally free Crete of the Minotaur.

 

And so, as the feast continued, Icarus's grief mingled with anticipation. The black stones on his silver jewelry seemed to pulse, echoing the sea's ancient song--a requiem for lost innocence and a hymn to the unknown future.

 

Icarus also had other plans, orders to follow from the Fates themselves. That he could not tell anyone. Not Ariadne, his best friend from infancy, not to his beloved father and certainly not to the love of his life, the sun god Apollo. But first he needed to obtain those wings. Icarus recalled an old design of Daedalus. For wings to fly on.

 

In the brightly lit recesses of Daedalus's workshop, Icarus sifted through the forgotten designs--the remnants of his father's genius. Among the dusty scrolls and half-forgotten blueprints lay a secret--a creation that could defy the very laws of nature: wings to allow men to fly.

 

Daedalus had kept this design locked away, hidden from the world. Perhaps he feared the hubris of flight, the audacity of reaching for the heavens. Or perhaps he knew the danger it posed--the delicate balance between freedom and catastrophe.

 

But the Fates had spoken, their voices echoing through Icarus's dreams. Apollo, the sun god, had drawn their wrath. His love for Icarus had ignited their fury. They demanded retribution--a sacrifice to appease their cosmic scales. And so, they whispered their cruel decree: Icarus must fly close to the sun, let his wings catch fire, and fall into the sea. Only then would Apollo be spared.

 

Icarus's heart weighed heavy as he unfurled the ancient parchment. The design was solid, intricate--a marvel of gears, feathers, and ambition. He traced the delicate lines, imagining the rush of wind against his skin, the taste of freedom. But freedom came at a cost--a price etched in flames and saltwater.

 

He found Daedalus in the corner, bent over a workbench, eyes hollow with grief. Alexios, their beloved grandson, had been murdered and taken from them five months earlier. The pain still seared their hearts, a wound that refused to heal.

 

"Father," Icarus said, his voice barely audible. "I need your help."

 

Daedalus glanced up, eyes weary. "What is it, my son?"

 

Icarus unfolded the design, revealing the wings--their delicate joints, the feathers like promises. "Build these," he said. "Two pairs."

 

Daedalus's hands moved mechanically, assembling gears, shaping feathers. Each stroke was a silent plea--for forgiveness, for understanding. As the wings took form, Icarus watched, torn between love and duty.

 

He hated himself for this--forcing his father to build the very thing that would carry him to oblivion. Yet grief had twisted their souls, and desperate acts became their currency.

 

When the wings were complete, Daedalus held them out--a fragile gift, a curse.

 

"Fly, my son," he said.

 

Icarus fastened the wings to his shoulders, their feathers brushing his skin. He kissed Daedalus's forehead, tasting salt and sorrow.

 

"I love you," he whispered.

Percy Jackson stirred in her narrow bunk, the familiar strains of music weaving through her dreams. It was a melody she knew well, etched into her soul across lifetimes. Apollo's gift to his beloved, a gentle wake-up call that transcended time.

He had been much pickier when it was time for lunch, only wanting his favorites and needing to be coaxed to eat the foods he didn't like.

It was still the same as before. The only thing that was different was the eyes. Their eyes had both changed color from their past lives.

 

Will hesitated. "I am, but... I don't want to eat something unhealthy."

 

Percy reached into her pocket, producing a small bag of blue gummy bears.

 

"How about these? They're not exactly ambrosia, but they're a sweet treat."

 

Will eyed the gummies, torn between temptation and caution.

 

"Okay, just one."

 

Percy handed him a bear, and he popped it into his mouth. His eyes widened in surprise. "It's good!"

 

Together, they sat on the sand, munching on gummy bears, watching the sun rise. Percy felt the weight of her ancient memories--the love, the loss, and the promise of new beginnings. Apollo's melody still lingered, a thread connecting past and present.

 

As the first rays of sunlight touched the waves, Percy leaned down and kissed Will's forehead.

 

"We're a family, Will. Across time and space."He smiled, his dimples mirroring hers.

 

"Yeah, Mom. Forever."

"I guess I shouldn't judge the mortal fathers of Athena campers too harshly."Percy chuckled."Exactly. Imagine having a kid dropped on you with no warning after just an intellectual conversation."

Metion's tense marriage to noblewoman Alcippe became even more strained. She despised Daedalus, yet had to pretend he was her own to protect Athena's reputation. Daedalus endured a childhood of hardship, all because of divine whims."

 

Michael listened, he did admit that it sounded quite rough.

 

Percy smiled ruefully.

 

"That is quite the understatement. The goddess of wisdom went out of her way to give her son the backstory of a comic book villain. And then she had the gall to be all offended when Daedalus finally snapped and killed one of his nephews."

Together, they made their way to the training areas. Swords clashed, demigods honing their skills. Percy picked up a dull-edged practice blade, but it felt wrong in her grip. She needed something more.

Chiron, the centaur trainer, approached.

 

"Percy, use one of the practice swords. Riptide is too dangerous for training."

This sword felt like an echo of their bond. Crocus was no longer just a friend. He was now officially her brother. So were the other sons of Poseidon who had helped Crocus waterboard that son of Ares for Hyacinthus' sake.

 

With determination, Percy began her ancient Spartan routine. Her new body moved fluidly, muscles remembering battles long past. She needed to get used to this form, to fight effectively. She moved to practice on the dummies, demolishing a few with precision.Then Luke Castellan, a son of Hermes, called her over. Percy shrugged and approached. They began a duel. Luke was good, but he wasn't Spartan good. Percy disarmed him effortlessly, making him fall on his butt.

 

His eyes flashed with anger as was typical for a young man defeated by a girl, but he smiled. "Again?"

Percy's response was simple: "I was the Crown Prince of Sparta. That title isn't earned by being pretty."

 

Several other campers eagerly demanded a turn fighting with her. Children of Ares and Athena challenged her, but Percy fought them one by one and emerged victorious. Icarus had always felt deep sympathy for the Athenian parents and families who lost their children to Minos' cruelty. Now, however he truly understood their pain, anguish and horror. "I may not be a warrior, but I know the Labyrinth's secrets. Together, we'll unravel its twists and turns."
