The daimones firmly placed him in one of the other lines, ensuring that he would get to judgement. Percy smiled, glad that despite the overcrowding, justice was still being done.

 

They moved closer to the gates. The howling got closer and it put Percy on alert. Not far away from them the air shimmered and Percy saw huge claws and fangs. She immediately reached for the bag from the pet store, pulling out a red ball. She squeezed it, producing a squeaky sound that made Cereberus' ears perk up. She smiled at the three headed dog.

 

"Hello! Hi Cereberus! Do you want to play?"

 

Percy threw the ball at the dog who shrank down from the size of an elephant to about as tall as Percy. Cerberus caught the ball and began pressing it with his paws, making more squeaky sounds. Percy pulled out a red plastic stick from the bag, making Cereberus look at her once more. She threw the stick and he immediately chased after it, finding it swiftly and then returning it to her. She took the stick from the drooling laws of his middle head and patted each head.

 

"Good job! Such a good boy!" She cooed at the fearsome guardian of the underworld.

 

She threw the stick again and this time it was the left head who got it and returned it to her. Then again so the right head could get a turn. Percy then took out the other bag. The bakery near the pet store had a selection of dog treats.

 

"I know that it is not Spartan spiced honey cakes but these should be pretty good too?"

 

Cerberus perked up at the sound of treats and eagerly licked her hands. Percy smiled and fed him the treats.

 

"Do you remember me buddy? I have been here before. More than three thousand years I descended here to get water from the Lethe. I gave you treats then too."

 

Cerberus tilted his head in curiosity, gently sniffing her before letting out a happy bark. Percy smiled as she patted him. Such a good dog, and the poor thing looked so lonely. She wondered if anyone took care of him. Like all dogs he needed love and care. Someone to play with him.

 

Unfortunately they had to leave because the daimones noticed them. Percy apologized to Cereberus before she, Will and Lee had to rush through the metal gates and then evade the daimones. Percy could hear Cereberus' sad hows a they run.

 

"That poor dog." Will said.

 

"For a three headed giant dog he is adorable." Lee opined.

 

"Yes he is. And he is lonely the poor dear. A neglected pet is such a sad thing." Percy told them as she gathered Will close to her.

 

Their next destination was the Asphodel Fields. Percy gawked in utter astonishment when she saw it. Before it had been desolate fields dotted with people. Now it was a nightmare. It reminded Percy of a crowded famous rock star concert, if the stadium was packed with millions upon millions of fans and the lights had gone out. The black grass had long been trampled. Percy could see a few black poplars growing sparsely among the throngs of dead souls.

 

She pictured every person that she had met in her short life. This was what awaited most of them after death. She pictured every classmate, teacher, salesperson, waiter ending up here. It was a bleak picture. The underworld had more people than it could comfortably hold. Percy took out her phone and snapped a few pictures. Next time someone accused Hades of trying to start a war to get more subjects she would show them these overcrowded conditions. Percy already knew that it was not the dark king, but this was further confirmation.Percy looked up, just like in her past lives, the underworld was a gargantuan cavern. A few times, when Hades had been especially angry, a stalactite or two had fallen. Usually over the Fields of Punishment. Percy spied a few of the stalactite over Asphodel indicating that Hades had a few more temper tantrums in the last few centuries and millenia. Idly she had to wonder how many had been caused by Disney's Hercules.

 

Percy, Will and Lee tried their best to blend with the dead and to avoid the daimones. Lee looked closely at the dead, as if he was trying to find someone. Percy was almost tempted to ask but she decided otherwise. They moved along, keeping up with the new arrivals from the gattes and the large black pavilion which was announced by more clarly labelled signage:

 

JUDGEMENTS FOR ELYSIUM AND ETERNAL DAMNATIONWelcome, Newly Deceased!

 

The lines past the pavilion were quite smaller. On the left, the daimones escorted struggling souls to the Fields of Punishment. That area was visible in the distance, glowing and smoking, a huge, desolate wasteland doted with rivers of lava, minefields and quite a lot of parbed wire separating the areas of torture. Percy culd see souls used for sport by hellhounds, burned at the stake. Fairly standard punishments and more unusual ones like people forced to run in cactus patches completely naked. She covered Will's eyes. And to her surprise there were people forced to listen to opera music.

 

Far away, on a hill she could see what could only be Sisyphus rolling his boulder up the hill. Percy saw much worse things too. She firmly kept her hand over he son's eyes as she guided him through.The right side was must more palpable. Percy was very familiar with this one. It lead toward what had been a walled city but it was now a gated community. She smiled briefly as she saw Elysium, where Hyacinthus had been taken right after death. The place that had been home to Icarus and Alexios for over three thousand years before their respective rebirths. Percy could see palaces and manors in the style in which she had lived in her previous lives. Disctitively Roman villas, medieval castles and Victorian manors. Gorgeous flowers bloomed everywhere, the grass was in every shade of color possible. If Percy strained she could make out the noise of happiness, laughter and pleasant chatter.

 

Just like before in the middle of Elysium was a beautiful green lake. From her previous lives Percy knew that it was a saltwater lake. In the lake there were three islands. The islands of Blest. Her destination if she died in this life. Percy swallowed with dread and unease. If she went there she would be forever separated from Apollo, Asclepius, Clio, Artemis and Ariadne. She would even be separated from Will. She looked away from it before Will noticed how upset she was.

 

"Lets go my darling," She told her son, grabbing hold of his hand.

 

They vacated the area and walked further into Asphodel. The lights dimed. The colors faded from them until they looked like black and white photographs come to life. The crowds of souls became sparser. They walked for miles until they heard screeching int he distance. In the distance they saw an elegant palace made of shiny black obsidian. In the parapets Percy saw the Furies in their monstrous forms. The three Kindly Ones clearly saw them but made no move to stop or confront them. Likely they knew that they were here to talk to Hades. Maybe were even ordered by him to let them pass.

 

The backpack hanging on Lee's back tightened and began dragging him away. Percy and Will startled. Lee immediately began to try and remove it but the straps were stubborn. Percy pulled out Katoptris."Lee!" Called out Will, grabbing hold of his brother. Will did his best to hold on but the force dragging Lee was too strong. Percy grabbed hold of her son as she tried to reach Lee.

 

"Remove the backpack!" She told Lee.

 

"I can't!" He cried out as he was indeed struggling to shrug of the clearly enchanted or cursed item.

 

Percy for a moment thought that this was Hades doing, to ensure that they did not grew cold feet and left but instead of being dragged to the dark palace, Lee was dragged sharply to the left, int he opposite direction of Hades' home.

 

The ground grew coarser and steeper. Percy's blood chilled as she and Will run after Lee. The cavern walls narrowed and became a tunel. Lee did his best to hold on to protrusions along the wall. Percy sprinted ahead, leaving Will behind. Maybe it was not the backpack itself but what was in the backpack. Maybe if she could open it if not cut it off Lee it would stop dragging him off.

 

The tunned grew colder and darker and Percy could feel the evil emanating from further in. Her blood turned to ice as she realised what this was. A gateway to the pit. She had seen it recently in her dream of the Crooked One and his servant.

 

Percy seized Lee and tore open the backpack. She was not one bit surprised to see the box tha Luke Castellan had given to her son' brother fly off into the chasm. Just to be on the safe side she cut off the tightened straps on Lee's shoulders. Lee breathed in relief.

 

"Mom! Lee!" Will called out from further back.

 

"Will! Stay where you are! Don't move any closer!" She screamed.

 

The last place she wanted her son in was anywhere near the Pit.

 

Lee grabbed his backpack by the upper handle and the two of them run away from the Pit and towards Will.

 

"Gods above!" Lee called out.

 

"What was that!"

 

Percy grimaced.

Lee paled, understanding the implications.

 

"No! It can't be!" He implored her.

"Luke Castellan is a natural thief as a son of Hermes. He has access to an item that grants invisibility. And everytime he speaks of his father, I can see the loathing in his eyes and hear the hatred in his voice."

 

Lee gave her a look of both anger and disbelief before he slumped in sad acceptance.

 

"He is my friend."

 

"You will be betrayed by one that calls you a friend." Percy quoted the prophecy.

 

"Seems that the prophecy does not just apply to me but to all three of us." She told him.

 

They caught up with a terrified Will who immediately rushed to hug the both of them. Percy kissed his curls. Lee was looking at Will with a puzzled expression. Percy gave him a questioning look.

 

"The incident a year and a half ago."

 

Lee spoke, making Will go tense in her arms. Percy raised an eye brow. Not liking the sound of this.

 

"What accident?"

 

Lee swallowed before answering.

 

"Our cabin decided not to tell you, but two Solstices ago after attending the party at Olympus we travelled back. At our stop at Stony Brook one of the unclaimed demigods in Cabin Eleven misted Will to stay behind."

 

Percy's heart stuttered in her chest. Her arms tightened around Will who drew even closer to her.

 

"Will was surrounded by monsters but he jumped into the sea and swam to camp."

 

Percy's jaw dropped.

 

"He swam to camp! It is twenty five miles of sea from Stony Brook to Camp, and it was December!"

 

Lee smiled.

 

"He takes after you then. But once he was back, dad appeared. He found out who the person responsible was..."

 

Lee paused and looked at her. Percy rolled her eyes.

 

"Punished him severely. I know Lee. I was never naive about your dad's temper."

 

Lee gave her a look of almost disbelief.

 

"I supposed not. But all the campers were shocked and horrfied. Especially the ones in Cabin Eleven. Luke might not be the thief and he could just have done this for revenge."

 

"Were they shocked and horrified that someone in Cabin Eleven tried to murder a seven year old?" Percy hissed.

 

She was sick and tired of people murdering her kids. First it was Alexios, murdered by a greedy son of a bitch of bitches. Then it was Asclepius, murdered by his own grandfather for saving a life. At least Asclepius had gotten to ascend to godhood which made it possible for her to meet him someday, hopefully soon. But now someone had tried to murder Will and campers were holding against him because Apollo frightened them when he punished the attempted murderer.

 

"It was really horrible to see." Lee told her.

 

"I don't care. That demigod tried to murder my child. Had I been ther I would have killed him myself."

 

Lee grimaced but stayed quiet.

 

"Let's go. We have to meet with Lord Hades." Percy told him, firmly taking her son by hand. Lee followed, backpack in hand. A reminder of their close call. Percy was in disbelief that they had almost fallen into Tartarus. Apollo, Artemis and Poseidon needed to know about this but she knew that prayers of people in the Underworld did not reach the gods in Olympus. It would likely reach Hermes, but Percy did not think it wise to pray to him when all evidence was pointing to his son being the thief.

Getting to the confrontation with Hades is hard to write, but soon I will have to stop delaying the inevitable. Going to reread a few more Hades scenes from the books and watch that episode in the show.

Percy meets Hades

The close brush with the Pit left them all rather rattled. Percy had it easier than Lee due to her past lives experience. As Hyacinthus he had been a crown prince and thus the one people looked to for leadership and assurance in a crisis. He had always needed to appear unruffled and in control. Amyclas and Sparta would not have tolerated anything else in the heir. Icarus had needed to be in control of himself when in Minos' court. Occasionally Icarus had slipped up and Ariadne had needed to do damage control. Percy decided to lean on Hyacinthus' experiences the most to face Lord Hades. She and Lee ensured to walk slightly ahead of Will and to shield him with their own bodies.

It was reasuring. Percy had noticed that outside his own cabin Will was somewhat isolated at camp due to both his age and Apollo's blatant favorism. At least Lee and the rest of Apollo's children had Will's back. Percy swallowed down the rage that someone had tried to murder her child. Lee refused to say exactly what Apollo had done to the culprit, but Percy could imagine. Her beloved had always been rather fond of skinning. Even the modern parts of her could not bring themselves to care. Will was her child, her mortal, fragile child. His safety was paramount, no matter the price.

Percy looked up at the parapets of Hades' palace. The Furies flew high, but the three of them had the demigod trio in sights. Percy could not tell which one was Mrs. Dodds, but none of them seemed pleased to see two sons of Apollo. Given that Apollo had unwillingly been party to their disgrace and dishonor during the mock trial of Orestes, Percy was well aware why. She wondered what Zeus had been thinking. While it had curbed Hades' influence and power in the human world, it had also handed the world to the humans in a sense.

If a court could decide if a kinslayer, the most accursed of all wrongdoers, could get off scott free, then what stopped everyone else from committing all sort of sacriledges and then just bribing a few judges? She wondered if the laws of non interference were just a cover for Zeus' blunder. Unfortunately she would never be able to speculate these thoughts to anyone, not even Apollo. But she was certain that Apollo had thought similar at some point. He definitely was not happy with the laws of non interference. How it must grate him to be considered just a myth, the invention of some long dead bard.

They reached the gates and stopped to admire the engravings. Predictably it was scenes of death. A lot of them were from ancient times. Percy saw the Attic city petrified of the map by Medusa, what had to be the Siege of Troy, the Burning of Rome. But also more recent events. Hiroshima and Nagasaki which made Percy bite her lip. How was such a weapon allowed to exist? The atomic bomb imitated godly wrath, and not just any godly wrath but Elder Olympian godly wrath.

She looked away from it and saw a trench from WWI, full with solders wearing gas masks. Percy also saw African famine victims waiting to be given food. Leaning closer she noticed that the etchings seemed ancient, even the one depicting fairly modern events. She wondered if these scenes were prophecies made thousands of years ago. If yes, who had done so? Apollo had never been permitted in the Underworld without Hades' leave and the two gods had always had some degree of bad blood between them. Apollo would not have agreed to do this for Hades. Percy could not think of an underworld deity with prophetic powers.

The doors opened for them and they stepped inside the courtyard. Will let out a gasp of amazement at the sight of the garden. Percy could not help but smile and stroke his golden curls.

"Mom, this place is beautiful!" Will told her, craning his neck to see.

Percy eyed the garded with more caution. It was full of multicolored mushrooms, plenty of shrubs that she recognized as poisonous, bioluminescent plants and more. In many areas, she saw gemstones of many kinds. Piles of enormous rubies, clusters of diamonds, glinting in the dim light.

Percy then spotted the statues, or to be more accurate, Medusa's victims. She had seen the receipts and knew that Persephone was a frequent client of Medusa's grisly artwork. To Percy's horror, most of the statues were children. She gathered Will closer to her and reminded herself that Medusa was slain and according to interview that Apollo had given to Olympus Weekly, this time it was for good. The dreaded gorgon would not rise again. She looked away from the children. The rest of the statues were satyrs, centaurs and perhaps nymphs. All of them had grotesque, terrified smiles on their faces. Percy gently steered Will so he would not look to closely. She looked at Lee and saw the expression of utter disgust in his face. He too had realised what the statues were.

The centre of the garden was the piece de resistance, an orchard of pomegranate trees. Her mouth watered as her nose caught a whiff of the wonderful sweet and tart scent of the fruits. In her previous lives, while figs had been her favorite fruit, she had still love pomegranates. She shook her head to clear the impulse to go and pick one. Percy's hand curled gently on Will's shoulder to keep him in place. With her other hand she grabbed hold of Lee.

Lee had a dazed look in his eyes and almost stepped of the path. Percy's hand darted quickly like a viper to grab his wrist. Lee startled, his own hand lashing out. His nails had grown out in the last few days and were awfully sharp. His attempt to slap Percy's hand away gave her a fairly deep scratch. A few drops of her blood fell on the soil next to the paved path.

"Lee!" Percy called out, hissing slightly in pain.

Lee startled, the dazzed look in his eyes replaced by horror when he saw the bloody scratches on her hand.

"Percy! I am so sorry!" He told her.

Lee grabbed hold of her hand and Percy saw his fingers glow slightly. The slight pain receded and when Lee released her hand she saw that the scratches were gone.

"Don't worry about it. It was literally just a scratch." She tried defusing the situation with humour but Lee still seemed tense.

"Those pomegranates are enchanted to tempt people. Don't worry. Just focus on the task ahead and ignore the allure. Okay?" Percy advised him.

Lee nodded, still giving guilty glances at her hand as they walked.

They went up the steps of the palace, between black columns. Percy was reminded of Amyclas palace with it's saffron columns and of the Knossos palace with the red columns. She felt a pang of nostalgia. The architecture was so similar. The portico ws black marble and she wondered if Hades, Persephone and their children ever got sick of the color black. It would explain the very colorful garden.

The entry hall had a bronze floor so polished that she could see her reflection. She looked up and there was no ceiling but then again, it never rained.

The doorways were guarded by skeletons bedecked in armour. She recognized a lot of the Ancient Greek armour from her past lives, some Roman styles from her personal history studies. British redcoats and almost every other military uniform in existence. All the skeleton guards held weapons. Be it spears and swords or muskets and automatic riffles. None of them even twitched at the presence of three living demigods but all of their hollow sockets followed their movements eerily.

The main doorway was guarded by two skeleton solders in Marine uniform. They held rocket-propelled grenade launchers. As they walked past the two Marines, Percy felt the weight on the bags on her back increase. She abruptly stopped, making Lee and Will crash on her.

"What is the matter?" Lee asked her in concern.

Percy removed her original backpack and the one given to her by Ares. She opened the first one, nothing was out of order. She then opened the second one. Percy screamed and threw the bag away when she saw what it was. She grabbed Will and scrambled away from it.

"Mom! What is happening!"

Percy pointed at the bag and the lightning bolt that was poking out of it. Lee gasped.

"Is that the bag that Ares gave us?!" He yelled.

"Yes." Percy spoke.

"This was his plan all along. The stupid little sidequest at Waterland was not to waste our time and delay us. It was so he could plant the Bolt and frame us!"

Lee looked at Percy and then at the Bolt.

"Shit." Was his short but succinct reply.

Percy heard clapping and looked directly ahead of her. Hades, the Dark King and Lord of the Underworld sat on his macabre throne. He was at least ten feet tall, dressed in black silk robes and on his head was a simple crown of braided gold. His skin was paper white and his shoulder length hair was the same shade of jet black that Poseidon's and Percy's hair was. But unlike Poseidon's unruly waves and Percy's hyacinthine curls, Hades had pin straight hair. The power emanating from him almost caused Percy to fall to her knees.

Percy decided to bow to her uncle instead, tugging the hands of Will and Lee so they followed suit.

"Lord Uncle." She greeted the god who had been her king for three thousand years.

"My former subject, reborn against my wishes." Was the reply.

Percy winced. Even if she wanted to lie in this situation, the enchantments on Hades' throne room prevented any soul from lying to him.

"I could not resist the temptation to be alive again." She decided to tell him the truth on her own volition rather than have it forced out of her.

Hades gave her an unimpressed glare.

"However, Lord Uncle. I did not steal your brother's Bolt or your Helm of Darkness."

Hades eyed the bag and the Bolt peeking out of it. He gestured to it.

"Explain in detail. From your little conversation with the sunny spawn of your lover, Ares seems to be responsible?"

Percy picked up the bag and passed it to Lee before moving closer to Hades. She pulled out her own backpack where the offerings to Hades were. She pulled out the glowing, petrified heart of the sun dragon. Then the potted planting of the Icarus tree and the black calyx with the design of Hades and Persephone on their thrones. She gathered the items Apollo had given them and approached the throne. She carefully placed them before Hades.

"Offerings for our intrusion in your domain." She told him

"The petrified heart of a sun dragon. The rarest of gems. A cutting form the Icarus tree, the only one of its kind. An calyx dating back to the rein of Minos in Crete. I personally crafted it myself from the finest materials under Daedalus' supervision. It was meant to be offered to your shrine on the first anniversary of Alexios' death but Theseus happened shortly before and then I died and Daedalus had to flee."

Hades waved a hand and the objects flew up, level with his eyes. He inspected each one, nodded and then a three skeletons appeared. One took the Icarus mini tree and headed toward the garden. Another took the petrified sun dragon hear and walked off to a direction Percy assumed was the treasury. The third one picked up the calyx and went in another direction, likely where Hades kept his ceramics.

"I suspected that it was a war deity when I first heard of it my lord."

That startled a laughlike sound from Hades.

"You suspected a brave war deity and not evil old Hades?"

Percy winced as she recalled Chiron's words and suspicions against Hades.

"You would have no motive to cause a war. The primary flaw of mortal is well, mortality. All mortals will die and come in your kingdom. The little I recall from my stay here was your rage everytime there was a large scale war or natural disaster. I know how much you dislike excessive paperwork. So you would have no reason to commission the theft of the Bolt."

Hades looked like he wanted to smirk.

"Continue." He ordered.

Percy took a deep breath.

"But there were some questionable actions. One of the Furies masqueraded as Mrs. Dodds and attacked me at the museum, accusing me of stealing something from my uncle. At the time I had no idea that I even had an uncle."

"Really?"

"Yes. My mother is an only child and all I knew of my father was that he was lost at sea."

"Lost at sea?" That prompted a raised eyebrow and Percy felt herself flush. It sounded ridiculous and she could not believe that she had once believed it.

"It is what my mother told me." She defended.

"Given that you had no motive to steal or want the Bolt then the only reason you would undertake this actions would be if your own symbol of power, your Helm was stolen."

"Only a war god would want a three way war between the Big Three. Ares gave himself away when he waylaid us in Denver to assign us a quest. I realised then that it was him and I prayed to Apollo, Artemis and my father to let them know of my suspicions."

Hades eyed the bag.

"My Helm is not there." He told them.

 

Percy grimaced, looking at the Bolt in distaste.

"I believe that Ares has it. But there is more."

Hades gestured at her to continue.

Percy told him about her demigod dream. The mortal servant addressing an immortal entity as 'The Crooked One'. Hades drew in a sharp breath and almost sat up on his throne.

"On our way here. Lee's backpack started to drag him toward the Pit. We managed to open it and the flying shoes that were gifted to Lee flew straight in."

Hades finally looked at Lee, inspecting him in a cold and clinical manner.

"Who gived him those shoes?" The god asked.

"Luke Castellan, son of Hermes. He was also one of Thalia Grace's two demigod companions. The other one possesses a cap of invisibility, gifted to her from her mother Athena. Castellan is the most likely suspect for the thief but I am not sure if the other one is involved as well."

Hades' obsidian eyes grew cold at the mention of Thalia Grace.

"I can't be lied to while siting on my throne. And in your second life you did build a shrine to me and you did aid my son and priest in his duties to me. I will act on your testimony Perseus Jackson."

Percy's heart stuttered at the mention of Nicodemos.

"Lord Uncle. What happened to him. To Nicodemos?"

Hades' mouth tightened.

"Your death greatly grieved my son. More importantly, he lost a trusted and valuable quest partner. Without you, he had to do everything on his own. Eventually, he slipped up and used his powers where others saw. He died from poison in his food, given to him by one of his fellow priests. That priest still screams in the Field of Punishment."

Percy felt tears run down her face. Nicodemos had deserved so much better. Hades' eyes followed the tears from her eyes to where they fell on the polished bronze floor.

"You weep for a son of mine?" His tone was curios, almost amused.

Percy glared.

"Nicodemos was my friend. Is he in Elysium?"

Hades eyed her blankly for a moment.

"He was, but chose to be reborn about eighty years ago. He was once again my son. When he was ten years old, a certain prophecy was issued. Zeus demanded that I send him and his sister to Camp Half-Blood. I refused. Zeus vaporised the hotel they were staying with their mother."

Will clutched her hand tighter, his face clouding with sadness but no surprise. Will already knew that Zeus murdered Hades' children. Percy looked at her uncle, mulling over his phrasing. Hades said that Zeus vaporised the Hotel, not that Zeus killed the children. She thought back to the two demigods at Lotus Hotel who thought it was still 1945. The boy's name was Nico and he had obsidian black eyes, much like Hades eyes. Percy decided to keep this to herself. Hades would not react well. Thinking that she meant to blackmail him. Besides little Nico would be safer there. It was a far from ideal situation, for him to be frozen in time, but better than Zeus killing him. Unlike Percy, who had several gods invested in her living status, Nico and Biaca would get an automatic kill order from the council. Hades had never been popular and it had only gotten worse in modern times.

 

Hades's voice snapped her out of her thoughts. He snapped his fingers and Percy's mother Sally appeared, frozen in golden light. Percy startled.

"Originally I meant to offer you your mother back in exchange for my Helm but you don't have it."
Hades looked at the Bolt.

"Unlike what my youngest brother believes I have never wanted that hideous thing. It is however powerful. And if my father is returning, I will need a powerful weapon to defend my realm from him."

Percy looked at her mother, then at the Bolt. She then looked at Will, her son. Her hand went to her pocket, where the pearls that her immortal brother had given her were.

"I have a counteroffer Lord Uncle. I will get your Helm back from Ares and return it to you."

Hades started to sit up and Percy quickly used the pearls. As they vanished from the Underworld Percy heard her uncle curse out her father and his little tricks.

Percy pulled out Riptide and started fighting him.To her utter outrage, Luke had the gall to grab Hyacinthus' sword from the belt of the slumbering Asclepius, and he and Percy clashed. She attacked him fiercely, driving him away from her slumbering son, both her sons. Will thankfully moved out of the way of any of the fights, pressing himself against a corner wall.

At first, Percy had the upper hand, but she couldn't injure Luke and the Styx either enhanced fighting skills or Luke had been holding back a lot during spars. They were too evenly matched. Luke scrambled away as Hecate threw him a dagger. Percy sensed poison on it. She thought Luke planned to use it on her, but he threw the dagger at Will instead. Percy saw Will's eyes widen, and her precious boy froze. Percy could not allow him to get hurt. Not again. Never again.

Percy instinctively stepped in the path of the dagger to protect Will. It hit her in her upper abdomen, and the poison acted fast. Apollo screamed when he saw her injury. His voice raw and piercing. Hecate and the rest used the distraction to grab Luke and teleport away.

Apollo rushed to Percy's side, his voice trembling, "Percy, stay with me. Please."

Percy gasped, "Will... protect Will."

Will knelt beside his mother, tears streaming down his face, "Mom, don't leave us."

Asclepius, now awake, hurried to his mother's side, "We need to get her to the healing chambers, now!"

Apollo nodded, lifting Percy gently, "Hold on, my love. We'll save you."

In the healing chambers, Apollo laid Percy on a bed, his hands glowing with divine energy as he tried to heal her. But the poison was too potent.

"It's Elder Python Venom," Apollo said, his voice breaking. "I can't heal it."

Will cried, "No, there has to be a way!"

Apollo's tears fell onto Percy's face, "You will fail to save what matters most, in the end," he whispered, recalling the prophecy.

Percy, despite the pain, refused to give up. She reached deep inside herself, finding a glass sphere at her core. With a final effort, she cracked it. The poison and the poisoned blood flowed out of her wound, leaving her weak but alive.

Apollo's eyes widened in amazement, "Percy, you did it."

Percy smiled weakly, "I couldn't leave you all behind."

Will hugged his mother tightly, "Thank you, Mom."

Asclepius placed a hand on Percy's shoulder, "You're a true hero, Mom."

Apollo kissed Percy's forehead, "Rest now, my love. We'll take care of everything."

The gods outside the chamber breathed a collective sigh of relief, knowing that another Dark Age had been avoided for now.

As sleep was claiming her, Percy heard Athena complain,

"Apollo wasted time on a mortal instead of chasing down the rebel gods. The rebel gods had this planned. Castellan demanded Jackson and Solace to buy more time for Hecate, Morpheus, Hypnos, and Nemesis to act. The target for the dagger was never Solace; it was Jackson. Luke knew that if he threw it at Jackson, she would easily dodge, but if he threw it at Solace, she would shield him with her own body."

Athena derided, "Silly maternal instinct."

Percy realized why Athena's kids were so messed up. Enyo congratulated Athena,

"Well done, Athena, for only figuring out the enemy's plans well after the damage is done."

Percy saw Apollo about to rise, intent on yelling at Athena but she grabbed hold of his hand to keep him near her. This situation did not need anymore complications. Let Athena keep her pride and posturing for know. The coming war would humble her enough. Nemesis definitely seemed bent on ensuring that.

The grand hall of Olympus was filled with tension. The gods had gathered to discuss the recent revelations regarding Luke Castellan, who had stolen Zeus' bolt and Hades' Helm. The air crackled with divine energy as the gods took their places, their expressions ranging from anger to concern.

Apollo, Hermes, Athena, and Enyo stood before Zeus, ready to report on the events that had transpired during Luke's escape. Apollo's golden aura shimmered with frustration, while Hermes' wings twitched with impatience. Enyo's eyes burned with a fierce intensity, and Athena's gaze was sharp and calculating.

Zeus sat on his throne, his eyes blazing with anger.

"Explain to me how Luke Castellan managed to escape confinement on Olympus itself," he demanded, his voice echoing through the hall.

Apollo stepped forward, his voice steady but filled with emotion.

"Father, Luke confessed that Kronos is rising. He has bathed in the Styx, making him physically invulnerable, and his mind is shielded by strong magic. The minor gods Hecate, Morpheus, Hypnos, and Nemesis helped him escape."

Zeus' eyes narrowed.

"The boy must be lying. The magical protections on him likely confused your truth sense and Hermes' lie detection."

Hermes bristled at the accusation.

"Father, we are not easily deceived. Luke's words rang true."

Athena shook her head in disagreement.
"This talk of Kronos rising might just be a smokescreen to cover the machinations of Hecate and her fellow rebels. They want us to go chasing a destroyed titan king and miss their movements."

Enyo's lips curled into a sneer.

"The Castellan boy was right about you, Athena. Always so eager to please daddy that you can't see past your own large nose. All that is missing is for you to accuse Uncle Poseidon of some nonsense!"

Poseidon, who had been silent until now, spoke up, his voice filled with anger.

"Why was my daughter Percy forced to be present during Luke's interrogation? You insisted on it, Zeus, and she was gravely injured and almost died!"

Zeus raised a hand to defend himself, glaring at his brother in annoyance.

"Luke refused to talk unless Percy Jackson and her son Will Solace were present. It was the only way to get him to speak. It was a necessary risk. Besides she did survive."

Poseidon glared at his brother but Artemis caught her uncle's eye and shook her head. Better to let it go for now. Zeus was definitely dispeased that Percy was alive when his own daughter Thalia Grace was not.

Enyo's eyes flashed with anger.

"It was a trap. Luke stalled until Hecate and the other rebel gods were ready. They used Percy and Will as distractions to cover their escape. We could hardly go all out with someone with as many ties to the council as Percy Jackson and her son present. I for one don't want another civilization collapse."

Athena's eyes narrowed. "You are stealing my deduction, Enyo."

The two goddesses of war began to argue, their voices rising in anger. Zeus quickly intervened, his voice booming.

"Enough! Enyo, leave us."

Enyo glared at Athena before turning to leave, her eyes briefly meeting those of her mother Hera and her brother Ares, who had been freed from his chains at Hera's insistence. Ares however did not dare speak and found himself glared by almost every other Olympian save for Hephaestus who was smirking at Ares and his recent blunders. Ares seethed but kept his mouth closed after warning glares from both his parents.

As Enyo stormed out of the hall, the remaining gods turned their attention back to the matter at hand. Apollo's voice was filled with determination.

"We must find a way to to recapture Luke Castellan and break the protections on his mind so we can have true and full confimation. If Kronos is truly rising, we cannot afford to be divided."

Hermes nodded in agreement.

"We need to work together, now more than ever."

Athena's eyes softened as she looked at her fellow gods.

"We must put aside our differences and focus on the greater threat. This rebellion would spell disaster for us all, especially given that prophecy. We need to investigate if Hecate and the other three have more supporters."

Apollo, Artemis and Poseidon glared at Athena for mentioning the prophecy and the possibility that it could be about Percy.

Artemis decided to interject.

"I understand that no one wants to accept the possibility of Kronos returning, but we must investigate just in case."

Zeus' expression softened slightly as he looked at his daughters.

"Very well. We will work together to uncover the truth and stop the rebels. But be warned, any further betrayal will not be tolerated."

That last one was aimed at all his sons, Ares in particular.

The gods nodded in agreement, their resolve strengthened by the gravity of the situation. As they left the hall, they knew that the road ahead would be difficult, but they were determined to face it together.

When the gods dispersed, Apollo and Hermes discreetly followed Ares and Aphrodite. Artemis went to check that Percy was all right. As Apollo and Hermes eavesdropped, they heard Aphrodite's voice rising in anger.

"How dare you think that the abandoned and derelict WATERLAND was a place suitable for a romantic date with me?" Aphrodite's voice was filled with fury. "I bragged about the 'special date' you were preparing, and now all of Olympus is laughing at me!"

Ares defended himself, his voice strained. "Kronos was affecting my mind, Aphrodite. I can't be blamed for what I did under his influence."

Aphrodite scoffed. "I've noticed the lowering quality of our dates recently. What's your excuse for that?"

Ares sighed.

"Hephaestus keeps a keen eye on romantic places. I have to work around it."

Aphrodite's eyes narrowed.
"Try harder, or there will be Tartarus to pay. And another thing, I'm very angry that you tried to get Percy, the third incarnation of Hyacinthus, killed. I've been looking forward to observing the third run of Apollo's and Hyacinthus' romance. I will not be pleased if Percy dies before the romance even starts. Considering the recent revelations about Icarus, Percy and Apollo might just become my favorites."

Ares looked taken aback. "I didn't realize..."

Aphrodite cut him off. "You'd better start realizing, Ares. Or you'll have more than just Hephaestus to worry about."

Apollo and Hermes exchanged glances, their expressions grim. They knew that the situation was more complicated than they had initially thought. As they continued to listen, they realized that the battle against Kronos would require not only their strength but also their unity.

Back at Apollo's healing chambers, Percy, Will and Asclepius were joined by Artemis. The goddess of the hunt placed a comforting hand on Percy's shoulder.

"Are you all right, Percy?"

Percy nodded, her eyes filled with determination.

"I'll be fine, Artemis. The poison is out and Apollo and our son healed the injury. I barely even have a scar. They just want to monitor me because of the bloodloss and for any side effects to the poison. No one has survived Elder Python Venom before apparently."

Artemis smiled softly.

"We'll get through this together, Percy. You have the strength of your past lives and the support of your friends and family. We won't let Kronos win. I will make that boy pay for this."

 

As Apollo and Hermes entered the room, Clio and Lee Fletcher also arrived. Clio and Artemis exchanged strange glances as they both positioned themselves near Percy.

Percy looked up at Apollo, her eyes filled with worry.

"When am I leaving? Zeus can't possibly be happy that three mortals, Will, Lee, and I, have stayed in Olympus for this long."

Asclepius snorted, "The only reason Zeus doesn't bring his mortal hookups to Olympus is because Hera would make a scene."

Apollo warned Asclepius, "Avoid talking ill of Zeus right now. The king of the gods is angry enough as it is."

Clio spoke up, "Before Hades left, he informed me that he will be returning Sally Jackson to her apartment soon."

Percy's worry deepened, "What about Smelly Gabe? He might harm my mother. He claimed money from the life insurance when Sally was assumed dead. He won't be happy when he has to return the money."

Apollo placed a reassuring hand on Percy's shoulder, "Don't worry, Percy. I've already dealt with Gabriel Ugliano."

Percy was almost tempted to ask how, but she caught Will's eyes and decided it was not for the ears of an 8-year-old. Likely there was a very ugly and stinky skin hanging somewhere. Percy could swear that Apollo had barely left her side, but she knew that gods could be in multiple places at once. She was snapped out of her musings by Hermes' voice arguing on behalf of Luke.

Hermes, trying to convince the others, kept saying, "My son Luke might be influenced by Kronos, just like Ares was."

Apollo shook his head, his golden eyes blazing with barely veiled anger.

"That's not how it works, Hermes and you know it! Luke is a mortal and would have decided out of free will to help Kronos. Ares wasn't directly controlled either, just given strong suggestions that acted on his impulses. Luke is serving Kronos out of his own free will, and you need to accept that."

Hermes stubornly insisted, "Luke is not a bad kid. He might be misguided and could be brought back to the right path."

Percy spoke up, "Luke stole Zeus' bolt and Hades' Helm. Zeus will want Luke's head on a spike for this humiliation, and Hades will ensure that Luke's afterlife is very unpleasant. With his actions, Luke has doomed himself."

Hermes argued, "It's not fair."

Percy laughed at Hermes saying that it was unfair that it was unfair that his disgrace of a son would pay for his crimes.

"Unfair? Unfair?"

Percy reminded him, "I almost died and I am in bedrest because Luke threw a poisoned dagger at Will, an 8-year-old, hoping I would intercept the knife and get lethally injured instead. It's sheer luck that I managed to survive."

Hermes had no reply to that. The messenger god looked at Will, whose eyes were still red and swollen from all the crying and lack of sleep over the trauma he had endured recently due to Luke Castellan and then at Percy, pale and exhausted, constantly sipping elixirs that Asclepius handed her regularly like clockwork.

Percy, curious, asked, "Why do you care so much about Luke?"

Hermes startled at her question and replied with some incredulity,

"Luke is my son."

Percy countered,

"Chris Rodrigues is your son as much as Luke is, but Chris hasn't even been claimed by you. Why is Luke so special to you when your other kids aren't?"

From her memories of Icarus' life, Percy recalled that Hermes never visited his son Cydon, the founder of a city that still stood. She had a feeling that if she asked Hermes about Cydon now, the god would not even remember that sweet little baby who had been a rather lively five year old when Icarus had died. Out of respect for that long dead demigod who had to the best of her knowledge not committed any serious crimes she decided not to ask Hermes about him.

During Luke's interrogation, Percy noticed that Hermes grew upset when Luke mentioned his mother. The god flinched, his eyes showing pain and then he glared in anger at Apollo. Had it been anyone else, Percy would have assumed that Apollo had done something to Luke's mother, but Hermes was Apollo's favorite brother. They avoided steping on each other's toes. The only time they had done so was during the Trojan War when they supported different sides. And even then Hermes had helped Priam reach Achilles to get Hector's body back.

Percy wanted to know, "Who is Luke's mother, and why is she so important to you?"

Apollo demanded, "Yes, Hermes, tell us."

The sun god had definitely realised that there was a deeper story there.

Cornered, Hermes had no choice but to confess. "Luke's mother, May Castellan, is the reincarnation of Crocus of Sparta, son of Poseidon, best friend of Prince Hyacinthus, and my favorite lover."

The room fell silent as the weight of Hermes' confession settled in. Percy, Apollo, and the others exchanged glances, realizing the depth of the connections and the complexities of their intertwined fates.

Percy, utterly stunned and processing the revelation, asked,

"So, Luke is the son of May Castellan, the reincarnation of Crocus, your favorite lover? My favorite brother? Crocus is back?"

Hermes nodded, his expression somber. "Yes, and that's why I care so much about him. I see Crocus in Luke, and I can't bear to lose him."

Percy sat up wringing her hands and looked at Hermes.

"Where is May now? Why didn't Luke stay with her?"

Hermes looked into the distance, guilt and regret flashing in his blue eyes.

"After giving birth to Luke, May tried to become the Pythia, the Oracle of Delphi, but she failed to house the oracular spirit and went insane."

Percy's jaw dropped. What was May thinking? Was she truly that different from Crocus. Was the lack of a Spartan upbringing that caused such a difference between the two incarnations of her best friend and brother?

"She lives in Westport, Connecticut. I ensure that she doesn't lose her home, her utilities don't get cut, and she has food, but I haven't been able to find a caretaker. Everyone I try to hire gets frightened by May's bursts of oracular power and leaves."

Hermes blamed Apollo's Oracle for May's insanity. Apollo reminded him with a stern glare.

"I forbade any more mortal women from attempting to house the Oracle almost thirty years ago because the world didn't need any more mad oracles. I didn't have oversight over May's attempt. I would have forbidden her from trying."

Hermes told him, "Chiron allowed May to try."

Apollo was irritated. He had told Percy that the only reason the Pythias were supposed to be maidens was to avoid pregnancies so the fetus would not be corrupted by the Pythian energies but it still was a longstanding tradition. To have it casually broken must rankle.

"A woman in a romantic relationship who had given birth a child was allowed to do so? I really need to have a long talk with Chiron."

Hermes explained, "May's clear sight was very strong. She already had some prophetic talent and was certain that she would succeed."

Percy interjected, "My mother Sally's clear sight is very strong too, but she would never dream of trying to become the Oracle. Not after having me. Also, I recall Crocus, and he would have never done something as reckless as what May did, not with the responsibility of a child."

Percy looked between the two gods and wondered aloud, "Was May influenced somehow to try and assume the Oracle? It led to Luke awakening Kronos. Kronos's sister Phoebe was the Keeper of Delphi before Apollo was born and the current regime has given her little reason to like Olympus."

The room fell silent as everyone pondered Percy's words. The implications were troubling, and the gods knew they had to tread carefully in the days to come.

Percy stood at the threshold of Apollo's healing chambers, fully recovered from the poisoned dagger that Luke Castellan had aimed at her son, Will, Percy was ready to face the world once more. She and Apollo had already said their goodbyes and Zeus was keeping Apollo busy looking for Hecate and the other rebel gods. Apollo was also looking for Luke Castellan and Percy knew that when her beloved got a hold of that young man, he would wish for something like the fate of Marsyas.

Lee had already gone to camp several days earlier. Percy was injured while a guest on Olympus after Zeus had put her in danger so the King of the Gods could not raise that much a fuss over her presence on his precious mountain, and Will was too young to be sent away from his sick mother. Lee however, Zeus had pettily demanded to leave. Apollo, not wanting to provoke his father given the state of affairs had taken his son to Camp. Percy had missed Lee in the last three days.

Ariadne, the former Princess of Crete and Icarus' best friend, arrived to escort Percy and Will back to Camp Half-Blood. Alongside them was Asclepius, Percy's son and the god of medicine. As minor gods, they were usually beheath Zeus' notice unless he had a reason to be fixated on them. Right now, Zeus had bigger concerns and since Ariadne was Dionysus's wife and Asclepius Apollo's son, their loyalty was not in doubt. The king of the gods was busy monitoring other gods, who werent so closely tied to Olympians.

"Are you ready, Percy?" Ariadne asked, her eyes filled with concern and tenderness.

Immediately after Ares' confession had been aired live on every screen on Olympus, Ariadne had read through the lines, genius that she always was and hurried to Aeaea to talk to both her mother, Queen Pasiphae and her aunt Circe. Both Immortal Sorceresses were very old, highly skilled and knowledgeable. Ariadne had hoped that they knew something of Kronos' rise. Unfortunately, neither daughter of Helios had been approached by Kronos' allies.

Privately, Percy thought that it was foolish of them. Circe and Pasiphae might not be the powerhouses that Hecate was, but they were still powerful, skilled and very, very dangerous. They also had ample reasons to resent at least two Olympians. Poseidon might be Percy's father but she was aware that what he had done to Pasiphae was nothing short of horrible. Circe was still obligated to stay in her island due to a decree by Zeus done thousands of years ago. Percy hoped that Ariadne's godhood was enough to keep both goddesses neutral if not cooperative with Olympus.

Percy nodded at Ariadne, her heart heavy with the weight of recent events.

"Yes, let's go. But before we return to camp, I need to see my mother."

Out of the corner of her eye, she noticed Asclepius made a strange expression but his face smoothed to its sweet youthfulness when she looked at him directly. Percy smiled at her firstborn son. She had given him the Crown of Lelex, which was his birthright but Luke had stolen Hyacinthus' sword, which Asclepius had received from Clio thousands of years ago, shortly before he himself went to Chiron's camp. Asclepius had held on to that sword and kept it in perfect condition only for a thieving, murderous little bastard to steal it from him. Despite what Hermes believed, Luke was nothing like Crocus.

Ariadne's chariot, disguised as a sleek car, awaited them outside. As they drove through the bustling streets, Percy couldn't help but reflect on the journey that had led her here. The quest for Zeus' bolt had revealed the true culprits: Luke Castellan, Ares, and the rising threat of Kronos. The gods Hecate, Morpheus, Hypnos, and Nemesis had aided Luke's escape, and Zeus' refusal to accept the possibility of Kronos' return had only complicated matters. She could not understand why Zeus was being so stubborn. Even if they did not have irrefutable proof that Kronos was back it was still obvious that he was. Ares' had been influenced. Hecate, Morpheus, Hypnos and Nemesis had unmasked themselves as rebels to help Luke escape. That told Percy that Luke was important to Kronos. The Titan king and his allies needed Luke Castellan.

Apollo had agreed with her. Luke was likely the conduit by which Kronos' essence was rising from Tartarus. The more demigods swore alliance to Kronos, the more anchors he would have to the world and then it would be a matter of time. Time which the king of the gods was wasting playing ostrich. At least both Poseidon and Hades would prepare their kingdoms for war. They were also terrified of the possibility of their father rising but they at least could be counted to prepare properly and accept reality.

Arriving at Sally Jackson's apartment, Percy felt a surge of emotion. Hades had kept his word and returned her mother unharmed after receiving his helm. The negotiations between Hades, Poseidon, and Zeus had resulted in concessions, including the revocation of Hades' banishment from Olympus.

Sally Jackson opened the door, her eyes widening in surprise and relief. "Percy! Oh, my dear, you're safe!"

Percy embraced her mother tightly. "Mom, I'm so glad to see you."

Sally's gaze shifted to the others. "And who are these young men?"

Percy introduced them with pride. "This is Will Solace, demigod son of Apollo, and Asclepius, immortal son of Apollo and God of Medicine. And this is Ariadne, a dear friend."

Sally's eyes widened further. "Two gods? How?"

Percy nodded, her heart swelling with emotion. "Yes, Mom. And I promise, we'll explain everything."

As they settled into the apartment, Sally couldn't help but ask, "What happened to Gabe?"

Percy's expression hardened. "Apollo dealt with him. You won't have to worry about him anymore."

Sally nodded, accepting the answer. "Tell me everything, Percy. What happened while I was in stasis?"

Percy recounted the events of her quest, how she and Will had been sent by Zeus to find his bolt, and how they had uncovered the truth about Luke and Kronos. She explained how Poseidon had manipulated the mist to portray her as the victim and how the police were now hunting for Gabe. The police were under the impression that Gabe Ugliano hired criminals to kill his wife for the life insurance money and his stepdaughter for the money from her modelling career. Percy was in the clear. She had seen how social medial had blown up in her defense.

Sally sighed with relief but also with a hint of sadness. "I never wanted this life for you, Percy. I married Gabe to protect you from the monsters that were drawn to your scent. His stench kept them away."

Asclepius interjected gently, "You could have sent Percy to camp, Mrs. Jackson."

Sally shook her head. "I couldn't bear to lose her. She is my daughter, my only child."

Percy reached out and took her mother's hand. "I understand, Mom. But now, I have to stay at camp. I can't be separated from my children, just like you couldn't be separated from me."

Sally's teacup slipped from her hand, shattering on the floor. "Children... How can you have children?"

Percy took a deep breath and began to explain. "Mom, there's so much you need to know. I am the reincarnation of Prince Hyacinthus and Icarus of Crete. After Hyacinthus died, Apollo created Asclepius from the essence of the original hyacinth flower. When Icarus died, Apollo transformed my corpse into a tree and convinced Persephone to create a magical connection between the tree and my soul in the underworld. When I was born as Percy, the tree pulled my essence to alert Apollo that Hyacinthus had been reincarnated again. While trying to get a vision of my whereabouts, Apollo accidentally mixed his godly essence with mine and created Will."

Sally's eyes filled with astonishment and tears. "So, I'm a grandmother?"

Percy smiled softly. "It's a long story, but the important thing is that we're together now."

Sally hugged both Will and Asclepius, her changing blue eyes overflowing with love.

"Welcome to the family, boys."

As they continued to talk, the understanding between mother and daughter grew stronger. Sally accepted Will and Asclepius as her grandchildren, and the family found solace in each other's presence.

The journey ahead was uncertain, with the threat of Kronos looming and the gods divided. But with the support of her family and friends, Percy Jackson was ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead.

As they prepared to leave for Camp Half-Blood, Ariadne's chariot awaited them once more. Percy turned to her mother, her heart filled with determination.

"Mom, we'll be back. And we'll make sure the world is safe for all of us."

Sally wiped her tears and smiled. "I understand. Maybe I'll move to Montauk so I can be closer to you and Will."

Ariadne and Asclepius both nodded in approval. "That's a great idea," Ariadne said. "We don't want Percy making long trips outside of camp."

As they prepared to leave, Sally hugged Percy tightly. "Stay safe, my dear. And remember, you always have a home here."

Percy smiled, her heart filled with gratitude. "I will, Mom. Thank you for everything. I will be in touch with you as often as I can."

Sally nodded, her eyes filled with pride. "I know you will, Percy. I believe in you."

With that, Percy, Will, Asclepius, and Ariadne set off on their journey, ready to face the trials and tribulations that awaited them. As much as Percy would like to believe that it would be smooth sailing from now on, she was all too aware of how much the Fates liked to torment her.

At the edge of camp Asclepius had to say goodbye to his mother and little brother.

"I have to go back to Olympus to help manage the virus that father caused when you fell of the Arch. It will be a long pandemic, and it will take years for the world to go back to normal."

Percy looked at her son with concern. "What will happen to schooling, work, and everyday life?"

Asclepius sighed. "Only time will reveal, but it won't be easy."

They closed their eyes so Asclepius could flash away to Olympus, Ariadne telling them when it was safe to open their eyes again. Ariadne would be coming with them in camp. In exchange for getting the agreement of neutrality from Circe and Pasiphae, Ariadne had managed to finagle more visits to her husband from Zeus. Once again Percy had to shake her head at how petty the king of the gods could be. Not only he had punished his son with a century of forced sobriety but he was also punishing the innocent Ariadne by forcibly separating her from her husband.

Percy Jackson, the reincarnation of Prince Hyacinthus and Icarus, walked through the gates of Camp Half-Blood with her son, Will, by her side. The twelve-year-old demigod had just recovered from Luke's murder attempt on Olympus, and now she was returning to the place she called home. Beside her, the goddess Ariadne, Icarus' best friend, accompanied them to visit her husband, Dionysus, the camp director.

As they made their way through the camp, Percy couldn't help but notice the stares and whispers that followed them. The camp was in shock after learning that Luke had stolen the bolt to start a war between the gods and had almost killed Will, an eight-year-old child trying to reach his mother.

"Mom, why is everyone staring at us?" Will asked, his voice filled with curiosity and a hint of fear.

Percy squeezed his hand reassuringly. "They're just surprised, Will. A lot has happened, and they're trying to process it all."

Ariadne, walking on Percy's other side, nodded in agreement. "It's not every day that such events unfold. Give them time."

As they approached the Hermes Cabin, Travis and Conner Stoll, the new head counselors, stepped forward. They looked nervous but determined.

"Percy," Travis began, "we wanted to apologize on behalf of our cabin. We had no idea what Luke was planning, and we don't support his actions."

Conner nodded vigorously. "We promise, we don't want any part of his goals."

Percy smiled warmly at them. "I only hold Luke responsible. As long as the rest of the Hermes Cabin doesn't support him, I have no grudge against you."

The brothers visibly relaxed, relief washing over their faces. "Thank you, Percy," Travis said. "That means a lot to us."

As they continued towards the dining pavilion, Percy noticed that there were fewer people at the Hermes table. Most of the unclaimed demigods, including Chris Rodrigues, were absent.

"Are they delayed for lunch?" Percy asked, her brow furrowing in concern.

Travis winced. "Shortly after the Dioscuri arrived to arrest Luke, a lot of demigods quietly slipped away from camp when Mr. D was called away."

Percy's heart sank at the news. "The more demigods swearing themselves to Kronos, the easier it will be for the Titan King's essence to rise from Tartarus," she murmured.

Ariadne placed a comforting hand on Percy's shoulder. "We'll find a way to stop them, Percy. My father in law might insist on being blind to the situation, but the rest of the Olympians are on alert."

Except Athena, Percy thought. The goddess of wisdom was determined to follow her father's lead as according to Artemis. But the rest of the gods would be ready to act if needed. Or get a demigod to act for them. Time would tell.

As they reached the dining pavilion, the whispers grew louder. Percy could hear snippets of conversations, all centered around the recent events.

"Did you hear? Luke almost killed Will!"

"I can't believe he stole the bolt to start a war."

"Poor Percy, she's been through so much."

Percy took a deep breath and held her head high. She knew she had to be strong for Will and for the camp. As they sat down at the table, Dionysus approached them, his usual grumpy demeanor softened by concern.

"Welcome back, Percy," he said, his voice uncharacteristically gentle. Percy blinked and pinched herself, incredulous that Dionysus was being so pleasant.

"I'm glad to see you and William are safe."

"Thank you, Mr. D," Percy replied. "It's good to be back."

Dionysus turned to Ariadne, a rare smile tugging at his lips. "And you, my dear, it's always a pleasure to see you."

Percy suppressed a snort, understanding why Dionysus was being so nice to her. It was all for Ariadne's benefit. Well, at least it meant that the god of wine truly loved and appreciated her friend. After what Theseus had done, it never hurt to be careful.

Ariadne smiled warmly at her husband. "It's good to see you too, Dionysus."

As they ate, Percy couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. The camp was on edge, and the threat of Kronos loomed over them all. But she knew they had to stay strong and united if they were to face the challenges ahead.

Percy and Will sat down at Poseidon's table and prepared the customary offerings for the gods. Percy was relieved to see the campers follow the formula she had shown to them not long ago. An offering for each Olympian, even if she noticed the Apollo table make the meat pieces for Zeus and Ares practically pea sized. She prepared her own offerings, the customary twelve, Hestia, Hades, Zagreus, Asclepius, Clio, Ariadne and each one of the muses. Will followed her lead and he stuck very close to her, as it had become his habit since Luke threw the dagger. Percy looked at Will's red eyes with concern. She would have to make sure he got enough sleep from now on. Will was a growing child, he needed to get a full night's sleep, it was not negotiable.

As she was pondering what to do about Will's recent trauma she almost bumped into Clarisse and Ellis. Clarisse's face was carefully blank and Ellis looked rather guilty.

"Is this about your dad?" She asked them as they walked to the hearth together.

Clarisse' lips pursed but she refused to give anything away. Percy looked at Ellis.

"We are sorry that our dad framed you." Ellis told her.

Percy grimaced.

"Your dad was tricked by Luke and his patron. And even if he wasn't I am not in the habit of condemning the kids for the parent's actions."

Clarisse's face twitched and she finally grit out with great reluctance.

"Great fight. Beckendorff managed to get some footage of it. Can't believe you beat our dad."

Percy gave Clarisse an incredulous stare.

"I didn't actually beat him? He attacked without me challenging him formally first. Immortals need to be challenged first in order to fight a mortal at their full ability. He didn't and that nerfed him a lot. Don't take that fight as a sample of his actual fighting ability. Had I done the mistake of actually challenging him it would have been a disaster for me. I wouldn't have lasted five seconds. And even with him nerfed and handicapped it still would have gone badly for me if the twins and my dad had not shown up when they did."

Clarise looked stunned for a moment before she smiled and looked haughty around at the eavesdropping demigods.

"Well, of course. My dad is the god of war. There had to be a reason he lost to a kid."

Percy rolled her eyes and started burning her offerings. She heard someone mutter that Percy still got first blood on the god of war but Clarisse quickly descended on however that was. Not wanting to get in an argument Percy quickly ushered Will back to the Poseidon table.

My back is pointed towards the tall tree as I effortlessly play my golden lyre. I suddenly stop when I see a lean boy almost float towards me, his assortment of tight and loose curls bouncing with each step. He sits down, one leg over the other and tilts his head with curiosity.
"Go on!" He encourages me.
I stare at him blankly
"Please? You are exceptionally good" He gives a big grin, which intrigues me.
I let out a warm smile and wave him closer. He sits beside me and I take his hand in mine. I overlap my hands over his, which are uncertain and chipped at the nails. His hands have calluses and scruff spotted on them, which made me thirst for more knowledge about this boy. I start to play a simple song as I guide his hands through each note. His hands are the slightest bit shaky, but I continue through.
"It's like a map. The strings are the locations while your hands are yourself. Just think of the notes as directions, and you follow them to get a pleasant sound. That is all it is." I say, in hopes that would calm his nerves.
"I'm not much of a musician." He admits as his hands find a way to his knees which are now to his chest.
"Nonsense," I counter. "Everyone is a musician, some just do not know how to express the melody they create."
He giggles at my words and introduces himself.
"I'm Hyacinthus," His deep brown eyes flutter when he says this, my heart does the same.
"Apollo," I say, not sure of his reaction.
"That is why you are so very talented at the lyre?"
I laugh. "Yes, I can teach you"
"You can? I apologize, of course you can, but are you sure? That would take a lot of time, I am not a very fast learner"
"I'm a patient teacher"

His dark curls took me by storm. How, how could such a boy be that flawless? No, he was more than a boy, no boy was that perfect. He was considerably tall, no taller than I. His complexion reminded me of forest bark that had not been touched by light. His chestnut hair perfectly curved around his soft jaw and curled up from his neck. His personality mirrored that of a bee's, striking yet curious, which evokes me with childlike wonder.He looks at me and his lips draw up, a small smile. A smile that could bring me to my knees without hesitation. I start to snap out of my daydream, then I see his face, Thamyris. His red hair, and pasty white skin. His eyes frost with a green glaze. He stood taller than I. He is a lengthy and grown man, not worthy of Hyacinthus.I can tell his eyes are filled with love for my Hyacinthus. Thamyris is a well-known musician, but more well-known than I? Never. My blood boiled at the thought of him coming close to Hyacinthus. My eyes fill with rage and I walk up to him without thinking."Hello, Thamyris.""Apollo, how is my favorite sun olympian?""I am the only sun olympian?""Yes, yes" He laughs, I grind my teeth."Thamyris, I have decided to hold a banquet for you to rejoice in your musical talent," I say with false innocence, having no idea what I am thinking."A banquet you say? I shall be there." He laughs."Great.""Will... Will he be there?" He asks, referring to Hyacinthus.I pause. "Yes.""Good. I will see you later tonight then?""Yes, I suppose you will."I acknowledge him and walk off. Thamyris, the man not worth the boy.I walk to see Hyacinthus. Perfect timing I say under my breath."Hm?" He smiles and giggles, his hair swaying in the wind."Sunflower, how are you?""Doing well, nothing new. Any news for you?""Yes actually," I take a deep breath. "Hyacinthus... How would you like to accompany me to a banquet I'm hosting? Just a small one, will not last through the night." I grab the cloth of my tunic, straightening it out.He smiles once more. "I would love to. Who will be there?"I take a breath of relief. "Anyone can come. I know Thamyris will be there, I am holding it for him."His smile fades."You are holding it for... Thamyris?""Yes, Hyacinthus, is that a problem?""No! No. It's just that- Well you know how I feel about him."He is right. I do know. The way the fiery man lured Hyacinthus to his bed, and undressed him without his consent. A disgusting man, but not uncommon in Sparta.I grab Hyacinthus's cold, limp hand, and kiss his knuckle. I hold his hand to my chest, my tunic creasing around his soft hand."Trust me on this, I will not let him near you. I am throwing him a banquet for reasons I can not say just yet, but I promise, I do not like that man any more than you.""Alright, 'Pello." His eyes are stricken with worry, but I need him for this."Thank you, Sunflower. You will not regret it."He walks off, and I feel guilty. Why am I feeling guilty? I vowed to protect him. I will make sure Thamyris never even glances in his direction again. It is the stars that swear to be there every night, they never break that promise and make even the darkest of nights bright, so, I will not break mine either. Hyacinthus will never feel unsafe again.Nothing more was to be said, so I walk away, a cloud of remorse forming above my head.

The banquet is gracefully decorated with candles, vines, and food from places I can not pronounce. I want this to be remembered throughout history, even if it is a ruse.I grasp Hyacinthus's hand, now warm and shaky. He looks at me, tilting his head up just the slightest to make direct eye contact."You okay?" He gives a sympathetic smile."Of course, what about you?" I kiss his soft lips, I can feel him smile as he kisses me back."I think nervous is the right word." He pulls away."I will not let him come near you, I promise, just stick with me." I squeeze his hand. He nods and I smile. I feel bad, but I will make it up to him. We will hang out, just me and him, no one else.Soon, Thamyris arrived.He entered the room with the confidence of an Ox, he might as well be as clumsy as one. He touches all the decorations that took hours to put up, and I bite my lip with annoyance.He keeps looking behind his neck, searching for Hyacinthus. Hyacinthus is with me, so I do not greet him like you usually would.The guests start to roll in and I smile. My Muses are set up in the back, playing the most amazing music, I really outdid myself.Everyone takes to the floor and starts to dance in diverse ways, I grab Hyacinthus's hands and I drag him over.He laughs and smiles as I hold his hands and move them up and down in a playful motion. He is not a very good dancer, so he relies on me for most moves. He holds me tight and I smile.But soon I cannot stall much longer, and I have to make an announcement about Thamyris because he is the whole reason I'm holding this banquet.I let go of Hyacinthus's hand and walk up to the front of the room, no one's attention directed towards me, yet."Excuse me, I would like to raise a toast to Thamyris, the reason we are all here tonight!" I shout to grab everyone's attention.Thamyris waves his hand and smiles. I force a smile back as he walks up towards me."Well, I am not surprised. I am the best musician here," The crowd laughs. "I just thank you all for recognizing that, and celebrating it with me! In preparation, I wrote a song tonight, just for you!"He walks back to my table and grabs my lyre as he pats my Hyacinthus on the shoulder, I cringe with resentment, but I do not say anything as he walks back to his place next to me.He grabs the instrument, and starts to play. His fingers dance across the golden strings like a leaf in the wind, while the sound plays a beautiful soft and confident tone, perfectly mixing the 2 opposites together, and for a second I forget why I am here. The music starts to become sick and streaky as I remember what I need to do.I started to alter the tone of my lyre so it sounds untuned without touching it.I watch in delight as Thamyris's eyes grow wider and more impatient by the second. He frantically inspects lyre while snapping his neck back to the crowd."Thamyris, I thought you were good?" I taunt as his skin grows as red as his hair."I- I am. I swear to Zeus, I am good! Better than the Muses themselves!""Is that so?" I laugh, and call over one of my Muses. As she comes, her white and golden dress flows behind her, her dark hair following."Yes, Apollo?" Erato asks with a sing-song voice."Our guest, Thamyris here, says he is even better than you Muses?"Erato tilts her head. "Even better than I, Lord Apollo?""Even better than you""Well then. I challenge you to a music contest! Whoever wins will be declared the best in all of Sparta!"And whoever loses?" He asks."Will face a punishment designed by the other""Very well"It was settled, the competition would begin shortly. The crowd is still as water, and one word could create a tidal wave.Erato summons her Lyre and starts to play. Such a beautiful tale that I can visualize it. A million different interpretations can be imagined from her song. A hero's life cut short, a rival romance, or a happy ever after, something so rare, even I am impressed. I look over to see Thamyris. He purses his lips and runs his fingers through his curly hair.Erato finally stops, the crowd is in awe, no words are spoken, the water is still unbothered. She looks at Thamyris and gives a half sympathetic smile."Well, that was nothing- I could do better!" Thamyris sneers while tripping over his own words.She nods, as if giving him the right of way to go and try to be better than herself.He hesitates for a moment, but then grabs my lyre, I cut him off. "Ah, see that is mine, meaning, you cannot use it. Good luck though!" Erato glances at me and silently her face reads 'Really? Just let him use your lyre. But I do not.He spits at her feet, and for a second I am about to maim him right here, but Erato cuts me off."Borrow mine. I will not mess with it or anything, you probably forgot yours, just borrow mine." She speaks softly, turning him away from the crowd so he is not embarrassed.I stare in awe. She is too nice. "Erato-""Apollo, you can not make it impossible on him."She is right, I nod, my golden hair sweeping in front of my face. I tuck it into my ponytail to see Erato handing her lyre to Thamyris.Thamyris scoffs, and snatched her lyre. I turn to her and I whisper "I'll make you a new one", because Thamyris would somehow find a way to ruin hers.She nudges me in the side, and lets him play.He uncomfortably grasps the instrument, as it was not fitted and carved for his unnaturally long fingers. Eventually he situates himself and starts to strum it. He manages to play a beautiful tune. I hate to say it, but I start to become engaged with it. I listen closely as a bead of sweat trickles down Thamyris's freakishly long face. His pupils are shaking in the white of his eyes, and I give a sickly grin.The audience listens intensely, their full attention on Thamyris. I just sit back and watch. A little trick I learned from Dionysus: People crack under pressure. Dionysus has often said that people will mess up on various things when they feel pressure to be perfect. That is what I'm counting on.Thamyris slowly gets wrapped up in his own mind and his fears eat away at him. He starts to go off beat while feeling the audience's eyes burn into his hands. His hands eventually slip off of Erato's lyre and he is furious. He throws the instrument to the ground and tears swell up in his eyes."That- That is not fair!! It is not my lyre! It's Erato's fault!!" Thamyris stammers, and Erato seems hurt. Her lyre, a gift from me to her, is shattered into a million silver pieces, and she is devastated.She looked at him, and with despair in her eyes she yells. "You were challenged to a competition. You lost fairly. You took your anger out on my property. For that you shall suffer. You will never look nor speak on music ever again." And with that, she looks at me to finish it offI smile and I blind and mute him.Thamyris grabs his throat and tries to speak, but no sound comes out. His eyes, once frosted with green, are frosted with a gray film. His head turns in every direction in hopes that his sight might be magically regained, but it does not.The first still water, is now a tidal wave of commotion.

Once the banquet ended, I walk up to Hyacinthus."So, what did you think of it?" I ask, pretty happy with myself."How could you do that, Apollo?!" He snaps at me. "How could you hurt him like that?" He takes a step back from me, like he is appalled by my actions."Hyacinthus, he hurt you. He deserved it!" I counter."Sure, he was not the best person, but you should not have blinded and muted him!! That could ruin someone's life!""He ruined yours, I was just returning the favor.""Apollo! He might have hurt me, but you should not hurt him back!" Hyacinthus rebukes."Sunflower-""Do not call me that." He walks away, I reach out to him, and he hits my hand out of his view."Leave me alone, I do not want to have anything to do with you, not now, not ever." Tears swell up in his eyes, I made him cry.I am speechless. This is nothing more to say, so he walks away.I am left there, alone. I hurt Hyacinthus. I hurt Hyacinthus. I swore I would not, and I did. It is all my fault. I never really took in account that things could be wrong because of me, but I think this is the worst thing I could've done.I punch the nearest tree and scream to anyone listening.The world seems to go on, kids in Sparta are throwing a discus at each other, and I yearn for the days I did not feel the guilt and loathe the touch of the green grass on my feet. I loathe the wind shoving against my back. I loathe the rich colors of the flowers. I loathe the sun beating against my back. I loathe myself for hurting him. I loathe the world, because everything reminds me of him. I loathe.I fall back onto the grass, the soft stems folding under my arms. I pluck one blade. I did not deserve Hyacinthus I think. I pick at the green till there is just a bare space where my hands lay.I stand up, a handful of grass between each one of my fingers. I open my fist up, and a strong gust of wind blows each one from my grasp."Feels like no matter what I do, something will go wrong" I cry to the invisible audience, hoping somewhere, somehow, Hyacinthus is watching.The wind blows my hair so it is no longer tied back.Message received, I mumble as I look towards the wind, now quiet, and still. I turn and walk away from any sign of him, I cannot bring myself to think of him, but that is all I can do.I decide that painting will be the best use of my time. Stroke after stroke I paint.
